PROCTEXT.PARA: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Sir Condor Laucke) took the chair at 10.30 a.m., and read prayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MAUNSELL

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from seven citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democratically elected by the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is not representative of the women of Australia;
That the National Women's Advisory Council is a discriminatory and sexist imposition on Australian women as Australian men do not have a National Men's Advisory Council imposed on them.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the National Women's Advisory Council be abolished to ensure that Australian women have equal opportunity with Australian men of having issues of concern to them considered, debated and voted on by their Parliamentary representatives without intervention and interference by an unrepresentative 'Advisory Council'.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: HARRADINE

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the following petition from 848 citizens of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

The decision to drastically reduce the ABC Melbourne Showband to half its normal strength is both deplorable and in the worst interests of the listening public. This unique orchestra must not be allowed to disintegrate in consideration of its proven past achievements and present reputation.
We, therefore, call on the Federal Government to rescind this decision and make more money available for the continuance of the full Showband.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That the National Women's Advisory Council has not been democractically elected by the women of Australia;

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: -I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Health Commission (Amendment) Ordinance 1981, contained in Australian Capital Territory Ordinance No. 6 of 1981, and made under the Seat of Government (Administration) Act 1910, be disallowed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. I refer to a question asked by Senator Colston on Tuesday of this week in which he asked whether the Minister could name any multi-billion dollar project that had begun without a pilot plant. Did the Minister say in answer to that question that Rheinbraun, the West German brown coal company, intended to proceed in the Latrobe Valley without a pilot plant? Has his attention been drawn to a statement by the Managing Director of Rheinbraun Australia, Dr Klix, in which he said that the company was currently carrying out a study of the Latrobe Valley project and, depending on the results of that study, a decision would then be made to embark on a feasibility study? Did Dr Klix also say that only after this feasibility study would a decision be made about building a commercial plant? In view of those statements, does the Minister believe that he has fairly and frankly told the Senate the real situation in relation to the Rheinbraun plant in the Latrobe Valley?

—I made the statement, as Senator Button has said. I read the report of the President of Rheinbraun. It is in no way divergent from what I said. The spokesman for Rheinbraun has indicated that the company does not intend, as I understand it, to go through the pilot plant situation but, having done feasibility studies, assuming they are carried out successfully, the company will then decide to go commercial. That was my understanding at the start and it is my understanding of the reading of the Rheinbraun statement now.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I also ask the Minister: Did he say, in answer to the question on Tuesday, that contracts had been arranged for the commercial stages of the process?

—I would need to look at the answer. My view is that all I said was that there was an agreement between the Victorian Government and Rheinbraun and that three stages were envisaged, and I read out what the third stage is. From memory, I did not say that the contract for the commercial plant was in place, but I would need to refresh my mind on that. If Senator Button has any evidence otherwise, he might raise it in Question Time and I will look at it.

—I draw the attention of the Minister representing the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs to the latest report of the Industries Assistance Commission on the Australian car industry. Has the Minister seen the statement by the Managing Director of General Motors-Holden's Ltd that, if the Government accepted the draft recommendations, GMH would have to commence planning to down-scale its business? Can the Minister advise whether there has been any development in Government consideration of the draft recommendations? Can the Minister give an assurance that in any consideration the effect on the South Australian economy will be an important factor?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industries Assistance Commission, I understand, released a report on the motor vehicle plan post-1984 about a month ago. In the report the IAC was very critical of the present assistance measures comprising the 85 per cent local content plan, the 80-20 market sharing policy and the tariff of 57 1/2 per cent applying to all imports. It sought an endorsement for a longer term objective by the Government of a general policy approach, which is for the passenger motor vehicle and component industry to be afforded similar forms and levels of assistance to those which are currently available to other sections of Australian industry.

ANSWER.PARA: Broadly, the IAC was seeking discontinuance of the present marketing plan, that imported vehicles and original equipment components be initially dutiable at 60 per cent, and that the rates be reduced by five percentage points each year so that by 1 January 1990 imports would be dutiable at the far lower rate of 35 per cent. Allied to that, vehicle producers were to be provided with a basic by-law entitlement of 10 per cent of the value of their production, while export facilitation credits of 7 1/2 per cent of the value of production were to apply to manufacturers as well as to component manufacturers. Specialist component producers were to be entitled to earn export facilitation credits equal to 20 per cent of their original equipment sales.

That is by way of background to the question from Senator Davidson. In particular he asked whether the Government has developed its consideration of the IAC recommendations. As I understand the situation, the IAC is currently hearing further submissions from industry. Indeed, I think the statement quoted by Senator Davidson in his question is in fact from a submission made by General Motors-Holden's Ltd to the IAC in response to its original draft report. Consequently it should be seen in the light that a further report will be coming from the IAC. When that will be, of course, is in the hands of the IAC. Upon the receipt of that report the Government will consider the situation and determine its position as to future policy. Senator Davidson also sought assurances that South Australia's special situation would be taken into account in this matter during consideration of the IAC report. I can assure him that the Government is most aware of the particular situation in that State, which is heavily dependent upon the motor vehicle industry, and will be taking that into account in making its final determination.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In view of the dramatic fall in the market capitalisation value of the Rundle twins, Central Pacific Minerals NL and Southern Pacific Petroleum NL, from $1,268m in January of this year to $462m on Tuesday's stock exchanges and as this peak had been achieved largely through the continued talking up of the Rundle project by the Minister, the Prime Minister and the Deputy Prime Minister, I now ask the Minister: What action does he intend taking to ensure that false hopes are not also built up in the minds of potential investors and the thousands of unemployed persons in South Australia because of the continued talking up of the Roxby Downs uranium venture in that State by the South Australian Premier, Mr Tonkin, as a great employer of labour with resulting financial benefits to that State? Finally, will the Minister bring down a firm statement to the Senate giving full details of the maximum number of persons who will be employed at Roxby Downs and the expected length of time of this employment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I, in my statements both in the Senate and in public, have not talked up Rundle. On the contrary, I have repeated a series of statements that are available to the Senate in Hansard and in which I have indicated that measures of this kind, of this magnitude, raise great technical problems, that there was no absolute proof of the technology and that it was therefore to the immense credit of the partners that they should undertake the project. In fact, I sounded a note of caution and, I repeat, of cautious optimism because I believed it was in the immense interest of the people of Australia that that should be done.

ANSWER.PARA: On the other hand, of course, since we are talking now about talking up and talking down, I remind the Senate that several days ago Labor Party senators, including Senator Walsh, said that Rundle was dead. I want to remind the Senate of what the Labor spokesman on energy and minerals in another place, Paul Keating, said on Rundle two days ago in a television interview in which I participated. It is diametrically opposed to every word that the Labor Party has said in the Senate, and this ought to be known to the people. Richard Carleton said to him:
So, Mr Keating, finally sir, in your view will Rundle eventually go ahead in another 20, 30, 40 years--

TALK.START.PARA: —Who in this place has suggested otherwise?
—The interjection is: 'Who suggested otherwise?'. Senator Walsh said it is dead, and the words are on the record. Let me now say what Mr Keating said. He said:

ANSWER.PARA: I don't think it will take that long-
Meaning, it will not take up to 20 years-
there are two very good Australian companies involved, Esso is a world energy leader-
In other words, he was paying tribute to the Rundle partners. He continued:
I think they are certainly, certainly will be developed. I hope they will. I just think that the time frame is longer than 1987 . . .
That is in contradistinction. They being things that have been said, let us hope that in the end the Labor Party will find itself not diametrically opposed to its spokesman, but otherwise.
Roxby Downs is in the process of being defined. The early indications are that it could be one of the largest mining complexes in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't tell us that again. You let us down on Rundle.

—If it is the aim of the Labor Party to denigrate every enterprise that is being established, then let the Labor Party take that responsibility. I will be happy to ascertain from the Bureau of Mineral Resources its present assessment of Roxby Downs. I will be happy to come into this--
—You might get them to do Rundle while they are on the job.

—The Bureau of Mineral Resources had indicated that the shale oil deposit at Rundle was of high quality-indeed, world quality. We did have the knowledge and advice of the Bureau. That has not been varied in any way at all. I will be very happy, in the interests of the Australian community, to ask the Bureau of Mineral Resources what its present knowledge of the status of Roxby Downs is. I hope, in the interests of all South Australians, that Roxby Downs, along with the Cooper Basin and the production of liquid fuels, is developed, because if these things succeed South Australia will be one of the front runner States under a State Liberal Government.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer to the recent re-election for a term of four long years of Mr John Halfpenny as the Victorian State secretary of the Amalgamated Metal Workers and Shipwrights Union. I ask: Was the total number of votes in that election about 11,000? Was that a very high proportion vote in union elections generally and in particular for this union? Was the margin about 400 votes out of 11,000?
—One is enough.

—I think he might have miscounted this time. Can the Minister confirm or deny the very strong rumours which are circulating in the industry, that the last three ballot boxes from which votes were counted contained a 98 per cent vote for Mr Halfpenny?

—The honourable senator has asked me a question about the election for the position of Victorian branch secretary of the AMWSU. I have some information about that election in my brief. My advice is that the election was by secret postal ballot, conducted by the AMWSU Victorian branch returning officer, and that it closed on 30 March 1981. The Department understands that the results of the election were: Mr Halfpenny, 5,859 votes, to Mr Kelly, 5,439 votes-a majority in favour of Mr Halfpenny of 420 votes out of the 11,298 valid votes which were received. I am not aware of the rumour referred to by the honourable senator. However, I am advised that there have been a number of Press reports, following the declaration of the ballot, suggesting that some members of the union may be considering a Federal Court of Australia challenge as to the validity of the election. I think most honourable senators will be aware that under the Conciliation and Arbitration Act provision is made for any member of a registered organisation such as the AMWSU, or a person who has been a member of such an organisation within the preceding 12 months, who claims that an irregularity has occurred in or in connection with an election for an office in that organisation, to lodge an application for an inquiry into the matter by the Industrial Division of the Federal Court. In other words, if there is concern of the type referred to by the honourable senator about the last three ballot boxes, the Act provides a means whereby an election may be challenged.

—I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my Gallery of a highly respected former member of this place, Mr John Marriott. We tender to him a warm welcome on his return to the precincts of this place.

—My question is directed to the Attorney-General. Is it the case that a person who holds an office of profit under the Crown cannot, under the Constitution, be elected to this Parliament? Is it the case that the resignation of the Liberal Party candidate for Wentworth, Mr Peter Coleman, from his office of profit as Administrator of Norfolk Island, has not yet been gazetted? Does this make Mr Coleman ineligible to be elected at Saturday's Wentworth by-election?
—I will have to take notice of that question and investigate the matter raised.
—I wish to ask a supplementary question. Can we expect an answer while the Senate is sitting today, as the by-election will be held on Saturday?
—I will give an answer as soon as I can.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. As the Federal Government received more than $2,000m in crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas levies last year, and Queenslanders supplied at least $300m of this figure, can the Minister inform me why, in view of Queensland's vast distances and need for a large decentralised road network, less than half this amount-namely, only $115m-was returned to Queensland for Queensland roads?

—All honourable senators will know that revenue from one source of tax or charge goes into general revenue. It is not identified for return for a specific purpose. For example, we do not return the revenue from tobacco to smokers. Therefore one should understand that if one looks at the disbursal of moneys to Queensland one should look at the totality of the disbursal in all its forms. I refer to equalisation under tax sharing arrangements. Queensland was a mendicant State and therefore received extra money. Moneys are received for education, hospitals and for a variety of other things. I would be happy to look at the totality of the disbursals. I can appreciate the honourable senator's keen interest in a State which has two great interests. It has a hugeness of size, and therefore a dependence on its roads. Also, it has one of the most exciting prospects for development that Australia has seen. In that regard the co-partnership between the Commonwealth and the State is such that that development is proceeding at an unprecedented rate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. Why do Government leaders, including the Minister, constantly stress the overriding importance to our future energy requirements of oil from shale, oil from coal and energy derived from our uranium reserves, to the exclusion of farm based energy sources? Is the Minister aware that Australia could produce most of its oil requirement through farm based methods from an area less than one-third of that which we now use to grow wheat? Why is it that when there are well over 2,000 species of plant in the world which can produce an oil almost identical to that which is drilled out of the ground, not a single major government backed research program at present is being directed to this alternative? When is the Government going to withdraw its support from costly white elephant energy projects, such as Rundle is threatening to become, and begin to look seriously at farm based alternative energy programs?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is keenly interested in the production of energy from all renewable sources, be they biomass, solar, wind power or any such sources. We will pursue that to the maximum. A significant number of undertakings are going on in Australia at this moment on a research basis. I will be happy to provide Senator Chipp with the compendium, which is world acknowledged, of the research in all forms going on in Australia, including very considerable research being developed towards the production of energy from biomass. However, I want to give Senator Chipp--
—With Government backing?

—Yes, with Government backing. Let me say that at this moment, for example, in Mackay a major experiment is being conducted into the production of petranol-that is, a mixture of methanol and gasolene, or the gasahol type of mixture-in which the sugar company and, I think, the Shell company are working together as a start towards regionalisation. So that we can get the matter into perspective, there are two things that must necessarily run. One is that in Australia, as in the rest of the world, when considering biomass, because we are strongly capable of producing alcohols from sugars and starches but not right at this moment from cellulose and wood products, which would be exciting, there is a great conflict between food and fuel, the use of acreages for food in competition with fuel. In a world where people are starving one must be careful not to shrink food acreages. I will give Senator Chipp an illustration. If we were to try to extend by 10 per cent the production in Australia of gasolene from ethanol, it is estimated that it would be necessary to put under cultivation an extra 300,000 to 400,000 hectares of sugar cane or the alternative. That would take up all the available arable land. Let me go further and say that we set up a study to look at sugar beet production in Tasmania. We were sad to have to report that the experts had said that one of the limitations was the availability of land.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware that there are interests in various kinds of sub-economic areas where, for example, wild rubber plants and other plants are growing. It is possible, and it is only at that level at the moment, that that will be looked at in the future. Studies are being made, both here and in other parts of the world, to see whether that can be done. If it can be done we will be keen to look at it rapidly, and we will be pressing on in that regard. There is serious contemplation that the Ord River will be used for growing sugar cane to make ethanol. Wherever we can we will be doing that. Senator Chipp asked why we are looking at oil shale and coal.

TALK.START.PARA: —And uranium.

—And uranium. First of all, the world at large is unable to produce the kinds of sugars and starches from biomass that could resolve its problems. The acreages available in the world and our present technology are not good enough for that at the moment. One hopes that they will be good enough in the future. I stress that we want renewable energy if we can get it. The world at large is also faced with the situation that even if America, Canada, Australia, South Africa and China put all the coal they can at sea, the pressure of infrastructure and costs will be so enormous that coal will not totally solve the situation. The pollution from coal and the great health effects on the world being identified now are very serious, and therefore there is an almost total recognition around the world of the inevitability of using nuclear energy. I notice that there is a tendency to say, and I see that it is being repeated now by Mr Keating: 'Shale and oil synthetics have a place, but that is down the track'. I wonder whether anyone can say to me--
—Nearly as far down the track as you are.
—Well, Mr President-

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I again draw your attention, as I have on two previous occasions, to the fact that the Minister is giving one of his long, windy replies and is canvassing everything except the question. He is killing the time for members on both sides of the chamber to put their questions. I ask you, with respect, again to draw attention to your previous rulings.
—There is no point of order. I again say that in presenting questions and answers honourable senators should be as brief as possible because we seek the greatest number possible.
—Senator Walsh interjected. Let me inject the report of what Mr Keating said in today's Australian Financial Review regarding Rundle. He is reported as saying yesterday:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . that the Rundle deposit probably had the best potential for oil from shale production in Australia-possibly the world-and the project would probably eventually go ahead.

I wonder how much that statement conflicts. Having said that I say-this is a deadly serious answer-that nobody can say that the Middle East will remain stable for any number of years. Nobody can say that we can depend on getting our oil from the Middle East for one, 2, 3, 4, 5, 10 or 20 years. Can anybody say that the threat to Poland will not start the building up of defence stocks and a run on oil around the world?

In that respect Australia cannot simply regard its necessities as a day to day buildup of shuffling an orchestration of energy sources which we can do relatively easily. It must put itself in a position in which the technology is here as fast as possible to meet critical world situations and to get an understanding of the technology of coal and shale so we can bring that into play as fast as we possibly can. Equally, I say to the honourable senator that the likelihood is that countries will make a run on coal out of coal mines for a while and then decide to switch to uranium. It is vital that in Australia the technology of chemical extraction from coal and shale should be in a position to substitute.

I hope that that is, in fact, a precise answer to the various points the honourable senator made. The question is an important one. I regret the length of the answer, but the necessity for it was there.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: RETARDED CHILDREN'S WELFARE ASSOCIATION OF TASMANIA

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Minister for Social Security aware that the Retarded Children's Welfare Association of Tasmania is now imposing a charge of $2 a day on all who use its activity centre? Is this charge an allowable tax deduction on parental income? If the answer is no and as the Association applies a means test to parental income so that no handicapped child will be denied access to the activity centre because of his or her parents' inability to pay, does the Minister concede that there is an anomaly in the area?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —My understanding is that the Retarded Children's Welfare Association of Tasmania is an association under which a series of activity therapy centres have been operated in different parts of Tasmania for some years. The organisation came to my attention because it made a request for additional funding either late last year or early this year.

ANSWER.PARA: My understanding is that at least one of the elements of that organisation, the activity therapy centre at Devonport, has charged the fee mentioned by the honourable senator for a number of years. I think the same fee has now been imposed by the other activity therapy centres which are run in different parts of Tasmania. I received a letter to that effect from the State secretary of the organisation in February.

The organisation also advised me that the charge would be remitted if financial hardship could be proved. That, in a sense, picks up the last part of the honourable senator's question. In other words, if it is a case of hardship, my understanding is that there would be no detriment to the person seeking to attend the centre.

The matter of tax deductibility is not a matter for me but for the Treasurer. I presume that the only case in which deductibility might be possible is if the fees are regarded as educational expenses and if it is possible for the taxpayer to claim concessional deductions. Of course, not all taxpayers do claim because of the $1,590 or so general allowance given to all taxpayers. I will have that aspect of the question checked with the Treasurer and let the honourable senator know the precise position.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for National Development and Energy. In answer to Senator Tate yesterday, he referred to an alleged printing error in his 2 February statement on alternative liquid fuels. At a Press conference on that day, 2 February, he was asked to explain the inconsistencies between the table in the National Energy Advisory Committee report dated July 1980 and the table in his associated Press release, both of which he released on 2 February. Why did he not claim on that occasion that the discrepancy was due to a printing error? Why did he claim on that occasion that the Press release had been deliberately altered to incorporate more up to date and, I might add, more optimistic information?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the latter part of the question, the alteration of the Press release to bring it up to date did not relate to those figures at all, so there is no connection between them. I have made it perfectly clear what happened. In a letter to the National Times, I wrote, and it was published:

ANSWER.PARA: In another of your columns in the same issue you drew attention to an obvious error in the table attached to the press release on the NEAC report on Alternative Liquid Fuels. The table attached to the press release was of course intended to be a precise reproduction of the table in the NEAC report. An error was made by a departmental officer in preparing the table in typescript form for use with the press release.

I think that is perfectly clear. Bear in mind the simple situation that that document and that table were published at exactly the same time. There would be no sense, assuming a malign intent, for the Government to print a different table. The error was made by a departmental officer. It was corrected. I made a public statement on that. I was not aware of the error until it was brought to my notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask a supplementary question. I presume the discrepancies to which Senator Carrick was referring, just to get the record straight, are these: The NEAC report referred to a possible lead time for shale oil of 8 to 15 years; the Press statement had cut that back from 8 to 10; and the Press statement had changed to 'good' the original assessment which was 'moderate to good'. Assuming that we are talking about the same thing, I again ask Senator Carrick: Why did he claim on 2 February that his Press release, which presented a more optimistic picture, had been deliberately altered because more up to date information had been received since the report, which is dated July 1980, had been prepared?

—I have the Press statement in front of me, and I have the alterations as made by the departmental officer, and not by myself, nor on my instructions. These alterations were made purely because it was realised, when the report was roneod, that it had not been put accurately.
—Why did you say it was deliberately changed?

—Senator Walsh should contain his choler. We usually find that the greater his indignation, the fewer his facts. He is usually very indignant, and one can therefore draw a conclusion. I have the table here. What the departmental officers have done is to correct it. What I said was that the NEAC report had in fact been presented quite some months before--
—That contradicts what you said two minutes ago.
—Two minutes ago I said--
—You said they were both prepared at the same time.

—The NEAC report was presented to the Government quite some months before my February public Press statement. What I said in my statement was that in the intervening period more optimistic information had come into the Government's possession regarding the various sources of energy achievement. For example, as has been indicated, there has been a progressive upgrading of the likelihood of getting oil out of Bass Strait beyond the present decade, and a flattening of what was the projected fall-off. So what I said in my statement was that we are able to be a little more optimistic than NEAC because of information that had come to hand since then.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources to an article entitled 'Farm Future in Asian Invasion' which appeared in the National Farmer of 15 March 1981. I ask the Minister to comment on this article and, in particular, the claim it makes in these terms:

QUESTION.PARA: The embryo Pacific community is, potentially, the most powerful influence over Australia's export farm industries and their future since the disastrous collapse of our markets in Europe nearly a decade ago.

Does the Minister agree with the point made in this article that we need firm long term agreements to achieve the maximum in trade? Does the Minister also agree that Australia's economic future will depend largely on its involvement in the formation of a Pacific economic community? If so, what action is being taken to ensure that Australia plays a more progressive role in the establishment of good trading relations with South East Asia and the wider area of the Pacific Basin region?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There can be no doubt as to the importance of the countries of the Pacific rim to Australia's present and future trade and development. The Pacific rim concept has been under increasing examination at both private and governmental levels in recent times. The Australian Government is active in this process, but it is as yet too early to indicate the likely outcome. Australia is taking every opportunity to expand its trade with Asia and with other markets for agricultural products and raw materials and the Government has a continuing policy of seeking assured opportunities of access to those markets. Long term contracts can serve a useful role in assuring our exporters of stable conditions of access to markets and ensuring reliable supplies for our customers. They are, of course, commercial arrangements and it is a matter for the industries concerned to determine to what extent they should commit themselves forward under such arrangements.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government, for its part, will always lend appropriate support to our exporters in securing and implementing long term contractual arrangements for the sale of Australian commodities. In line with the importance the Government attaches to its relations with countries of the Pacific rim, Australia is continually seeking to strengthen trading ties with those countries through such means as the negotiation of trade agreements, regular consultations, visits by Ministers and officials as well as specific measures. I would be happy to provide the honourable senator with further information if he should require it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Finance. It follows one asked recently by Senator Kilgariff about superannuation coverage for permanent part time employees in the Northern Territory Public Service. As the South Australian Government has made arrangements for superannuation coverage for permanent part time employees in its Public Service, why cannot similar arrangements be made in respect of employees of the Northern Territory Public Service which is an employer within the meaning of the Superannuation Act 1976?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — I will have a study made of the provisions that have been made by the South Australian Government to see whether I can make any advance on the statement I made earlier with regard to this matter. If I can get further information or if further work can be done through government sources on this matter, I will see that Senator Robertson is informed of it.

—Has the Minister for National Development and Energy seen reports that a senior Japanese oil-man told the Australian Petroleum Exploration Conference in Adelaide yesterday that shale oil could still become an important energy source for export to Japan in the future? Is the Minister aware that he also stated that the great potential of shale oil and the possibility of its development on a large scale after 1990 will make it more attractive in view of the possible energy shortage expected in the 1990s? Does that statement not contradict Mr Keating's statement that it is premature to be looking to the production of alternative fuels at present?

—Mr President, I raise a point of order as to whether the opinions of Mr Keating come within the portfolio of the Minister. I am getting sick of Mr Keating dominating this place and being held up as an authority during Question Time. If he is the greater authority, why does the Minister not resign and let us get the expert in here so that we do not continue to rely on the Minister's safeguards-if Mr Keating is the greater authority to whom he will not give the job?
—Mr President, will my question not be broadcast because of the point of order which has been raised? If that is the case, may I ask my question again?
—When a point of order is taken on a question that question is deleted from the broadcast. Do you wish that, Senator Cavanagh?
—I have lodged my protest. The Minister acknowledges the capability of Mr Keating and is relying solely on him as the authority to justify the Minister's comments.

—Mr President, you should rule that there is no point of order. The question asked of me by Senator Young is fully within my responsibility. Mr Keating is the Opposition, or alternative government, spokesman within that discipline. Therefore it is very appropriate that there should be revealed in the Senate what is the Government's attitude, what has been said by a Japanese, and whether it contrasts with what has been said by the person who has been selected by the Australian Labor Party to be its authoritative spokesman, although indeed the Labor Party here rejects him.

—In respect of the point of order which was raised, I allowed Senator Young to speak and following that I made a request to Senator Cavanagh. But there is no point of order. I ask the Minister to reply to the question.
—With regard to the point of order, does this mean that the question will still be broadcast?
—No. The rulings which apply to recording and broadcasting will apply.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Ushijima, the executive assistant to the president of Japan's Mitsubishi Oil Co. Ltd-I think that is the biggest undertaking in Japan-is reported to have said yesterday that Australian oil shale still could become an important energy source for export to Japan in the future. He was addressing the Australian Petroleum Exploration Association conference. He stated that, whilst the Japanese were very much interested in oil shale, the resource would not play a significant role in the supply of energy before 1990 in terms of quantity. That, of course, is completely understandable. He also stated that the great potential of oil shale and the possibility of its development on a large scale after 1990 will make it more attractive in view of the possible energy shortage expected in the 1990s.

ANSWER.PARA: The Japanese spokesman has said what the Government has always said, and that is that synthetic crudes from coal and shale will play a vital role in the decades ahead. That has been confirmed. Incidentally, I remind the Senate--

TALK.START.PARA: —How far ahead?

—As to the question of how far ahead, he said that it would be in the 1990s. He said that the great potential of oil shale and the possibility of its development on a large scale after 1990 will make it more attractive in view of the possible energy shortage expected in the 1990s. I repeat, because of the perilous nature of the world outside, it is imperative--
—Oh!

—Does the Opposition believe that there is no peril in the world outside? That is for the Australian people to judge. The fact is that it is absolutely necessary for Australia to have the technology, the know-how and the ability to expand its activities rapidly, as I acknowledged to Senator Chipp.

—My question is addressed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and it follows the answer given to Senator Chipp in which the Minister expressed concern regarding world production of food. It is also prompted by a Government news release urging Australians to take part in a campaign aimed at a healthier lifestyle which may be achieved by eating and drinking less than we do now and by taking more exercise. It is now known that there are more than 2.5 million refugees in Somalia. Somalia is one of the five poorest countries of the world and, to make conditions even more terrible, it is stricken with the worst drought in 30 years. Will the Government bring sustained and immediate pressure on all countries for urgent action to save these people from a slow death by starvation? Will the Government immediately order shipments of appropriate foodstuffs to start the rescue mission? Will the Government send a delegation from this Parliament in the very near future to investigate the position and report back to the Parliament so that Australia can offer long range support to prevent the annihilation of these people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is addressed to me because it logically follows from my reply to Senator Chipp; but, of course, it relates heavily to foreign affairs. Senator Melzer's illustration of the terrible plight of Somalia, along with the other kinds of Somalias in the world, underlines the dreadful dilemma involved in making a choice between using agricultural products for food and using them for fuel. I directed a very sober reply to Senator Chipp. We will, nevertheless, progress with ways of seeing whether we can process cellulose effectively so that we can use forest wastes and other materials. What I said was not said in any negative sense at all. Obviously I share with Senator Chipp the recognition that if we can produce renewable energy we ought to do so, from whatever source.

ANSWER.PARA: I am aware of the plight of the Somalians. I am not aware of what action the Government has taken or proposes to take. I invite my colleague Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle, who represents the Minister for Foreign Affairs in this place, to seek the information and, when it is available, let the honourable senator know.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment. Is it true that a collection of pre-Columbian art of Mexico consisting of 190 items, the earliest of which dates back to about 1500 BC, and which was given in June and August last year to the National Gallery of Victoria under the Scheme of Tax Incentives for the Arts, was valued at $3.7m by three independent valuers although the purchase price a year earlier was in the vicinity of $1.2m? If the facts are as stated, would there not be a massive and apparently unjustified tax benefit to the donors? Can this explosion in the value of pre-Columbian art over the year in question be explained by the Minister? Is not valuation supposed to be based on recent market prices? Without necessarily saying that this donation was one, will the Minister take any necessary action to prevent taxation rip-offs so that this very valuable scheme will not be destroyed by people using it to gain windfall tax profits?

—I am advised that the Committee on Scheme of Tax Incentives for the Arts was not told, did not ask for and has no reason to request information concerning the purchase price of the items which constituted the gift to the National Gallery of Victoria. The legislation defines the scheme solely in terms of the value of the property at the time of the making of the gift, the value to be determined by at least two valuers who are approved valuers in relation to a class of property. In this case, of course, the class of property was the pre-Columbian items to which the honourable senators refers. I am further advised that the Committee has no reason to believe that the three world respected valuers, all experts in the field of pre-Columbian art, gave other than honest appraisals.
—A very cosy arrangement. What experts were on the Committee apart from the director of the gallery concerned?

—It would be good if Senator Evans's interjection were recorded. I repeat that the Committee has no reason to believe that the three world respected valuers gave other than honest appraisals. My colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment, advises that he has been fully briefed by his Department on this matter and that he is satisfied that the Committee on Scheme of Tax Incentives for the Arts has fulfilled its functions in regard to this gift to the National Gallery of Victoria in conformity with the provisions of the legislation. If I can obtain any further information on this matter for the honourable senator I will pass it on to him.

—Did the Leader of the Government in the Senate hear the comments of Mr Vince Matthews, the head of the Government Information Unit, on AM this morning? He said: 'We are the same as Press secretaries. If Press secretaries had done the role no one would complain'. When describing his and his organisation's activities in liaising with the Liberal Party, he said: 'We are performing a purely reasonable Press secretary role'. I ask the Minister: If Mr Matthews, the Director of the Unit, considers that he and his colleagues are the same as Press secretaries, does the Minister hold to the view that Mr Laurie Power in his office does not perform a Press secretary's role?
—In fact I heard the tail end of AM this morning and therefore did not hear the whole of Mr Matthews'--
—Why?

—Because I was holding a conference here and I thought it more important to deal with delegations than to listen to AM. I would hope that Senator O'Byrne and the public would agree with that. Having said that, I want to make it perfectly clear that what I have said is absolutely right, and I repeat it to the Senate. I, as a senior Minister, have an establishment on my staff for a Press secretary. I am entitled to appoint one today or tomorrow. I have declined to do so because that is my choice. I have no Press secretary.
—Is Mr Power on your staff?

—Let me tell the honourable senator the precise instruction given to me about Mr Power, that is, that the officer not be absorbed into the normal work of the Minister's office-that is where he is-but, although under the Minister's control, operate a service for all Ministers and for the Government as a whole. That is precisely what Hansard records me as saying. It is precisely the instruction to me for him. It is precisely what I have acted under. After somebody interjected the other day and said that Mr Power hands out most of my Press statements, I had a look. Since I have held this portfolio I have issued some 140 or more Press statements. Eight of them have come from Mr Power, none of them later than 14 months ago and the last one on 14 February of last year. So, indeed, that statement was not true. I will have a look at what Mr Matthews has said. The aim is that the Information Unit should do for groups of Ministers what under the Whitlam Government individual Press officers did for individual Ministers; that the Information Unit should be more economical, be fewer in numbers, and therefore function more efficiently. That is the authority under which I have worked and that is how I have pursued it.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Is the Minister aware of a report in the Northern Territory News and on the Australian Broadcasting Commission this morning that a visiting politician, Mr Mohammad Amin Iskander, said that later this year Indonesia hopes to hand over administration of East Timor from the military to the East Timorese Administration and, further, expects the province to be wide open to foreign visitors? If that heartening statement is correct-it was described as the end of a saga of seven years of misery-can the Minister advise the Senate of the Government's attitude to the statement? Is the Government able to elaborate on the information contained therein?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Minister for Foreign Affairs did see the Press report referred to by Senator Kilgariff. Mr Iskander is a prominent Indonesian politician from the Muslim Development Unity Party who is currently visiting Australia at the invitation of the Australian Government. The Minister for Foreign Affairs noted in particular that he is reported to have said that it was expected that later this year East Timor would be open for everybody to go and see. Whilst questions relating to the administration of and entry into East Timor are domestic responsibilities of the Indonesian Government, the Australian Government would welcome such developments, if decided upon by the Indonesian Government. I have no further information than what I have just stated on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate and Minister for National Development and Energy. I ask: Does the Minister recall the launching of the Australian Labor Party's policy on minerals and energy at the Commonwealth Centre in Sydney in April last year? At the conclusion of the launching, did the Channel 10 crew which attended the launching play the videotape to Mr Laurie Power? In turn, did Mr Power very shortly after report the contents of the tape to the Minister so that he could make a quick response to the ALP policy? How does the Minister reconcile that behaviour with his statement in the Senate last week that he told Mr Power that he was not to engage in party political activity? Did he advise Mr Power at the time that he had exceeded the scope of his duties?

—Sadly enough, I do not recall that the ALP launched its energy policies at the Commonwealth Centre. I am not aware whether Mr Power recorded the launching on videotape. I will seek that information. I am not aware whether he gave me a precis of the policies. I do not recall it. I will check on that. My statement still stands. I said that in the election campaign the co-ordination officer under my responsibility was told that he should not take part in Liberal Party political activities. That is what I told him.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. It follows his answer yesterday to a question concerning Aboriginal medical services. Does the Minister support the principle of directly funding approved priority programs such as Aboriginal medical services? In particular, what is the situation of the service at Broome? When will the Minister be in a position to confirm funding arrangements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —For some years now the Government has been funding Aboriginal medical services around Australia in several ways. We have been funding a number of services which have had bulk billing. A number of services have been funded by grants-in-aid from the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and some services have been funded through health program grants from the Department of Health. That support continues. Our funding is fairly extensive this year-of the order of just under $6m.

ANSWER.PARA: A question was asked yesterday in relation to the service at Broome. I indicated then that I hoped to be in a position to give an early answer. I can now advise the Senate that I had officers visit the Broome service at the end of last week to ascertain the financial position of that service. I am now in a position to approve a grant to the Broome Regional Aboriginal Medical Service initially of $2,500 to meet its immediate financial needs and to enable it to continue its present level of operations. I will be making a further grant to the service to enable it to continue its operations until the end of June. The amount of this further grant is still to be determined after further discussions with the Medical Service.

I am convinced that the Commonwealth should provide some immediate financial assistance to BRAMS and to continue this assistance. I have so advised the Ministers in Western Australia. We are continuing to have consultations with the Western Australian Government officials. We hope to continue to work with them to identify how funding should be continued. At this stage I am unable to say what the level of funding might be after the end of June, but we hope to have that information available for the people in Broome fairly soon.

I have this morning sent a telegram to the Broome Regional Aboriginal Medical Service advising it of this funding. It has had a particular and acute financial problem in the last several weeks. I believe that the action which the Government has been able to take will relieve its immediate problem and assure it of funding for the immediate future.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. Is it a fact that nearly one million persons who were eligible to vote were not enrolled for the 1980 election and that these people were probably migrants and young people? Is the Minister able to say how many members of the population were eligible to vote at the 1980 Federal election? How many of these eligible voters were not enrolled to vote, voted informally or voted formally? Can the Minister indicate what actions have been taken to reduce the number of informal votes? Further, what steps have been taken to ensure that all people who are eligible to vote will be enrolled by the Commonwealth Electoral Office?

—It is clearly desirable in a country such as Australia, with a democratic system such as the one we have, that all those who are eligible to vote be in fact registered and that all those who are registered to vote in fact do so. If that is the purpose of Senator Gietzelt's question I endorse the principle which he puts forward. I know that in relation to my portfolio the Government has made some policy commitments about Aboriginals eligible to vote being enrolled. But the question that the honourable senator asks involves a large number of matters-numbers of people in this category and that category-requiring detailed answers. I will have to refer that to my colleague and get the information for the honourable senator.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology. Have tenders for a new Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation oceanographic research vessel closed yet? If so, what special considerations will be given to have that vessel Australian built?

—Tenders invited from Australia and overseas for the construction of an oceanographic research vessel closed on 20 March this year. The scientific, technical and engineering aspects of all the tenders which were submitted are being assessed at the moment by the CSIRO. Any suitable tender will be examined against the background of the Government's purchasing policy. In addition, under the provisions of the Bounty (Ships) Act 1980 the notional bounty that would apply to an Australian shipyard will also be taken into account when tenders are being evaluated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I add some further information to the question of radioactive materials which I think Senator O'Byrne initiated interest in and which I am continuing to investigate. The New South Wales Minister for Health made an announcement on this matter yesterday. He indicated that the radioactive containers were not breached. He has ordered the monitoring of Laurieton's water supply. I indicated that if that had not been done it ought to be done. Any additional medical checks that are necessary will be carried out. Investigations will also be made regarding the pesticide spillage. The honourable senator will note that I said that there were really two kinds of toxic substances. Mr Gillespie, the Australian Atomic Energy Commission officer on leave who attended the site of the accident, found there bottles marked along the lines of 'Stripper XX'. Stripper XXX is a substance fatal if absorbed through the skin. I understand that Stripper XXX is a degreasing agent containing methylene chloride. I am not aware of its toxic nature, but presumably it is a dangerous chemical.

ANSWER.PARA: The bottles were in a small tool box in a caravan which was being transported on the back of a truck. One bottle was broken and put to the side of the road. The bottles were not related to containers of radioactive materials being transported on the truck. I am advised that Stripper XXX is a moderately to highly toxic chemical, according to the Commonwealth Department of Health's national poisons register. There were two containers with radioactive sources on the truck. One was an 18-inch by 18-inch steel drum in which there were containers of americum. One weld on an outside drum was slightly damaged but there was no damage to inside containers-and I stress that. One lead pot four inches in diameter contained caesium 137. Both containers were ordered by a New South Wales Commission of Health officer to be taken out of the sun as a precaution against the danger of fire if materials had been damaged as they had been packed in paraffin. That was done. I will keep the Senate in touch with the investigations but that is the information I have up till now. It may well be that some of the toxic substances have caused some medical effects on persons who were associated with them.

TALK.START.PARA: —What happened to the food?

—I said yesterday that the food on board was in no way damaged. It continued its journey and the Health Commission of New South Wales was advised. I am not aware of the action that it took on the matter, but I will seek out that information. My understanding is that anything that was soiled or damaged was buried on the spot.

—I have further information on several matters raised by honourable senators. The first matter concerns gold plated Parker pens. The question, which was asked yesterday by Senator Jessop, was in relation to expenditure by Australia Post on gold plated Parker pens. I am advised that in fact the contract related to the purchase of about 1,000 pens valued at about $30 each. That purchase related to Australia Post's service award scheme introduced on 1 January 1980. Essentially, the pens are part of an award scheme for long service. Awards are made after 25 years' service and 40 years' service. At 25 years' service people receive a small medallion and after 40 years' service a gold plated pen. With the introduction of the scheme about 500 persons immediately became eligible to receive a pen. I understand that the remaining 500 pens are expected to be allocated over about the next five years. That at least gives some indication of the number of people qualifying for long service each year.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: CANBERRA CENTRAL HEALTH LABORATORY: USE OF SURPLUS SPACE

TALK.START.PARA: —On 1 April Senator O'Byrne asked me a question concerning the Capital Territory Health Commission building and plans. He asked whether that building might be sub-leased. The Capital Territory Health Commission has been approached by the Canberra Development Board to ascertain the availability of temporary accommodation in its central health laboratories for use by a private organisation. The organisation is considering the establishment of a research and development group in Canberra. Initially, it is seeking temporary facilities to establish the feasibility of its operation. There is some vacant space which may be suitable in the central health laboratory. The Canberra Development Board is conducting confidential negotiations with the organisation regarding the suitability of the vacant areas. Rental charges will be set by the Commonwealth valuation office. This action has been taken as part of a review by the Commission of the use of its buildings and its policy to utilise unused space wherever possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ACACIA RIDGE NORTH NON-OFFICIAL POST OFFICE

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Colston raised by way of question and in the adjournment debate matters regarding the Acacia Ridge North unofficial post office. I am aware that the new post office at Acacia Ridge is to be opened on Friday of this week. I understand the Parliament is to be represented by the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) whom I represent in this place and by the honourable member for Fadden, Mr Don Cameron, and by Senator McAuliffe. In addition to the information I have given previously to Senator Colston I can say that about 75 per cent of business previously conducted at the unofficial post office was business conducted through the Commonwealth bank agency; about 75 per cent of it was banking business. Following representations on this matter made by the member for Fadden it has been possible to make arrangements for the banking business to continue. In fact, arrangements have been possible for most of the functions of the non-official post office to continue. I understand that the mail box outside the post office will still be available for posting, that the bicycle shop next door will be able to sell stamps and that the fruit shop on the other side of the post office will be undertaking the banking functions previously carried out in the non-official post office. Actually, I compliment the local member for having been able to achieve this arrangement.

—During Question Time Senator Button, I think, asked me whether I had mentioned any contract with Rheinbraun in terms of its coal liquefaction. I have looked at the Hansard record and there is no mention by me of a contract.

—I refer to the concern expressed by Senator Young earlier in regard to deletion from the broadcast of a certain question. I have now learnt that the point of order is excised from the broadcast. A question concerning which a personal explanation is made is not broadcast. Concern was expressed about the deletion of the question from the broadcast. The question will not be deleted in this case.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented by Senator Carrick on two occasions, once today and once yesterday. In answer to a question I asked this morning concerning the talking up of the Roxby Downs uranium project in South Australia by the Premier of that State, Senator Carrick said that it was obvious that the aim of the Australian Labor Party was to denigrate development in Australia. As a member of the Labor Party I emphatically deny that I am opposed to development in Australia. Neither is my party. A perusal of the record will reveal conclusive proof of that. However, I am opposed to the deliberate attempt by people in authority to talk up certain mining projects and, by doing so, creating false hopes in the minds of Australian citizens. The other occasion occurred yesterday in Question Time when Senator Carrick answered a question asked by Senator Young. The question, which was about the Murray Valley League, asked:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . for earnest support in bringing about a moratorium on the issuing of any further water licences in New South Wales until a resources management study has been prepared?
I interjected on Senator Carrick and asked:
Doesn't it know that each State has sovereign rights?
Senator Carrick, in reply, said:
I would have thought Senator Young's question would have attracted warm support from Senator McLaren instead of an expression of anger.

There was no expression of anger whatever from me. All I was pointing out to Senator Carrick by way of interjection was something that he has said in this chamber many times in recent weeks, that is, that each State has sovereign rights over its own water resources. There was no expression of anger on my part. Also, I am reported in Hansard as saying:
The suggestion is impracticable, and you know it.
Further in that interjection I am reported as saying:
Anyway you represent New South Wales.
I would like to have the Senate Hansard record corrected because it was my colleague, Senator McClelland, who uttered the words: 'Anyway you represent New South Wales'. I leave the matter at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —A correction will be made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) That the Senate considers that the United Nations Security Council should take immediate action to bring about a peaceful settlement in Lebanon, where bloody conflict has once again flared.
(2) That the Senate considers that such a settlement will require-
(a) strict respect by all members of the UN for the territorial integrity, unity, sovereignty and political independence of Lebanon within its internationally recognised boundaries;
(b) extending the responsibilities of the United Nations Interim Force to apply to the internationally recognised boundaries of Lebanon;
(c) the transfer of responsibilities currently exercised by the Arab League peacekeeping forces to the UNIF and the subsequent withdrawal of the Arab League forces;
(d) disarming of factional and communal militias;
(e) concurrent steps toward settlement of the Palestinian question which will provide Palestinians with a national homeland.

DEBATE.TITLE: LEADER OF THE GOVERNMENT IN THE SENATE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Opposition from moving a motion of censure against the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the suspension of Standing Orders so that the matter can be debated forthwith.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Leader of the Government in the Senate for persistently misleading the Senate as to the nature and activities of the Government Information Unit.
Hansard of 2 April this year records the following exchange which took place in the Senate. In answer to a question from me Senator Carrick said:
In fact what I said yesterday was that if one looks at the Press statements that are handed out by me, one will see that they come from here but that one or two had come from Mr Power.
I then said:
You did not say that. That is a total invention. Come on now! Get out the Hansard and read us that bit.
Senator Carrick said:
I suggest that that is quite unnecessarily offensive.

If the Minister is offended by that statement by me, namely, that what he said was in the Hansard was not there at all, I am afraid that some of the things I have to say today will be more offensive to the Minister. If the truth is offensive to Senator Carrick this motion will be offensive because we are very concerned about the truth in relation to the Government Information Unit. In talking about the truth I remind Senator Carrick and the other members of the Senate again about the standards which were set by this Government, allegedly, in 1975. In 1975 the present Prime Minister, Mr Malcolm Fraser, had this to say about misleading Parliament:

Ten per cent or even 50 per cent of the truth is as good a way of misleading this Parliament and the Australian people as a downright lie. The half truth, the partial answer and the slipping over of the full facts are a misleading of this Parliament . . .

I rely on that statement of Government standards to support the wording of the censure motion, namely, that Senator Carrick has persistently misled the Senate as to the nature and activities of the Government Information Unit. Mr President, we will be referring at a later stage to a number of documents relating to the Government Information Unit. What we are saying in this censure motion is that the Minister in charge of this chamber, a senior Minister in the Government, the Leader of the Government in the Senate and a man who has played a very prominent part in Liberal Party strategy over the years, has the failing of many members of this Government-a capacity to deal very lightly with the truth and an incapacity to be frank as distinct from dealing with half truths, deception and ultimately the misleading of this Parliament.

Maybe the problem is, of course, those very high standards which were so important in 1975. There is not only deception on behalf of this Government but also self-deception because of the failure to meet those standards. In fact, it is fair to say, I think, that Senator Carrick's self-image, insofar as his dealing with the truth is concerned, would make George Washington pale with envy because Senator Carrick denies persistently, day after day at Question Time, the possibility that he might have misled this Parliament in one way or another. I refer again to the standards set by the Prime Minister on 12 March 1978. He said:
One of my Government's first promises when we were elected just over two years ago was to restore the integrity and honesty of government.
Without integrity-without the appearance and reality of integrity-no Government can ever hope to have the confidence of the people, or the trust of the people.

In connection with this Government Information Unit, I interpose that no government, including this Government, can expect to have the confidence and trust of the people because of the way in which Ministers have behaved in relation to dissembling about this Government Information Unit. The Prime Minister went on:
My Government has demonstrated again and again our fundamental commitment to restoring integrity to public administration in Australia. Our record in this regard is without parallel in our history.
People might regard that as a somewhat equivocal statement. The Prime Minister continued:
As long as I lead the Government, there is no way known that anything less than the highest code and practice of public administration will be tolerated.

In relation to this Government Information Unit those standards have not in any way been maintained. There are numbers of reasons, I suspect, for that. We are talking, of course, about the two faces of the Government Information Unit. We are talking about a Jekyll and Hyde creation of the Liberal Party-the nice Jekyll face which Senator Carrick projects in this Senate in answer to questions and the Hyde face which I will tell honourable senators about in a minute and which every journalist in this country who is concerned about political issues knows about.

Why is Senator Carrick singled out from other Ministers in this regard? Senator Carrick is singled out because in this chamber he is, if I can coin a phrase, the 'Lynch-pin' in answering questions about the Government Information Unit, and I want to come to Sir Phillip Lynch at a later stage. But in this place, Senator Carrick is the responsible Minister in relation to these matters. If the truth had been told from the beginning, it would not be necessary to initiate this messy procedure. I want to refer to some of the documents in relation to that in a minute. The fact is, of course, that the Fraser Government was so concerned with its own probity and the standards which it would set, the standards laid down by the Prime Minister in the passages to which I referred, that it was not going to have Press secretaries such as those of the Whitlam Government; it would set up something quite different that would provide a facility for the people of Australia in order that they might better understand government decisions. That facility would disseminate information, it would be quite clean, a neutral organisation-nothing like Press secretaries were in the past or have been at any other time in the political history of this country.

As I have said, the Government Information Unit has two faces, and I want to say something about that. The function of the Government Information Unit is very much one of manipulating the media, getting the taxpayers to fund Liberal-National Country Party propaganda. That is what it is really about.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stop distorting it.

—I suggest that the honourable senator listen for a minute; just give me time. I was referring to a point which Senator Walters can take home to her electors in Tasmania. She can tell them that the Government Information Unit admittedly cost $360,000 this year, and with upgrading it will cost $500,000. That is a piece of information that the honourable senator can take back to the worthy burghers of Hobart. That is taxpayers' money, and I will show that the taxpayers' money is being spent and was spent in the course of the last election on Liberal Party propaganda, and nothing else.

SPEECH.PARA: What is the Government Information Unit supposed to do, as distinct from what Senator Carrick and other Ministers have said it does? I refer first of all to a statement about the Government Information Unit released by the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr John McLeay, on 22 December 1978, in which he said:
These officers who will be on Ministerial Staff, will be stationed in the State Offices of the Minister concerned and will be responsible for assisting all Ministers--
As Senator Carrick said-
in their dealings with matters affecting the State . . .

He said that they will be ministerial staff. In a later document, believe it or not bearing the date 6 April 1981-surprise, surprise-the present Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman) made this statement:
Overall, the Unit's objective is to maintain a steady flow of straightforward, factual information about the policies and decisions of the Government.
The statement goes on to say and this is a quotation which I commend to the Attorney-General (Senator Durack) when he is dealing with the Freedom of Information Bill:
Governments in modern democracies have a responsibility to inform; the people have a right to know. This Government accepts this responsibility.

That statement was made on 6 April this year. I have referred to two Government statements from the Minister for Administrative Services of the time. The first statement says that these people will be on ministerial staff. Senator Carrick has persistently denied that in the Senate. The second statement says that the purpose of the Government Information Unit is to provide a steady flow of straightforward information, and I will come to that.

Over the last few weeks we have heard a variety of versions of the functions of this Unit from Senator Carrick, from the Prime Minister, and from Mr Newman, the Minister for Administrative Services. Let me cite some examples of the variety of versions we have had about this unit which is to provide simple straightforward information about Government policies. In the Senate on 2 April, referring to the GIU officer, Mr Laurie Power, Senator Carrick said:
. . . he is in no way a ministerial Press officer.

The day before Senator Carrick said: 'I do not have a Press officer'. On 25 March, in the House of Representatives, the Prime Minister said that officers of the GIU: 'stand in very large measure in place of a Press secretary'. Who does one believe about that? Who is telling the truth about that situation? One can look to 9 April, which I think is today-I am not sure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Are you sure of anything?
—Yes. If the honourable senator listens, I will tell him about it. On the AM program, Mr Vincent Matthews, the head of the Government Information Unit, was asked this question by Mr David Margen:

SPEECH.PARA: So, the Unit's role is not simply providing the public with the information about the function and activities of Government or to explain to the public a Government policy?
It is in fact a political organisation involved in electioneering as well.
We must bear in mind the statement of the then Minister for Administrative Services-that it is a body designed to provide straightforward information. Mr Matthews said this:

Well, what is politics? Anyone concerned with Government is in politics. We are, as I said, on Ministerial staff. We are the same as Press Secretaries and if Press Secretaries had done the role, performed the role that we performed there would have been no questions asked . . .

So it goes on. There is a version from the head of the Government Information Unit-again different from the version put by Senator Carrick in this place and again different from the version put by other Ministers. What was Mr Newman still maintaining last night? I quote from the transcript of the PM program. He was asked whether the Unit was being used for party political purposes. He said:
No, not for Party political purposes.
Mr Vincent Matthews, the head of the organisation, contradicted him today. On 1 April Senator Carrick told the Senate that he did not have a Press officer. He went on:

Mr Power himself would indicate that he does not in fact work for me; nor do I seek his services in day to day public relations. All my media work is done either by me or by my personal staff here in this Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is true.
—Listen, Senator Teague; just bide your soul in patience. Senator Carrick said:

SPEECH.PARA: All my media work is done either by me or by my personal staff here in this Parliament.

When Senator Carrick replies to this debate will he deny that for a substantial period journalists in this Parliament who wanted to see him had to make appointments through Mr Laurie Power in Sydney? If he does deny that, and if I can paraphrase an expression, flights of journalists will sing him to his political rest, because they know that to be untrue. On 2 April, the day after he had given that answer, and again referring to Mr Power, he told the Senate:
. . . he is in no way a ministerial Press officer;
Let us remember what Mr Matthews said-
he is a Government information officer.

That was on 2 April. Of course, there is now quite clearly some confusion because Senator Carrick says that that they are not on ministerial staff. One can ask this question: If the members of the GIU are not on ministerial staff, why are they given access to the Parliamentary Library on the basis that they are ministerial staff? Let us work that out, because after the GIU was set up its members made numerous demands on the Library for research material.

TALK.START.PARA: —And still do.

—And still do. The rule is that such requests can come only from members of parliament or their research staff. The Government Information Unit has been said by Senator Carrick not to be involved in that sort of activity. The requests came mainly from Elizabeth Bell, number three in the Canberra GIU operation. Those demands for Library services were based on the tenuous claim that the GIU was attached to the staff of the Minister for Industry and Commerce, Sir Phillip Lynch. Surprise, surprise, old Stumpy Gully Lynch is still at it! The claim made to the Library is that they are the personal staff of Mr Lynch. I suspect very strongly that there are many activities in relation to the Government Information Unit which a senior Minister, Sir Phillip Lynch, did not bother to tell the Leader of the Government in the Senate about. That is one of the reasons that the Government is in this dilemma over the problem, with Senator Carrick saying things which are totally different from things said by other Ministers and by members of the Government Information Unit itself. There was a row about the Government Information Unit's using the Parliamentary Library as members of Mr Lynch's staff, and the Library staff asked for a ruling about it. They received no direction on how to treat these requests from the Government Information Unit. When the Parliamentary Librarian was asked, he went on record as saying that the Unit did not fall into the guidelines set down for the staff of members of parliament. As far as can be ascertained, the Library staff have not been informed of this and the GIU continues to use the Parliamentary Library facilities.

SPEECH.PARA: What does the Government Information Unit do? This will be a matter of great interest to Senator Walters, I am sure. What do Mr Power and his colleagues really do? Let us take Mr Power as an example. On 11 February last year-this was the subject of questions in the Senate-he wrote, distributed and invited requests for information about a Press handout bearing that date. That Press handout was read to the Senate last week by Senator Walsh. In April of last year Mr Power, as part of his Government Information Unit functions presumably, attended nearby the Labor Party briefing on its energy policy, obtained a copy of the tape and took that information to the Minister. Those are some of the things that Mr Power has been doing. We will come later to some more things. What did Senator Carrick say about that in the Senate? He denied that Power was a member of his staff and carried out work for him. On 1 April he said in the Senate:
