I did say, and I repeat, that I did not have a Press officer . . . Mr Power himself would indicate that he does not in fact work for me; nor do I seek his services in day to day public relations. All my media work is done by me or by my personal staff here in this Parliament.
Senator Carrick, when pressed about it the following day, said:
. . . what I said yesterday was that if one looks at the Press statements that are handed out by me, one will see that they come from here but that one or two have come from Mr Power.

That was the basis of an exchange in which Senator Carrick accused me of being offensive when I pointed out that he did not say that at all on the previous day. As I said, Senator Carrick on the previous day in fact said nothing of the kind. Secondly, Senator Carrick has denied that Mr Power did anything more than work for the Government of the day as distinct from engaging in party political activity. This is what he said on 1 April:
. . . my instructions to Mr Power were that he was a government employee, that he was to pursue work for the Government of the day and that he was not to be an employee of the Liberal Party as such.
That was a funny way of putting it-'an employee of the Liberal Party as such', because he is employed by the Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can't you differentiate between party politics and--
—It is apparently a distinction which the Minister felt it necessary to make and which clearly eludes Senator Walters. On 2 April Senator Carrick said:

SPEECH.PARA: Of course, if one wanted to locate Mr Laurie Power one would look towards my suite of offices and would find him there. Nevertheless, he is in no way a ministerial press officer;-
Contrary to what the Prime Minister and Mr Vincent Matthews are saying--
he is a Government information officer for the totality of government.

Senator Carrick also said that the Government Information Unit, as distinct from individual officers attached to it, had not been engaged in political activity. Further, he said that they had not been involved in party political activity at the last election. On 31 March I asserted in the course of a speech that during the last election campaign the members of the Unit were engaged in electioneering for the Liberal Party. Senator Carrick, according to Hansard, said:
That is not true.
That was in the Senate on 31 March. That is a deliberate or a totally ill-informed misleading of this Parliament, as I will show. On 2 April Senator Carrick said:
My clear instruction on political matters to the Government information officer is that his job is to pursue Government information and not party political matters.

This is an extraordinary set of allegations and, of course, Mr Newman shares the view of Senator Carrick and was expressing it last night on the PM program when he said that the Unit was not for party political purposes. The essential questions are these: What is the truth about Mr Power's activities? Is he what the Minister pretends he is or is he something else?

I want to refer to some documents that have come into our possession from the Liberal Party Federal secretariat. I also rely on other matters of public knowledge-published reports and the evidence of journalists and others. How did we get the documents? How did the documents from the Liberal Party secretariat come into our possession? I will tell honourable senators how and I will tell them why. There are many Liberals in this country who are deeply concerned about the deception and the prevarication that have gone on about the activities of this Government Information Unit. Every honourable senator on this side of the House knows that because they talk about it. They are deeply concerned about the prevarication and the deception that have gone on. That is why we have the documents and that is why they were made available to us-because they are very concerned that the standards which were set by Malcolm Fraser in 1975 and in 1978 have in no way been kept by the way in which this Government Information Unit has been operated. That is how the documents came to us.

Let me mention some of the activities revealed in those documents which can be related to Mr Power, first of all, and which can fairly be described as party political activities. First of all, a minute dated 30 September last year, and marked with the time 8 a.m., states:
Eddie to ask SCOs to report daily on placement of press ads.

Eddie Dean is his name. He is a member of the Government Information Unit. What Press advertisements? In the context of the last election, what Press advertisements? Government Press advertisements or Liberal Party Press advertisements? Perhaps Senator Walters may have an answer to that question. The Government Information Unit officers were to report daily on the placement of Press advertisements. Government Press advertisements?

Is it a straightforward organisation disseminating Government information to the people of Australia or something acting for the Liberal Party? What Press advertisements was it to report on? The answer, of course, is that it was to report on the placement of Liberal Party Press advertisements during the last election. There is no mention of any exception to that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not monitor all the advertisements?

—Senator Teague may suggest all sorts of things, but we should look at what happened. That is what I am asking honourable senators to do. Power obviously received that instruction, as did all the Government Information Unit officers in the States. They were to report daily on the placement of Liberal Party Press advertisements.
—That is a good interpretation.
—Senator Walters, you Tasmanian genious, give me another interpretation of what that means and we will hear it from you, as they say.
—Flattery will get you nowhere.

—Yes, I appreciate that. There is no mention of any exception to that. The second point which arises from the documents is this: There was to be daily political impact monitoring. This was to be a standard procedure followed by State co-ordination officers, including Laurie Power of the Government Information Unit. There was to be daily political impact monitoring as part of the task of disseminating straightforward information on Government policies to the people of Australia. Is that part of the function of the Government Information Unit? Senator Guilfoyle laughs because she knows where those documents came from. She knows what it is all about. Political impact monitoring on a daily basis is a party political activity in which these members of the Government Information Unit were engaged. Other functions are listed in the documents. There are various headings under that daily task. One is 'Problem Areas and Criticism'. Criticism of whom? Another heading is 'Positive Issues'. Issues for whom? The fourth heading is 'Pressure Group Activities'. Pressure group activities against whom and for whom? The next heading is 'Party Morale'. The Government Information Unit is to be concerned about party morale. The last heading states 'Other Matters (Including Local Labor Tactics)'. The information which the State co-ordination officers of the Government Information Unit-a body designed to provide straightforward political information on Government decisions-including Mr Power, monitored and collected daily was to go to the Prime Minister, a Government official. The information was also to go daily to Mr Tony Eggleton, the Federal Director of the Liberal Party. Their function was described in the documents as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: Serve as a channel for fast communication between the Prime Minister, the Federal Director--
That is, Mr Eggleton-
and members of the Organisation and the Parliamentary Party;

Members of the organisation! What organisation? I ask Senator Walters what she imagines could be the organisation. On 26 and 27 June, according to one of the documents, the State co-ordinating officers, including Laurie Power, appear again, apparently without the good Minister's knowledge. They were responsible for assessing on that day the political climate. From the documents it appears that on 25 September Power needed some help about those matters. On that date the agenda for a Liberal Party strategy meeting listed a task for Mr Dale Budd, who incidentally is Mr Anthony's brother-in-law and one of the Prime Minister's functionaries. This task was set for Mr Dale Budd by the Liberal Party:
Follow up request made by Vincent Matthews as to whether the Party can assist Laurie Power.

Laurie Power needed the Party assistance on that day. Of course, in all these documents the political climate is a continual obsession with the weather men at Robert Menzies House not far from here. Before the election campaign began there was written a minute which shows the way in which the GIU, the Government Information Unit, the cleanskin to replace or raise the standards of government and so on--

TALK.START.PARA: —That's right. You nearly said it, didn't you?
—I do not retreat from that statement at all. It was to replace, as the argument went--
—The dirty tricks department.

—No, I do not retreat from that at all. Freud defined 'neurosis' as an abnormal obsession with the past. By that definition, Senator Lewis is the most neurotic member of the Senate. The task agreed on as to how the GIU could best do its task was set out in this memorandum:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . consult with State Director--
That is, of the Liberal Party-
and State Co-ordination Officer to obtain input for an initial 'political climate' report for the PM and federal campaign director
That was the initial task given to the GIU. Other tasks included:

On the eve of the PM's visit the State Director should liaise with the State Co-ordination Officer about the filing of a 'political climate' update (this should reach the PM and Federal Director no later than 24 hours prior to the start of the visit)

That is the Federal Director again. Let us look at some of the other activities of Mr Power not documented in the set of papers. I referred before to the provision of Press statements. We had an argument about that and the activities with the Labor Party energy policy launch.

TALK.START.PARA: —Would you answer just one question for me? Just tell me whose information you rely on.
—The Liberal Party's.
—Are you willing to name this person?
—No. Perhaps it is an appropriate time for me to seek leave to have these documents incorporated in Hansard.
—Mr President, it is customary for the person seeking leave to identify the documents, their nature and their authorship. I now invite Senator Button so to do before we consider the matter.
—They are documents of the Liberal Party. The author has signed each page.
—Is there any proof, Mr President?
—You saw them all before. You saw them in October.
—I have never seen them. I do not object to the incorporation of the documents. I merely say there has been no proof as to their authenticity.

1. During the campaign proper Ministers will be asked by the Prime Minister to undertake one of the following roles-
(a) Travelling Ministers: Ministers who take part in a co-ordinated programme of visits around the country.
(b) State Spokesmen: Ministers who will act as Senior Government Spokesmen in their State throughout the campaign.
(c) State Specialists: Ministers who will undertake general campaign activities within their States.
2. The aim with each Travelling Minister is to design an itinerary which maximises publicity for the Government both nationally and in each State he visits.
3. This should be done keeping in mind:
(a) the need to use Ministers to the best possible advantage during the campaign;
(b) the wishes of both the Ministers themselves and the State Divisions;
4. In consultation with Ministers' offices and the Divisions, the National Co-ordinator will draw up a programme for each Travelling Minister 'allocating' him to particular States on particular days.
5. In preparing the programme, the following guidelines will be kept in mind:
(a) Travelling Ministers should not be in a State at the same time as the Prime Minister. (Activities by other Ministers are less likely to receive coverage if the Prime Minister is also in town.)
(b) Otherwise, at least one Travelling Minister should be in each State on each day of the campaign.
(c) Desirably, each Travelling Minister should visit each State.
(d) Visits should be of two days duration to maximise impact.
(e) Adequate time must be allowed for each Minister to spend in his own electorate.

6. Once the overall programme is finalised, the detailed planning of itineraries in each State will be the responsibility of the State Director. State Directors may wish to delegate the task to a Senior Officeholder or staff member, but they should retain overall responsibility.

8. The co-ordinated programme for Travelling Ministers will commence on the day following the Campaign Launch and will conclude on the Wednesday prior to polling day, allowing them to spend the last days of the campaign in their electorates.
9. The primary role of State Spokesmen is to generate favourable media coverage for the Government in their State. To do this they should be available to the media at all times.
10. State Divisions may wish to ask State Spokesmen to undertake a campaign program within their home States, but this should not impinge upon their primary campaign responsibilities.

11. In normal circumstances State Spokesmen would not accept engagements outside their home States. Where they do so, arrangements should be made with another Minister to assume their responsibilities.
12. It is suggested that State Spokesmen be co-opted to State Strategy/Campaign Committees.
13. State Specialists would be available to undertake general campaign activities within their State.
(c) Working closely with the Party Organisation at electorate level.
15. In some cases, there may be scope for these Ministers to undertake engagements outside their home States.
16. Ministers are a scarce 'campaign resource' and all activities they undertake during the campaign should be designed to get the most possible mileage.
17. The principle aim of all Ministerial engagements should be to obtain favourable media coverage.

18. Other engagements should only be undertaken if there is a definite objective in mind-for example meeting key businessmen, civic leaders and other opinion formers, speaking at a 'closed' fund-raising function, et cetera. (Normally, fund-raising activities in electorates would be expected to generate coverage, at least in the local Press.)
19. Because of the special importance of Travelling Ministers to the overall campaign, the following guidelines are suggested for planning their itineraries:
(a) On arrival in a State, their first port of call should be the office of the Minister to whom the State Co-ordinator Officer is attached, for a briefing on the local campaign climate.
(b) State Directors should also contact them to brief them on any special campaign matters, and to finalise last minute details of their itineraries.
(e) Wherever possible, opportunities should be taken to get Travelling Ministers on radio talk-back shows.

(f) There is often scope for Ministers to take advantage of forums such as major Chambers of Commerce, Conventions et cetera during the campaign. State Divisions should be alert to opportunities to 'orchestrate' suitable invitations.
20. Where Travelling Minsters visit local electorates, close liaison is needed with candidates and campaign managers.

(a) Past experience has shown that it is not satisfactory to leave arrangements solely to those in the electorate. Against this background it is essential that detailed itineraries be provided well in advance (preferably before the campaign commences) and be cleared by both the State Division and the Travelling Minister concerned.
meetings with key special interest groups, civic leaders et cetera;
visits to local institutions, clubs and factories;
in country electorates, local TV and radio interviews, talk-back shows et cetera.
large meetings of Service Clubs, Chambers of Commerce et cetera.
(c) All electorate activities should involve the local candidate and, where possible, Senate candidates as well.
(d) Coverage in the local Press, and if appropriate the major dailies and television, should actively be sought.

(e) Use the time of Travelling Ministers frugally. Generally speaking, activities such as attending small gatherings of 'Party faithful' or Branch meetings, purely social functions and doorknocking (!!) do not require the time of a Travelling Minister . . . and can be left to others to handle.
21. Similar guidelines to those contained in Paragraph 20 should also apply to the kinds of activities undertaken by State Spokesmen and State Specialists.
Attached is brief for you on Hinch show and brief on ethnic media was already sent to you to Martin Place office on Tuesday afternoon.
I believe Hinch should be taken head-on otherwise he will win what he is billing as 'the battle of the year'.

The difficulty is that Hinch has the assistance of Jill Nankerville and Barber (both sit in an outside studio and have direct access to Hinch via earphones). Paul Barber tends to feed questions and follow up points to Hinch. I would suggest that someone remains outside and talks and disturbs both Nankerville and Barber. I found this worked well with both Newman and Howard interviews.

TALK.START.PARA: —I referred earlier to the activities of the Government Information Unit. For example, when the Prime Minister went to Delhi last year for the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting the reports on the Australian media were supplied to the Prime Minister by Laurie Power. Traditionally the Department of Foreign Affairs has monitored the Australian media. On this occasion Laurie Power of the Government Information Unit, to whom I have referred on a number of occasions, sent a resume to the travelling Prime Minister. That was done so that the Prime Minister could get advise on what he should be doing and saying in a political context rather than rely on a department of government as has traditionally been done-namely, the Department of Foreign Affairs-for objective monitoring of the media.

SPEECH.PARA: One of Laurie Power's tasks as the Sydney operative of the GIU was to carry out media liaison work as indicated in the documents I referred to earlier. When the Prime Minister arrived at Mascot airport Power was always there of course waiting at flight facilities for the Prime Minister's plane. He was to look after the needs of the media and when required was to organise a Press conference. He rang radio stations frequently during the election campaign to pass on material on behalf of the Liberal Party. He always introduced himself to radio station announcers as Laurie Power from the Liberal Party. This is the man whom we were told in the Senate is fulfilling a non-political, non-partisan role.

TALK.START.PARA: —What evidence do you have of that?
—I cannot drag radio announcers into this place but that happened.
—Let him deny it.

—Let Laurie Power deny it. See how he gets on with some of his journalist colleagues when he denies that one. Mr Power might have been fair in saying that he was Laurie Power of the Liberal Party when he was ringing up because he is an endorsed Liberal candidate for the next State election in New South Wales. So that is the sort of defence that should be adopted. He was probably pretending he was a Liberal--
—Do you find that offensive?
—No, not at all.
—Because you had better ask Senator Sibraa and Bill Morrison to leave, hadn't you?

—I would not get fussed about that but that is another alibi that perhaps could be used in the course of debate. Perhaps Laurie Power, when he was ringing up in the context of the Federal election and describing himself as being from the Liberal Party instead of from the Government Information Unit, was in fact--
—A touch of honesty.
—A touch of honesty about his being an endorsed Liberal candidate.
—You lost that argument.

—The whole sordid story, Senator Lewis, is one of power without glory. That is the trouble with this Government. That is the trouble with the Government Information Unit. Senator Carrick might want to step aside from all these answers he has given about Laurie Power. That will be very hard to do because of the indelible nature of the printed word. He might want to talk in generalities about the Unit's role during the last election campaign. So let me refer to some of its activities as an organisation. Perhaps Mr Newman should also note these facts.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer again to the set of documents from the Liberal Party. The first meeting of the Liberal Party campaign committee was in June. The agenda is headed 'Federal Campaign Headquarters, Structure and Operations'. Under agenda item (5) which is 'Operations' the following appears: 'Liaison with Government Information Unit'. Under the same agenda item at the same meeting the following appears: 'Liaison with GIU and PM's Office'.

Earlier in the year-on 25 August to be precise-there was another meeting about monitoring. Under the heading 'Operations', agenda item (4), there appears: 'GIU/SCO's'. That refers to State co-ordination officers of the Liberal Party. Under agenda item (7) for the same meeting there appears: 'GIU'. The agenda then sets out matters for resolution involving that Unit, including 'Method of Operations/Location (s)/Staff'. This is all in Tony Eggleton's bailiwick over in Robert Menzies House. The poor old fellow would turn in his grave if he knew that this sort of stuff was going on in the Liberal Party of Australia. Under agenda item (7) also is the heading 'Liaison with PM's Press Office/National Campaign Headquarters'.

On the same agenda for the Liberal Party campaign committee is a list of monitoring priorities-the most wanted men, it is said. Those priorities are named as follows: 'Hayden, Hawke, Wran, Shadow Ministers, Advertising (theirs and ours), All Local Media/Talk Back Radio/Press Conferences/Interviews etc.'. That appears in the minutes of the Liberal Party's campaign meeting under the heading 'Government Information Unit'. I repeat that reference is made to 'Advertising (theirs and ours)' as well as 'Hawke, Hayden, Wran' and so on. The Liberal Party even used-in fact it assumed the use of-equipment belonging to the Government Information Unit. That comes under the heading 'Facilities and Equipment' in the Liberal Party campaign minutes.

Other facilities and equipment would have come from the national campaign headquarters of the Liberal Party, the Prime Minister's Press Office and State divisions or branches. That is fair enough. That is a proper divorcement of the activities of a political party from the proper activities of government. Sure, they are the facilities that any political party should use-State divisions and branches of the Liberal Party, the national campaign headquarters-but not equipment paid for with taxpayers' money, namely the equipment of the Government Information Unit. As I said, the campaign minutes of the Liberal Party refer to 'Facilities and Equipment'.

On 25 August there was a meeting of the Federal Secretariat of the Liberal Party. It was on a Monday. The meeting began at 10 a.m. Who was there? Tony Eggleton, the National Director of the Liberal Party; Martin Rawlinson, the resident analyst, I am told he is called but I do not know whether he is a psychoanalyst or a political analyst; Bob Baudino, otherwise known as the Chuck or Charles Colson of Australian politics; Grahame Morris, Baudino's underling; Eddie Dean-not John Dean-a Melbourne film producer who was hired as a jack of all trades for the purposes of the campaign; Dale Budd to whom we have referred before; also David Barnett, the Prime Minister's Press Secretary, and his assistant Alister Drysdale. There was Jonathan Gaul, the Canberra lobbyist and public relations man who had been hired to run the media unit during the election campaign. Of course there were two other gentlemen employed out of taxpayers' money, two other gentlemen who were to provide facilities and equipment to the Liberal Party during the election-Vincent Matthews, head of the Unit, and his chief assistant Mr Jim Hall; both from the Government Information Unit.

On 26 and 27 June there was another campaign seminar. There was a discussion on ministerial co-ordination. Under the heading 'Kinds of Engagements', this instruction to Ministers appears in agenda item 19:
(a) On arrival in a State, their first port of call should be the office of the Minister to whom the State Co-ordinator Officer is attached, for a briefing on the local campaign climate.
There was a further strategy meeting on 5 October. The first item on the agenda was this: 'Speak to Vince Matthews about the GIU relaying all Press releases and AAP reports to the travelling team'.

On 30 September more follow-up action was required, with Eddie Dean being asked 'to request the State co-ordinator to report each day on placement of Press ads'. The Queensland officer was asked to monitor closely the repercussions of Mr Eric Robinson's statement on the National Party. Is that straightforward provision of decisions about Government policy? I do not think so. On 9 October a copy of the front page of the Adelaide News, one of the more notorious front pages to appear in the election campaign, was sent to Baudino of the Federal Secretariat of the Liberal Party. It was marked: 'To Bob Baudino from Maurice Dunlevy'. He is the officer of the GIU in Adelaide. On 9 October one Barbara, whoever she is, sent a note to Baudino which read:
Vincent Matthews has just phoned through the following message: 'Sydney Stock Exchange prices rose sharply this morning in all sections'.

Is that straightforward provision to the public of important information concerning Government policy? On 29 September Mr Verbickis sent a telegram to Jonathan Gaul, a man hired by the Liberal Party and the man in charge of the campaign media unit. The telegram from Arnis Verbickis, the Victorian officer, stated:
Have arranged news conference for Mr Howard tomorrow at 11.30 a.m. at 4 Treasury Place, Melbourne.

At the strategy committee meeting on 26 September more follow-up action was required of Dale Budd, who had to 'investigate operational problems with the PM's Press office and the Government Information Unit'. There were further instructions of a similar kind, including an instruction to obtain information required by the Prime Minister prior to his talk-back programs. There is, of course, the notorious example of Mr Verbickis in Victoria advising officers travelling with Ministers how to carry out dirty tricks to distract the producers of the Derryn Hinch Show. Similar comments can be made about the activities of Mr Vincent Matthews in launching the Prime Minister's campaign and so on.

I commend to honourable senators as bedside reading those documents which have been incorporated in Hansard. They really are extraordinary documents. They illustrate the deception which has gone on right from the beginning about the nature of the Government Information Unit-a deception which has trapped Senator Carrick in its web. Statements here again and again represent attempts to divert, to mislead, and to tell only part of the truth about the role of the Government Information Unit. It has all happened, of course, because of the statement by the Prime Minister right at the beginning about the integrity and probity of the Liberal Government and the high standards that would be set. The high standards have not been kept. I assert categorically that what has happened is that taxpayers' money has been used to finance the so-called Government Information Unit. Taxpayers' money has been used for that purpose. That money has been siphoned off to the Liberal Party-the party in Australian politics which always resists the sourcing of campaign donations at election times, which always resists the placing of limits on expenditure at election times and which during the course of the last election campaign spent $3m and, in addition, stole taxpayers' money in order to employ people in the pursuit of Liberal Party activities in the election.

The facts are documented. They are clear. Facilities and equipment were used. Personnel were used. Personnel employed by the taxpayers had to report to Mr Tony Eggleton every day. People employed by the Government had to report to him. What has he to do with the process of government? Can honourable senators on the other side of the House not distinguish between the process of honest government and the activities of the Liberal Party? Are those two things so merged together in their minds that they see no distinction at all in terms of the propriety about which the Prime Minister spoke? That is what has happened.

Senator Carrick has been cast in the unhappy role in the Senate of dissembling and misleading in relation to the whole thing. He did not want any of that stuff to come out. He wanted us to believe what he said, namely, that the Government Information Unit was not party political and that the persons referred to, quite contrary to what they themselves say, were not on Ministers' staffs, and were not involved in the last election campaign. When I made that allegation last week, Senator Carrick said: 'That is not true'. He accused me of telling lies. It is true. Senator Carrick deserves the censure of the Senate because, as I said earlier, he has been the linchpin of the Government's dissembling, dishonesty and prevarication about the true function of this unit.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CARRICK
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, what a curious form of perverted morality it is that a Labor Opposition leader rises in this place, allegedly to censure someone for unethical behaviour, and uses as the base of his argument something he has found at a garbage tip. Let us have a look at this question of morality. Here is a person who bases the whole of his claim on the fact that he has a document, the origin of which he is not willing to disclose. Let me simply say that in a comparative test of morality we on this side of the chamber walk with our heads high. I do not accept such a document. I do not believe that any member of the Liberal Party of Australia would give the Australian Labor Party such a document. Every member of the Liberal Party knows the disaster that the Labor Party is. It is a curious document. There is no letterhead on any of its pages. Let the Labor Party tell the Senate the source of the document. We will then be able to decide whether it is acceptable.
—You are the experts at falsifying documents. Then you will get them knocked off.
—Decent members of the Ministry must be ashamed of you.

—Mr President, I heard Senator Button in silence. I can understand why the Labor Party would not want me to be heard in silence. The censure motion is not aimed at the Government; it is aimed at me. It suggests that I have misled the Senate. I categorically deny so doing. Let me take the facts. I was asked whether Mr Laurie Power was my Press officer. I said: 'No, he is not'.
—You seconded him to the unit.
—Order! This matter is very serious. I ask honourable senators to listen without interjecting.

—Mr President, every time there is an interjection I am prepared to pause for the interjection to be voiced. I will do that. I said that as a senior Cabinet Minister I have provision on my staff to employ a Press officer. I have never filled that vacancy. That is a fact. It is absolutely capable of proof. I ask the Senate to accept it as such. In any case, honourable senators can simply go to the Department of Administrative Services to ask the question. I said that there is a--
—We will certainly be doing it during Estimates time.
—Order! The Minister is replying. I ask honourable senators to cease interjecting.

—Mr President, I do not mind if they want to help me. Their interjections only show again the spurious nature of the allegations. I said that there is a Government Information Unit, that a Government information officer is stationed in every State and that the officer is under the control of the senior Minister in that State but is not his Press officer. I repeat that the Government information officer in each State is under the control of the senior Minister in that State but is not the personal Press officer of that Minister. That is a simple fact capable of easy proof. I said that the New South Wales officer is quartered in my suite of offices in Sydney for the sake of convenience. That is a fact. Quite clearly, ordinary administrative conditions apply to him there. I said that his role is not to be my Press officer but to service all Ministers and the Government generally. They are facts. The whole thrust of this issue is that the answers I have given to questions in the Senate are inaccurate. I have stated the simple facts. They are easily capable of being ascertained.

SPEECH.PARA: The instruction regarding the information officer is that the officer be not absorbed into the normal work of the Minister's office-that is, my office-but, although under the Minister's control, operate a service for all Ministers and for the Government as a whole. Part of the duties of the officers shall be to maintain close liaison with the Government Information Unit in Canberra. They are the facts, and Hansard has recorded, one by one, what I have said. I have pointed out that the Unit provides various services for Ministers collectively. Whereas in the past the Whitlam Government had one Press officer for every Minister and, in addition, a large propaganda unit, we have reduced the number of officers for Ministers down to three, I think, for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and about four for other Ministers, excluding myself. Some 20 Ministers do not have Press officers, and in their place is a much more economical set-up-a Government Information Unit functioning for all Ministers. Of course, if I were of a mind, as one of the eight or nine Ministers from New South Wales, to ask Mr Power to help, he would be available, as he would to the 27 Ministers who move from time to time through my State. He is a servant of all Ministers and of the Government. I have said that and made it quite clear.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Liberal Party. He is also a servant of the Liberal Party.

—I thank Senator Cavanagh for his help. No one would know this more than the Labor Party because the Labor Party Press officers were total servants of the Labor Party, and of course that is not denied.
—I hope you are going to give us some proof of that.
—We would not have to go to the garbage heap to do those kinds of things.
—Be a bit fair dinkum; I mean it.

—I hope so. Senator McClelland ought to know that in the last few weeks a couple of members of the Labor Opposition in fact misled this House. I took the opportunity privately to show them the evidence of that, without stunting in this House. So I know how to be fair dinkum, and if the honourable senator will come into my office I will show him how fair dinkum an honest Australian is when he finds out that somebody is misleading the Senate and does not try to stunt in this place. Let us talk about being fair dinkum. The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, said that journalists were instructed to make all appointments with me through Mr Power. That is not so. The fact of the matter is that I have no doubt that journalists contacted Mr Power from time to time when seeking arrangements with me. That would be a very proper thing to do, but the bulk of contacts by journalists would have come through my personal staff, and they still do.
—Why didn't you do it through your private secretary?

—Because the Government Information Unit would, perfectly properly, be a channel for journalists to contact any of the 27 Ministers. That is not an extraordinary situation. When we take the situation apart, what I have said is absolutely accurate. I have said that I do not have a Press officer, even though I am entitled to one. That statement is factual. I have said that Mr Power functions for all the Ministers, not just for myself alone, or even significantly, and that is demonstrably true. I have said that he is under my control but, of course, he is a direct liaison with the Government Information Unit. That statement is true. It so happens that I personally have used his services rarely. From time to time I have used them, but statements were made in this place that my Press statements all go through Mr Power. I had my officers take out a list and, as far as they could ascertain, there have been something like 141 Press releases since I have been Minister for National Development and Energy; there may be an error in calculation of one or two. From the first one on 11 December through to recent times, of those 141 Press releases I can locate eight that Mr Power handled.
—Eight political ones.

—Let me invite this kind of situation because I do enjoy the interjections. It is said that the eight were political ones. It so happens that six or seven of the eight were Press releases that impeccably were not connected in any way with politics. For example, I put out a statement on the restoration of Rum Jungle. I take it that that is not regarded as party political. I put out a statement on the number of drilling rigs in Australia. I take it that that is not regarded as political.
—In your parlance.
—No. I will circulate these.
—This is all part of your propaganda.

—I point out the kind of nonsense that is now being demonstrated. It is the duty of governments in this country to tell the people of Australia about the number of drilling rigs, whether we are losing or gaining them, whether we are recovering Rum Jungle. Another of the eight Press releases was a completely factual statement on the new prices to apply for all petroleum products in Australia following the price rise by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
—Are you trying to say that there were eight occasions when you used Mr Power as Press secretary?

—No, I am not. What I said was that the Labor Party had said that all my Press statements came through Mr Power and I had said that there were a few. It will be remembered that Senator Button raised this matter.
—You are saying there were eight occasions.
—There were eight occasions?
—Are you saying that on eight occasions he was used honestly for your work?
—I said that I have located eight occasions when he was used.
—On the other occasions he worked for the party.

—I am terribly grateful for the interjections. The next Press release was a completely factual statement of the $1,200m Esso-BHP development in Bass Strait. Another was a factual statement that I would visit Bass Strait. One Press release was quoted the other day, and when I turned it up I found that, in fact, what had happened was that it had been issued late at night. It would not be my normal practice to issue that kind of statement through that Unit. I will be happy to give copies of the eight Press statements to the persons concerned. Let me make it clear that if Mr Power were to be contacted by radio stations and asked whether I would go on radio, the answer would be yes. If he were to be contacted by television stations and asked whether I would go on television, the answer would be yes. He functioned as a Government information officer for all Ministers.
—Who prepared your other statements?

—What wonderful interjections from a party which was saturated with Press officers! Incidentally, these same Government information officers were in exactly the same status as were the Press officers of the Labor Party. They are not permanent public servants.
—But you said that they were not Press officers.
—I am thankful that in his own discipline I have never had to visit this man. I said that they were in the same status.
—You said on previous days that they were not Press secretaries.

—I said that they are not Press secretaries in the sense that they are not my Press secretaries. I will again state the situation; they are temporary public servants, not permanent public servants. They have the same status as temporary public servants, as did the Press officers of the Whitlam Government which had so many more. The whole of the ministerial staff of the Fraser Government totals some 48 fewer than the staff of the Whitlam Government. The simple fact is that we have a unit functioning for the purpose described. A number of extraordinary statements have been made. There has been some suggestion of something difficult or malign in the fact that Mr Power is an endorsed Liberal Party candidate. I see nothing wrong at all with the taxpayers paying for the salaries of Senator Sibraa and Mr Morrison when they were candidates for the Labor Party. I hope that we do not need to get to that situation. I have no doubt at all that using the salary of the--
—You had better make sure that is dead set right. You don't know what the resignation dates were.
—I am not talking about during campaigns.
—I am talking about endorsed candidates.
—I am talking about endorsed candidates.
—At least I did not try to hide the fact that Mr Morrison was working out of my office.

—I am not trying to be critical of the honourable senator or to be offensive. Senator Sibraa and Mr Morrison were endorsed by the Labor Party and while endorsed, it is my understanding, they were also employed as temporary public servants. Therefore, they were working for party political purposes on taxpayers' money. I do not think that is offensive. I certainly was not referring to any time--
—They were not disguised as public servants.
—The fact that Government Information Unit officers are temporary public servants has never been disguised. The reason I said this was that the Government was accused of stealing taxpayers' money.
—Have you come to the point of your denial about their being used in the election campaign?

—The fact is that the Government Information Unit has set out its purpose in the statement that I think was provided to Senator Button on his request. I will read to the Senate from this statement. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government Information Unit was set up in Canberra following a decision by Cabinet--

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise a point of order. I apologise for interrupting the Minister, but he did invite interjections. I would rather take a point of order than interject. As I understand the allegation made against the Minister by Senator Button, it is that the Minister misled the Parliament and is therefore under censure. With great respect, the functions of the Government Information Unit are barely relevant to that charge. The Australian Democrats are still contemplating which way we will vote on this issue and we are listening to the debate. Can I plead with the Minister to reply to Senator Button's charge that he, Senator Carrick, categorically stated to this chamber that officers of the Government Information Unit at no time engaged in party political activity in the last election campaign? Did the Minister state that? If he did, is that misleading the Parliament? If he did mislead the Parliament, did he do so wittingly or unwittingly? To me that is the crux of the issue.
—There is no point of order.

—I understand that that point has to be met. Incidentally, the only related question concerned Mr Laurie Power. What I said was that my instructions to Mr Laurie Power were that he was a government employee but he was to pursue work for the Government of the day; that he was not to be an employee of the Liberal Party, as such. As far as I know, those were the duties he performed. I stand by that. My understanding--
—You didn't know he was acting informally for the Liberals in the campaign?

—It was my understanding that during the campaign the instruction given to Mr Laurie Power was that he was not to take part in Liberal Party activities as such, but that he had one job as all co-ordination officers had. This was not a job which I gave him but one which was given him by the Government Information Unit. That job concerned monitoring. I do not know the details of monitoring. I never saw the document arising from such instructions. I cannot tell.
—But you didn't know the answer on behalf of Power.

—I said that I gave this information to my co-ordination officer. That is how the Hansard stands. If indeed the honourable senator wants to pursue it further and ask if I have any knowledge of anything wider, I have to say to the honourable senator that it was my belief that the same instructions would have been transmitted through other responsible Ministers to their government information officers.
—You said 'that is not true', in answer to the use of government information officers in electioneering.
—I said 'That is not true', because I had instructed Mr Power to do particular things.
—No, you did not say that; you said 'That is not true'.

—Let me make it perfectly clear that my interjection 'That is not true' was meant in good faith. Senator Chipp is entitled to ask me such questions. However I bow to nobody in this place as to responsibility for the accuracy of what I say as contained in Hansard. What I have said and what was reported in Hansard is that I do not have a Press officer; that is demonstrable. I could have one but I do not; that is demonstrable. There is a Government Information Unit and it is collectively used by all Ministers; that is demonstrable. It is under my responsibility; that is demonstrable. Officers report to the Government Information Unit. I also said that I had used Mr Power only a few times for Press purposes. I have said all those things. Concerning the question on my knowledge of the role of the Government Information Unit and of unit officers in the campaign, the information that I had was that my responsibility was to say to my information officer: 'This is your responsibility. Do it'. I was on a circuit throughout Australia and had no other information. I hope that those points clear the matter up. The point that Senator Chipp makes, in fact, is very relevant to what I was going to say. The test is: What is the concept of the Government Information Unit? How was it instructed to me? The instructions have read out very clear. They are the instructions that I followed. In fact, the Unit was for the use of all Ministers and not for one. The nature of the Government Information Unit becomes of tremendous importance. I will read from the paper that has been supplied. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Government Information Unit was set up in Canberra following a decision by Cabinet in May 1978 to encourage. 'more effective communication to the public of government decisions and actions', and to provide 'advice and assistance in that context to all Ministers'.
The role of the Government Information Unit is:
to provide advice and assistance to Ministers on a day to day basis as required on the most effective way of communicating government decisions and actions to the public;
to plan and arrange media coverage, both print and electronic, on matters of substance and advise on services provided by the Government;
to co-ordinate Ministerial publicity where necessary and ensure there is neither conflict nor overlapping of effort.
Only four Government Ministers apart from the Prime Minister have press Secretaries.
Here is a clear statement of fact:
Overall, the Unit's objective is to maintain a steady flow of straightforward, factual information about the policies and decisions of the government.
Governments in modern democracies have a responsibility to inform; the people have a right to know. This Government accepts this responsibility.
The Government Information Unit is a genuine effort on the part of the Government to keep the Australian people informed of what the Government is doing.
The Staff of the Government Information Unit:
There are two journalists on the Unit's staff in Canberra and one in each State capital, a total of eight. The journalists in the States are known as Federal Information Directors.

There is provision for a journalist to be appointed in Darwin, and for another to be appointed in Canberra to assist journalists, especially radio journalists, in their contacts with Ministers. In the Unit's Canberra office there is also a research assistant, a secretary and a typist. And, in the States, there is provision for each Federal Information Director to appoint a secretarial assistant.
The Federal Information Directors are a genuine attempt by the Government to ensure the best possible communication and understanding between Commonwealth and State governments at all levels.

They are stationed in the State offices of the Ministers who have responsibility for Federal-State affairs. They assist the media in the States in gathering information on Federal affairs, in making contact with Government Ministers, in helping to co-ordinate programmes for Ministers visiting States, in arranging Press conferences and preparing press releases for special announcements, etc.
The Federal Information Directors are also required to keep the Commonwealth Government aware of the significant State issues which are relevant at the Federal level.
The Directors also help Federal Ministers in their contacts and activities in the States and keep the Federal Government in touch with public reaction to Commonwealth policies and programmes.
Sitting suspended from 1.1 to 2.15 p.m.
