I have found that the interjection 'That is not true' was not made in Question Time but was made during debate on protection of the sea legislation. My clear recollection is that I made that interjection in the unqualified belief that the conditions that I understood the Government Information Unit officers to be working under at the election time were the prevailing conditions. They are the ones I instructed. I have looked at the Hansard reports generally. I say quite clearly and without qualification that I have not either wittingly or unwittingly misled the House. I ask that the censure motion be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In supporting the censure motion moved by my colleague, Senator Button, I will also be brief. First of all I take up three of the arguments used by Senator Carrick in his reply to Senator Button. I believe a reply needs to be given to those arguments. I will give an example which demonstrates the difficulty Senator Carrick has had in answering the case. Senator Carrick cast doubts on the veracity of the documents which have been tabled by Senator Button and then he questioned the morality, as he put it, of using such documents. The first point I make is that these documents have been seen by Ministers in another place. They have obviously by now been seen by officials of the Liberal Party. No one, until Senator Carrick spoke today, has questioned the veracity of the documents. I challenge anyone on the Government side to state that these documents are not what they appear to be-true documents from the Liberal Party. Any suggestion that these documents have been falsified by anyone else I believe is nonsense. I believe that Senator Carrick and his colleagues know that it is nonsense.
—It is a measure of Carrick's desperation.

—As a second measure of Senator Carrick's desperation, as Senator Walsh puts it, I refer to the extraordinary performance that was put on to show that the use of documents like this is apparently immoral in this Parliament. If we need an example of queer morality in this place the statement of Senator Carrick must be the best. Those of us who were members of the Senate in 1972 and 1974-I include Senator Carrick-will remember the extraordinary flow of documents which were leaked to the then shadow Treasurer, Mr Lynch. An honourable senator was given a copy of the 1975 Budget documents on the morning of the Budget Speech and delivered them to Mr Lynch. In a Four Corners interview soon after the election the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) justified the use of leaked documents as being in the public interest. Every member of this place knows of that; every member of this place has heard the statement. Senator Carrick was part of that process of using leaked documents.

SPEECH.PARA: On one occasion in this place Senator Carrick moved a motion which was carried to allow Senator Townley to table in this place an unsigned document which made allegations about the former Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam. Let us not hear any of this nonsense about the immorality of using documents that are acquired in this way. These documents are Liberal Party documents. These documents are true. These documents were legitimately used by the Labor Party as documents were claimed to be legitimately used by the previous Opposition in this place. The difference is that the Treasury documents used by the then Mr Lynch were, in fact, private government documents. It was illegal for them to be leaked. This is particularly so in the case of the Budget documents. In some cases they were even purchased by Mr Lynch and his agents. Let us not hear this nonsense about the immorality of using these documents. It comes ill from Senator Carrick.

My second point is that Senator Carrick decided to remark that Mr Morrison, who is now a member of the House of Representatives, previously worked for an Opposition member and that one of our senators worked for an Opposition member. The point is that those people were hired by the senator and member to work for them in the same way as people are hired by those opposite. They were electorate assistants. Everyone knew who they were and what they were doing. In this case Senator Carrick and others have persistently pretended that members of the Government Information Unit were somehow separate and divorced from politics and from the Liberal Party. This plainly and obviously is not true. Senator Carrick has referred to the remark he made to Senator Button in this place on 31 March. Senator Button said:
During the last election campaign the members of the Unit were engaged in electioneering for the Liberal Party--
Senator Carrick quite unequivocally said:
That is not true.
Senator Button then said:
I make that charge and I invite the Government to deny it by argument and not by interjection.

The denial has not been made by argument here today. It has not been made anywhere else by argument because we have documentary evidence that what Senator Button said is plainly and obviously true. Senator Carrick said that at the time he made the remark he believed it to be true. He has had ample opportunity to discover in the meantime whether his statement was true and to correct it in this House. He has not done so. I believe that is sufficient reason for Senator Button to move the censure motion.

Senator Carrick, other Ministers and backbenchers have repeatedly made a virtue of the claim that junior Ministers, and some senior Ministers in this place, do not have Press secretaries. This was apparently a virtuous state of affairs. Some of us see no particular virtue in it. Whether one Minister has a Press secretary or not is not a matter of great importance. What is important is that Senator Carrick, Mr Newman, Senator Chaney and others have repeatedly fed us the line that there is something special about this Government because it set up a unit which was divorced from the Liberal Party and from party politics; that somehow this is more pure than people having Press secretaries with which, by implication of the argument, there is something wrong. It is clear-as one can show quite clearly after an interview on AM this morning-that this is just not so. The director of the Government Information Unit, Mr Vince Matthews, and his colleagues saw their role as Press secretaries. It was obvious to everybody in this place and many people outside that people like Laurie Power, Arnis Verbickis and Mr Bruce Montgomery were in fact performing the role of Press secretaries and that they pursued this role vigorously and aggressively.

It is pointless for Senator Carrick and his colleagues, by using the feeble, transparent and phoney device of calling these people information officers, to expect honourable senators to consider them as anything other than Press secretaries. However, we have been told repeatedly that these people are not Press secretaries and that their role is divorced from the Liberal Party and from the political functions of the various Ministers. When the Government Information Unit was set up, I suggest that its nature was obvious to anyone close to the scene. Newspaper articles at the time were pointing out that it was a Liberal Party propaganda operation. The people who were appointed to it were ex-Liberal Party functionaries. They were well-known Liberal Party supporters, like Mr Montgomery and Mr Power who were well known for their beliefs and who had been party activists before.

In Tasmania the situation was probably more obvious than in most States. It is a small State. People in the media know each other and people in politics know people in the media. It was perfectly obvious from the time that the information officer was appointed in Launceston and housed in Mr Newman's office that he was acting as a Press secretary in every way. He spent his time chasing the local Press. He produced tape recordings of party political statements for supply to local radio stations before, during and after the election. In fact, when one talked to members of the local media they frequently complained of the number of times that Mr Montgomery was coming around pushing the political barrow of Mr Newman. He has now transferred to Hobart to assist Mr Hodgman. One thing that has not been brought out in the debate today is that he is now to be given an assistant who will assist Mr Newman and who will act as Mr Newman's Press secretary in every way.

I believe it is important to look at what the senior person in the Government Information Unit said this morning in an interview on the program AM. He said that he thought that Mr Dawkins, who yesterday apparently had said that these people were permanent public servants, was wrong. He went on to say:

In fact we are Ministerial staff. This means we do not have permanency of tenure and we're seen by the public service in exactly the same way as a Press Secretary would. Now the presence of a Ministerial Press Secretary at a meeting with Liberal Party officials on certain occasions would not be considered out of place and that's precisely the role that we were playing.
He was asked:

So, the Unit's role is not simply providing the public with the information about the function and activities of Government or to explain to the public a government policy. It is in fact a political organisation involved in electioneering as well?
Mr Matthews said:
Well what is politics? Anyone concerned with Government is in politics . . . We are the same as Press Secretaries . . .

Later, when asked whether members of the Unit had any contact with the Liberal Party Secretariat or Tony Eggleton during the election campaign-that is something which plainly happened, as was demonstrated by Senator Button in his reading of the document this morning-he said:
Not directly. We were based in Melbourne.
He went on to say:
. . . we simply carried out a media monitoring function in advising Ministers of what was in the media. A purely reasonable Press Secretary role.

These people obviously saw themselves as Press secretaries. They were obviously used during the election campaign, as Senator Button has demonstrated, in close liaison with the Liberal Party. They were used as a monitoring unit to assist the Liberal Party in its election campaign. In everything but name they were Press secretaries, and even when questioned they considered themselves to be Press secretaries.

What was the Unit originally supposed to do? When the co-ordinating officers were first appointed, I asked Senator Chaney, as Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), what they were supposed to do. We got from Senator Chaney an answer that was quite different in some ways from the answers that have since been given by Mr Newman and others. We were told that they were to keep the Government in touch with public reaction to government policies and programs, a function that I thought-I said it at the time-should have been reasonably a function of members of parliament, senators and members of the House of Representatives. There was no need for a highly paid journalist to do this. Secondly, we were told it was to ensure the best possible communications and understanding between the Commonwealth and State governments. Surely that is the role of senior public servants and of members of parliament in liaison with their State colleagues. I said at the time, and we knew at the time, that these were not the roles of the journalists, that these people in fact were intended to be public relations officers and Press secretaries; and that is the role they have played. That is the role that Senator Carrick has denied repeatedly in this place that they have played. That is the reason for the censure motion moved by Senator Button.

Further disturbing aspects of this case have come out since the fuss has arisen. As honourable senators are aware, and as Senator Button has mentioned, we have in this place the Parliamentary Library. It is an excellent library which is made available to members, including Ministers and their staffs, for assistance in the course of their parliamentary duties. The duty statement of Library staff says 'parliamentary duties only'. The Library is not there to help with private concerns. It is not there to help political parties push their own political propaganda. It is certainly not there to get a Minister's personal image across to the public. It is not there to assist with the dissemination of government propaganda and party political propaganda. Yet we know-no one on the Government side can deny this-that officers of the Government Information Unit have made repeated requests to the Current Information Section and the reference service of the Library and, I believe, the Legislative Research Service. Those requests have been made by people on the grounds that they were on the staffs of Government Ministers, particularly Sir Phillip Lynch. They have misrepresented themselves to the Parliamentary Library and they have taken up the time of the Parliamentary Library, they have made it more difficult for members of parliament to use the Parliamentary Library and they have put an extra stress on the staff. If nothing else comes out of this censure motion, that sort of practice should stop.

There is no need to go on at great length on this matter in this place. Senator Button has demonstrated at length, with carefully documented evidence from Hansard and from the Liberal Party documents we have received, that these people operate as Press secretaries. He has demonstrated quite clearly that this Unit, paid for by the taxpayer and purported to be a Unit which puts out information about government activities, has worked in close liaison with the Liberal Party, and, indeed, worked in close liaison with the Liberal Party on a daily basis during the last election. It is quite clear from the Minister's answer to Senator Button on 31 March 1981 and his repeated denials to this House that Mr Laurie Power in particular, but co-ordinating officers in general, were in fact working as Press secretaries for Ministers, and were working in close liaison with the Liberal Party. He has had time to find out the truth of the matter and has had an opportunity to deny those allegations. He has not done so. He did not even do so satisfactorily today. For that reason this censure motion is justified. For that reason this censure motion should be supported. I support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -It has been the view of the Australian Democrats for some time that the Government Information Unit was from the start a misconception-a rather stupid misconception-because it would be bound to attract this sort of criticism sooner or later. We naturally deplore the plain use of this Unit for what at best- I emphasise at best-could be called quasi-political purposes. I use that term because in the very nature of present day politics where can one draw the sort of line that I think we are attempting to draw in the Senate today? A Minister has a duty to inform the public about his or her work, and every piece of favourable publicity or air time or television time that he or she may get could be said to give him or her political advantage. That of course is true.

SPEECH.PARA: I have listened carefully to what Senator Carrick has said in this place over the last few days. Our impression is that every utterance he has made on this point-a sort of convenient blurring of role-supports more or less what I have said; that is, that this is a grey area. It is a grey area because the Government designed it as such. Therefore, the Government is culpable to that extent. We do not disguise our contempt for it for that culpability. The extent to which it involves the Minister in this case is something I will come to later. But let me make that point quite clear at this stage.

Indeed, that blurring of role was changed by the Minister only on 31 March last when he interjected and said that it was not true that GIU members were engaged in political activity. That was an interjection made on the spur of the moment. I think we have to consider whether in fact the Minister genuinely believed at that time what he said was so.

The purpose of this motion is to censure him, not to do all the other things mentioned. I will try to address myself to that. We make two points about GIU. I think they are very relevant. In the first place, the Government should either disband this Unit and attach its people honestly as Press officers on the staff of Ministers and not try to get away with this stupid dissimulation that it is trying to get away with, or it should allow the GIU to make its services freely and impartially available to shadow Ministers in the Opposition, including, I might say, the Democrats. Unless it does one of those two things, it will continue to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha!

—Senator MacGibbon laughs at that. I take it from the expression on his face that he believes it is perfectly all right to have other than those two situations. In other words, is he saying that it is perfectly all right for the GIU to work overtly for the Government at election time? The honourable senator should take these things a little more seriously. I reiterate the two points for Senator MacGibbon's benefit: The Government should either disband the Unit and attach its people to Ministers honestly, so we know where we are, or it should make the Unit completely apolitical in the sense that its services are available to other areas of this Parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: We have listened carefully to what Senator Button has said. Unfortunately, the Australian Labor Party-we wish it could have done better in this respect-did not do us the courtesy of making the material available to us before it moved this motion, although it did warn us that it might happen and it has given us the information since. That made it a little difficult for us to assess the matter at short notice, and I would like to record that. I would like to speak next about the apparent role of the Unit as disclosed by this information. The Minister has cast some doubts on whether this material is genuine. Senator Carrick, when he first started to speak, made some noises as if he thought it was not genuine, but he has not been very explicit about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not said one way or the other.
—No, that is quite true. I was going to make that point. Therefore, I think the assumption we can make--
—You did say you had never seen it.
—Yes. I had never seen it-that is absolutely true-until last night.

—That clarifies that point. But it returns us to the main point. I do not think there is any serious suggestion from the Government that this material is not genuine. If so, we would like to know about it. I take it from the silence that there is no doubt about that. As a result of that, we see a reason to indict the Liberal Party absolutely and in every possible respect for its dirty tricks, its dirty tactics and its cynical and dishonest exploitation of taxpayers' money which have now been revealed by this matter. To the Australian Democrats that is far more important than whether a Minister should be censured, because it is the behaviour, ethics and morality of the entire political party which represents a substantial part of the Government which we are now considering. An honourable senator mentioned that Sir Robert Menzies might turn in his grave. I would say that any honest Liberal Party politician or any other honest politician from the past would certainly do so at these revelations.

SPEECH.PARA: We have watched this situation. We are aware of the way in which the Government sneaked in to abolish section 16 of the Commonwealth Electoral Act to its own advantage at a carefully planned time when it knew there was a Press strike on so that its action would not be known to the Australian people. Large numbers of the Australian people still do not know that that happened. That was due, of course, to the sneakiness of the Government in its desire to get electoral advantage in 1980 in every possible way. Indeed, the tactics emerged, including the abolition of that section of the Electoral Act, various other things we have discussed previously and the quite unwarranted attacks on the Australian Democrats. The allegations about our being allied with the Labor Party were denied in the eastern States when they were raised against Senator Chipp and me. The Government dropped them here and then, a few days before the election, it spent $400,000 in Western Australia when it knew it was too late to deny the allegations. That is how the Government won the last Western Australian Senate seat, and let that not be forgotten. This matter we are discussing--

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are proud of your candidate when he does come here.

—Indeed, I hope the Government is. I hope he does the Government credit. Let it be said and clearly understood that the 1980 Federal election was Australia's dirtiest election to date. We have discussed whether the documents are genuine. Did Senator Carrick know about them? We are not impressed by Senator Carrick's garbage tip ploy. It is not good enough. It is quite irrelevant. If the Liberal Party did these things, it is absolutely essential that we, the members of this Parliament, and the public of Australia should know the full revelations. It does not really matter very much where they come from. I again mention the relevance of this to what we were discussing last night-freedom of information. Honourable senators opposite have created the climate, as I said last night, in which things fall off the backs of trucks, in which journalists have to resort to leaks and in which things have to come out in this way. So do not be surprised. As I said last night, there will be more and more of it. Are honourable senators opposite surprised that that is beginning to happen already?

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that Senator Carrick has been less than clear and frank in his answers here and we would castigate him only to that extent, although I must say again that the blurring of roles here makes it very difficult to be completely explicit. There is involved a subjective judgment of what is political and what is not political during an election campaign. I do not want in any way to pull any punches in our condemnation of the Liberal Party-that is absolute-nor do I want to qualify in any way that our belief is that the Unit should be disbanded or otherwise made apolitical. But we accept the assurances the Minister has given that he did not know of these documents and that he believed that the Unit--

TALK.START.PARA: —And that he did not know of the Information Unit's involvement in the election campaign.
—That is right. He said that he did not know of its involvement in the Liberal Party campaign. We accept those points. On that basis we will not support this censure motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, has moved the most serious motion that can be moved in this Senate in relation to an honourable senator. The terms of the motion are:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate censures the Leader of the Government in the Senate for persistently misleading the Senate as to the nature and activities of the Government Information Unit.

The nature of the charge against Senator Carrick is contained in the phrase 'persistently misleading the Senate'. I would have thought that there was upon any honourable senator who makes that charge against another senator the highest responsibility to do so with the strongest evidence and with the strongest conviction that he was justified in taking that step. That step is justified, and the Senate should support such an expression of opinion, only if the Senate is satisfied that the Leader of the Government in the Senate, or any other honourable senator against whom such a motion is brought, did deliberately and intentionally mislead the Senate. But it is alleged against Senator Carrick that he not only misled the Senate but also that he persistently misled the Senate.

The way in which this debate has gone, and indeed some of the things that Senator Button said in moving the motion, make it quite clear that the purpose of moving the motion here this morning was only very slightly related to Senator Carrick at a personal level or to any allegations that he was responsible for misleading the Senate. The purposes of members of the Opposition are really otherwise, although they may be somewhat confused. The Opposition seemed at one point to be condemning the existence of the Government Information Unit, which has been in existence for some considerable time and about which a number of questions have been asked and information has been provided. In another place yesterday the Opposition raised the issue in that form and did not seek to raise it in the form of a censure motion against a Minister.

Another theme has been running through this debate; that is, the activities of members of the Government Information Unit during the election campaign and whether they were engaged in party political activities in association with the Liberal Party in that election campaign. That is another issue altogether. That issue is completely different from the existence of the Unit or from whether Senator Carrick misled the Senate. That seems to have been the basis for introducing the documents which the Australian Labor Party quite openly and proudly introduced despite the way in which they may have been obtained; and we do not know whether they are even accurate documents. The Opposition has not provided us with any evidence and has made no attempt to prove that they are accurate documents. They may be accurate, they may not be. Those documents were introduced into this debate not to attack the existence of the Unit but to attack the way in which some members of the Unit are alleged to have operated during the last election campaign. That is an entirely different issue. Other matters have been introduced into the debate about the dirty tricks of some members of the Liberal Party, of the Government, or of officials during the campaign. That is another quite irrelevant issue.

I want the Senate to come back to the real issue, which was identified by Senator Chipp very early in this debate. I think he adopted an unusual tactic to elicit the point of the debate, but it was a very valuable intervention he made to elicit what is the one and only real point in this debate. I am desperately disappointed in the attitude that has been taken by the Opposition, its Leader and its Deputy Leader in making these highly serious imputations upon Senator Carrick when really their purposes were otherwise.

Introducing the motion, Senator Button indicated, I thought in a somewhat apologetic way, that this motion was directed at Senator Carrick. He said something about Senator Carrick being selected because he was the spokesman for the Government on this issue. It is quite unjustified to use the procedures, the Standing Orders, and the conventions of the Senate as a vehicle for a motion censuring a Minister. It is not a motion censuring the Government, it is a motion censuring the Minister. They are not the same; there is a fundamental difference, and Senator Chipp put his finger on it very clearly.

There is a fundamental difference between a motion censuring the Government and a motion censuring a Minister. If the Opposition had wanted to raise the issue of the Government Information Unit or if it had wanted to raise the issue of the activities of members of this Unit, the proper course was to put down a motion which attacked the Government and alleged the Government's responsibility for these matters. But it has brought this motion-this is what I want the Senate to come back to and to focus on-against the Minister.

The Opposition has made a serious charge against Senator Carrick, and it has not established any proof whatever against him. The issue is simply and solely-this is the point which I said was earlier identified very clearly by Senator Chipp-whether the Senate is to believe that Senator Carrick, when he made that statement, believed that statement to be true. That is the only possible issue of substance in the exercise that has been going on here today at great length.

Senator Carrick has made very clear and very correct statements about the situation of Mr Power and his position as information officer attached to Senator Carrick's staff. He made it clear that Mr Power is not his Press secretary. Indeed, that is all perfectly clear and, I think, well established. These officers are attached to the office of a Minister but they are not Ministers' personal Press secretaries. Senator Carrick has given figures on the statements he has issued since he has been the Minister for National Development and Energy. Of approximately 144 Press statements, only eight were issued by Mr Power. As I have said, the issue is in relation to an interjection Senator Carrick made when Senator Button said that during the last election campaign the members of the Unit were engaged in electioneering for the Liberal Party. Senator Carrick interjected and said: 'That is not true.' Senator Carrick has clearly stated what he understood to be the role of Mr Power, the person attached to him, in the election campaign. He specifically instructed Mr Power as to what his role should be and what he understood to be his responsibility for Mr Power's work. Senator Carrick has made perfectly clear what his understanding of this role was. He has quoted from the documents which show what that role was.

I challenge anyone in the Senate to assert honestly, and vote accordingly, that he does not believe what Senator Carrick said in the Senate today in relation to this issue. I believe that it is a misuse of the Senate to bring this most serious censure motion in relation to Senator Carrick personally on issues which the Opposition wants to raise on other matters. Let the members of the Opposition raise those matters and let them be debated, but they should not raise them as a censure motion of Senator Carrick. I believe that this motion is hypocritical, misdirected and unjustified. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put-
That the motion (Senator Button's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr President, I claim to have been misrepresented. During the debate on the censure motion earlier today Senator Carrick said something to the effect that it was all right for Morrison and Sibraa to be on the government payroll when they were endorsed Australian Labor Party candidates. That is the way my staff took it down and that is the understanding that people on this side of the chamber have. As a matter of fact, it was mentioned by my colleague Senator Grimes, the Deputy Leader of the Australian Labor Party, that Senator Carrick had said that both Morrison and I as endorsed Labor candidates, had been on the government payroll. I advise the Senate that when I was elected to this place in 1975 I was the Assistant Secretary of the Labor Party in New South Wales. It paid my salary. I worked as Assistant Secretary during the campaign. It was the members of the Labor Party who paid my salary during that campaign.

SPEECH.PARA: When I was defeated in 1977 I occupied my seat in the Senate until 30 June 1978. From that date, 30 June 1978, until I was selected by the New South Wales Parliament to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Senator James McClelland, I was not working; I was unemployed. As a matter of fact, I was being interviewed for a number of positions when the vacancy occurred. The only other time I was an endorsed Labor candidate was in 1966 and that was for the House of Representatives seat of Wentworth. At the time I was a local government official and I took annual leave for the duration of the campaign. At no time have I ever been on the Commonwealth Government's payroll, including the time when I was an endorsed candidate.

Bill Morrison was appointed by me and was responsible to me and worked out of my office. I have never tried to hide that fact. I repeat: At no time have I been on the Commonwealth Government payroll, as an endorsed candidate or otherwise. I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick) to acknowledge that fact and to apologise.

DEBATE.TITLE: OPERATIONS OF THE REGISTERED MEDICAL BENEFITS AND HOSPITAL BENEFITS ORGANISATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I have so moved first of all because of the obvious fact that here we have an annual report for 1978-79 being brought down in 1981. This situation has recurred almost every year since the report became necessary. The introduction to the report states:
This report has been prepared in accordance with the requirements of section 76A of the National Health Act which provides:

(1) The Permanent Head shall, as soon as practicable after 30 June in each year, commencing with the year 1971, furnish to the Minister a report on the operation of registered organizations during the year ending on that date.

Apparently, to bring down a report for the year 1978-79 in April 1981 is to furnish it as soon as practicable. There are several things of interest in the report. The problem is that the report is so much out of date. Of course, one thing that is of interest to honourable senators on this side of the chamber, particularly those from Tasmania, is the fact that the report contains a list of funds which went out of existence in 1978-79. Only one of those funds-I believe that it was the Hibernian Medical and Hospital Benefits Fund in Queensland-was subject to court proceedings, but in all the other cases difficulties and obviously some anxieties were expressed by people who were caught up in the collapse of funds. Since then we have had the collapse of a very large fund in Tasmania-the Druids Hospital and Medical Benefits Fund-with the result that doctors, patients and, in some cases, hospitals have found themselves in financial difficulties.

We asked questions about the funds last year. We asked why they were not better monitored. We asked why we and members of those funds could not have some foreknowledge of why the funds were collapsing or even of the fact that they were going to collapse. We were assured in the Estimates committees by Mr Carroll that there had been a tremendous improvement in the provision of timely and adequate information coming from the health and secured funds. Despite that reassurance we have this report coming down so long after the episodes which occurred in this case. I suppose that the next report will be equally delayed. We seek some assurances that some action will be taken to make sure that the reports are not so delayed.

Only last Thursday the Auditor-General's report was presented in the Senate. It contained a complaint that the collapsed registered medical fund in Tasmania-Druids-had not responded adequately to requests by the Department for the provision of information. The Auditor-General sent a circular to all organisations asking for a more intensive program of reviews of the operations of the funds. It is regrettable that the annual report on the operations of these important registered medical and hospital benefits organisations-organisations which can exist only when they are licensed by the Commonwealth Government to do so-comes down when its information is so much out of date. We would like to know why the ninth report for the year 1978-79 was presented to the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) only in March 1981-about 15 months later than most annual reports are presented to this place. There is no explanation in the report of why it has been delayed. The only thing stated in the report is that the report should be presented as soon as practicable. If this is as soon as is practicable, surely the Senate should know why.

The other thing that makes this report out of date is that it gives details of changes to the health insurance scheme in 1978. But these changes were rendered out of date by the 1979 Government changes. The financial and accounting base on which the funds were then operating was also changed. The report is so delayed and so out of date as to be of interest only to historians. It provides the minimum of information which is required under the National Health Act. The accounts are there and the abstract of assets is there, but there is no analysis of fund membership and no real analysis of the problems facing funds. There is insufficient information in what should be the companion volume to this document-the annual report of the Department of Health.

If we are to have a proper oversight of our health insurance scheme, if we are to have some sort of confidence in our private health insurance funds, if the Commonwealth and the Parliament are to have a proper oversight of the functioning of these funds and their general operations, we really ought to receive a report on their operations less than 21 months after the end of the financial year. The funds are required to provide information to the Department of Health. Clearly, they do so only after considerable delay and considerable effort by the Department. The Auditor-General had to send out his own investigators to find out how the funds were financially situated, because the Department of Health, not having the returns, did not know. The simple fact is that the Minister for Health has the power to require that this information be given and be given promptly. The officers of the Department of Health have the power to follow up and to make sure that the health funds registered under the National Health Act play the game and play it properly. There has been a remarkable reluctance by either the Minister or the officers of the Department to put pressure on the funds in order to find out what is going on. I am afraid that until the Government and the Department of Health know what is going on the clients of the funds will be at risk, as were the unfortunate clients of the Druids health fund in Tasmania.

We point out that the report is late, skimpy and of interest largely to historians only. I believe that it is essential that in future a report should be brought down on time each year. I hope that at a later date we can have an answer from the Minister as to why the present set of circumstances exists. For that reason I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the annual report for 1978-79 on the Operations of the Registered Medical Benefits and Hospital Benefits Organisations, be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for investigation and report as to the reasons for the delay in its presentation.

Very briefly, I refer to page 15 of the fourth report of that Committee at which reference is made to the Committee's inquiry in relation to previously delayed reports. I believe it may be advantageous for the matter to be investigated further.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I wish to speak very briefly on an aspect of the report which concerns the Anglo-Australian telescope at Siding Springs which, as honourable senators would know, is one of the largest astronomical instruments in the world, a device truly designed to explore the furthest possible limits of space. When we-that is, the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment to which I have the honour to belong-visited that telescope on 14 and 15 June 1979, considerable problems occurred with the telescope due to the temperature differential between the air inside and outside the dome. Whilst this may seem a rather technical point, it was more than that because in fact it meant that this instrument, which has been built at huge cost, was not able to operate at its full potential and, after all, its principal value is at its full potential. It had been reduced to the performance level of a lesser instrument because of air perturbations within the dome. I understand from inquiries that large fans have been installed now to bring the outside air into the dome before opening the aperture and also very large fans have been fitted into the aluminising room where mirrors are plated; thus a lot of the problems have been overcome.

But, I think there is a lesson to be learnt from that, and I would hope that it has been learnt. It would appear that these aspects were originally designed into the observatory but they were removed at some stage during its construction on a cost cutting principle. I think that this is as good an example as any to bring forward to show how this kind of cost cutting which may appear simple and easy can have profound implications for the total investment concerned. I raise the matter now partly because of its intrinsic merit. We did have a situation whereby for many nights of the year this large, expensive instrument did not have the opportunity of working to its full potential. I am pleased to congratulate the Government and whoever has been concerned in seeing that that situation has been remedied. I think that is good.

Finally, I make the point that the observatory is now going through a fairly large period of expansion in the laboratories at Coonabarabran, as is the associate one at Epping, with the instalation of some rather sophisticated computers. I believe that there again there may be some kind of staff strains. I exhort the Government at this stage to look at this matter and to ensure that we do not have a situation again where somebody-perhaps someone in the Public Service Board or an accountant-says, 'You can't have this and you can't have that', thereby perhaps hindering the valuable work going on at that place. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW COUNCIL ON THE PROCEDURES OF THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING TRIBUNAL

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In relation to this report, the Minister for Communications (Mr Sinclair) will be making a statement later today outlining the steps the Government will be taking to invite comment on it. In this case the Government is taking the step of tabling the report in manuscript form prior to its printing. This is being done to ensure that there will be opportunity for public comment on the recommendations made by the Administrative Review Council before the Government reaches a decision on the recommendations. Limited copies of the report will be available in the Bills and Papers Office, the Senate Records Office and the Parliamentary Library. It is hoped to make printed copies available shortly.
—Could the Minister tell me whether it will be the case that a speaker from this side will be able to speak on that statement when it is introduced later today?
—I understand that the normal rules would apply.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I would like to point out to the Senate that on page 15 of the report mention is made of government assistance to the manufacturers of tobacco. For example, it is stated that domestic manufacture of cut tobacco is assisted through the rates of duty and that provision is made for funds for domestic manufacturers. On page 17 of the report there is a section which points out that assistance is given to tobacco growing.

In taking note of the paper, I could not help but think of a question that was asked by Senator Hamer in the Senate, two days ago, that is, on 7 April, about the anti-smoking campaign in Coffs Harbour in New South Wales.

TALK.START.PARA: —Coffs Harbour is right.
—That is right. Senator Hamer asked, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: Was the campaign designed to alert people to the dangers of smoking-related diseases, the most serious preventable health care problem in Australia?

In reply, the Minister pointed out that the Government had contributed $260,000 towards a campaign to instruct people on health care, and that smoking would come into this. The Minister went on to say that last year the Government had committed $500,000 to health care and had committed itself to a further $500,000 for the same purpose. I just wonder what the Government's attitude to this problem really is and where we are really going. On the one hand we wish to assist the tobacco growers and on the other hand we are spending money to promote a health campaign against smoking. I wonder whether the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Senator Peter Baume, could explain sometime the attitude of the Government towards the campaign for health care and anti-smoking on the one hand and the assistance to tobacco growers and manufacturers on the other hand.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -What is hinted at in the Industries Assistance Commission report on manufactured tobacco and what tumbles out of the transcript of the public hearings of this inquiry, for anyone who wants to look at it, is that this was an exercise in applying a veneer of probity to one of the shady backroom deals for which the Fraser Government is gaining richly deserved notoriety.

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances which led to this report are that, after many years of extremely high levels of protection estimated by the IAC in the report to equal $20,000 per tobacco grower, the tobacco growers were faced with a market which was shrinking absolutely. Given that the proportion of Australian leaf as a component of tobacco manufactured in Australia is not likely to increase despite the protective arrangements, the Australian tobacco producers were therefore faced with an absolute market decline and, therefore, commensurate reductions in quotas. This led them to seek means of enlarging the captive market granted to them by the existing arrangements. One way in which it was being by-passed was that already manufactured tobacco imported into Australia was not subject to the protective arrangements which comprise about 5 per cent of the market and involved principally Douwe Egbert tobacco.

What the National Country Party wanted was a back door arrangement to force imports of manufactured tobacco within the captive market mechanism. The problem was the Industries Assistance Commission Act. The IAC was established in the first place to guard against this sort of practice. That is why its establishment was fought so strenuously by the National Country Party. It was established to prevent, amongst other things, that sort of shady back room deal being done without anyone being aware of it. Confronted with the existence of the IAC Act the Government was obliged to send a loaded reference. Quite clearly it is regarded by the IAC as being a loaded reference. I shall not read it in full. It can be found in Appendix 1 to the Industries Assistance Commission report on manufactured tobacco. I will precise the reference. The Commission was asked to ascertain the level of assistance required to facilitate the use of Australian grown tobacco leaf in place of manufactured tobacco imports. Page 33 of the Commission's report reads:
If the terms of reference imply that:
(i) a mechanism has to be found to facilitate the increased purchase of Australian leaf, by altering the rates of duty applying to sub-item 24.02.9 in the Customs Tariff;
(ii) purchases should be at prices maintained by the Australian Tobacco Board's Grade and Minimum Price Schedule; and that
(iii) the policy includes importers within the term 'suppliers';

then this could be most appropriately achieved by the introduction of a concessional duty for imports of manufactured cut tobacco, contingent upon purchases of Australian leaf, along the lines outlined in Section 6.1.4.
The critical paragraph reads:

The Commission is not prepared to recommend adoption of this mechanism. On the basis of the evidence received, this would appear to be incompatible with the policy guidelines under Section 22 of the Industries Assistance Commission Act.
The Commission proposes that the assistance afforded the tobacco growing and manufacturing industries be reviewed by the Commission as soon as possible.

In the official Press release that accompanied the public release of this report there was no hint that the Commission was not prepared to recommend the extension to imported manufactured tobacco of the arrangements which apply to Australian manufactured tobacco. However, in spite of that the Government went ahead, which it is legally entitled to do, and it will offer a rebate in the vicinity of $120 a kilogram on imports of manufactured tobacoo for each kilogram of Australian leaf purchased. Since the importers of tobacco have no use for Australian leaf inside Australia, and if the importers of manufactured tobacco are to operate under the scheme, the Australian leaf, which they are forced to purchase in order to obtain the rebate of duty paid on imports, will have to be re-exported. This provoked comments from the IAC. Page 29 of the report reads:
Tariff arrangements which encourage the use of Australian leaf have been bound in the GATT as part of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations to a limit of 50 per cent.
That is the legal limit at the moment; the proportion of Australian leaf used in Australian manufactured tobacco is 57 per cent. The report continues:
Yet the industry has, by means of pressures not specified, induced the local manufacturers to voluntarily agree to absorb 57 per cent. It now seeks to have the same proportion imposed upon importers.

Furthermore, the methods by which the tobacco growers seek to impose that requirement on importers amount to an export subsidy to induce further purchase of leaf at the high prices determined for local leaf. Such a subsidy appears to be contrary to the protocol on Export Subsidies adopted by the GATT as part of the Multilateral Trade Negotiations settlement-notably Article 10.
The report continues:

The principle of our trade policy which would be most affected would be Australia's opposition to subsidies paid to induce export of agricultural products by rich countries which, by world standards, are relatively inefficient. The Australian Government has consistently attacked such direct or indirect subsidies to agricultural production designed to place upon world markets output which cannot be absorbed locally. An export subsidy for Australian tobacco leaf would compromise the Australian position, which is of major importance for efficient industries.

It is predictable that this further breach of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade which the Australian Government has now accepted as policy was done at the behest of a National Country Party Minister. Of course, that fact has come out in evidence given before a Senate committee. Evidence was given on oath by the former Chairman of the Australian Dairy Corporation that in 1976 Mr Sinclair, as Minister for Primary Industry, sanctioned such a breach of GATT with respect to the export of the skim milk powder. To be fair one ought to add that a former public servant whose demeanour before the Committee was, to say the least, vague did not corroborate that evidence and another public servant, after a great deal of pressure had been applied, did implicitly corroborate that the Minister was not aware of it. That will be the subject of a discussion at some other time.

However, according to more recent reports the arrangements, which the Government has tried to make but which it has declined to acknowledge publicly or frankly, regarding the extension of the protective mechanism-that is, protective to producers of tobacco leaf-effectively to encompass imports of manufactured tobacco, may not succeed. Douwe Egbert, according to the latest information I have received, has declined to purchase any Australian leaf at auctions presumably because it believes the inducement, bribe, or whatever one likes to call it, offered by way of rebate of duty is insufficient incentive.

I think I should also put on record the fact that there is a serious problem in the Australian tobacco industry. The consumption of tobacco is declining absolutely. Anyone who takes a balanced and rational view of the whole area will agree that that is a good thing for the nation. This means that there are adjustment problems for Australian tobacco producers. I repeat what I have said in public both last year and the year before, namely, that Australian tobacco production ought to be concentrated in north Queensland instead of being spread around three States as it is now. It just so happens that both technically and economically tobacco production in north Queensland is more efficient than it is in any other tobacco growing area. I believe it is also true that there are fewer alternatives available to people growing tobacco at Mareeba and Dimbulah in north Queensland than there are to people currently producing tobacco in other parts of Australia.

Ultimately this problem must be faced. Adjustments will be imposed upon the Australian industry by a declining market and, if we are to show any common sense, Australian tobacco industry production will ultimately be concentrated in north Queensland. In the meantime the Government, having declined to face up to that problem or to offer any constructive policies as to how that objective could be achieved, is in a sleazy back door way sanctioning-this is being done by a government which preaches the virtues of small government-a complex arrangement which is wide open to malpractice and corruption, and it is sanctioning further breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. This is most important. Because it is sanctioning further breaches of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade it is undermining its own moral position in its argument against the European Economic Community and is endangering the exports of a number of other Australian agricultural commodities.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: ADMINISTRATIVE REVIEW COUNCIL ON THE PROCEDURES OF THE AUSTRALIAN BROADCASTING TRIBUNAL

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Robertson Sen E.A.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

The report brought down by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) is concerned with the physical conditions under which livestock are to be exported from Australia. That aspect of the matter was covered very comprehensively yesterday by my colleague, John Kerin, in the House of Representatives. If anyone is interested in the subject I refer him to that speech. The export of live sheep, of course, has been a controversial issue both with respect to the physical conditions under which the animals are held on board ship and of course on the question of whether the sheep ought to be exported at all. There has been a continuing public debate, if that is not too euphemisic a term, between the Liberal and National Country parties in particular and the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union over whether the trade ought to be permitted to continue at its present and immediately preceding level.

This issue was touched on by Mr Michael Baume in the House of Representatives on 5 March in the context of broader comments on a resources rent tax but his comments would be more accurately described as advocating a return to Tudor mercantilism. He was advocating that any new materials capable of further processing in Australia ought to have an export tax imposed on them. He called that a resources rent tax. For all sorts of technical reasons it is not a resources rent tax and it does not meet these objects of such a tax. In case anyone should be induced to believe that the Liberal Party is modernising its economic thinking I think it should be added that what Mr Baume calls a resources rent tax of course would be a resurrection of 16th century Tudor mercantilism. The Liberal Party has reached back even further for that economic inspiration than it did by way of John Stone and a few other people when it adopted monetarism as its current economic dogma. Mr Baume continued on this theme and said:

There should be, for example, an export levy placed on live animals, but there is no levy on meat being exported. Such a levy would encourage the maintenance of a thriving meat processing industry to the benefit of all Australians, particularly primary producers. Once again I declare my interest in that industry.

Mr Baume is in fact a director of the meat processing and exporting firm Tancred Bros Pty Ltd. I guess that as well as having once been a partner of course in Patrick Partners, because of his association with Tancred's he would be well aware of the effect on the meat processing industry and the people employed in it of the current severe turndown in the numbers of livestock available for slaughter in Australia-particularly the numbers of cattle rather than sheep. The point I really want to make is the supreme irony of a Government member-the Government has in the most outraged tones for the last two or three years denounced the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union for daring to suggest that any impediment should be imposed on the export of live sheep from Australia and that there should be any interference with pure market forces-condemning the AMIEU for suggesting there should be any interference whatsoever with pure market forces in determining the level of live sheep exports. The proposition, although different in its form, has precisely the same object as the object of the AMIEU, which is to restrict the number of sheep and other livestock currently being exported from Australia. It was announced without any apparent embarrassment by a member of the Liberal Party, without attracting any squeals of outrage from members of his own party or members of the National Country Party. They are so forthright and so eager to condemn members of the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union who, whether they are ill-advised or otherwise, attempt as they see it to maintain their employment in the industry by placing some restrictions on the export of live sheep. It is an ironic situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge that sheep are a little out of the run of my ordinary line of business.
—What about chooks?

—I am prepared to make an exception on occasions for chickens. On this occasion I make an exception for sheep as well. The matters raised by this report on the sea transport of sheep are not just of interest to farmers and meatworkers and those concerned with animal welfare, they are also of considerable interest to those concerned with honesty and openness in government. I refer in this respect to an item which appeared in the 19 March 1981 issue of the National Farmer and which was in the 'Waterbag' column of that paper. The article appeared under the heading 'Stormy wether'. It read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The government has apparently ordered a swift bomb-disposal operation on a report which could have had an explosive effect on the live sheep industry.
Last year, with the animal welfare debate raging, Primary Industry Minister Nixon despatched a government vet to the Mideast on a live sheep carrier to monitor conditions on board.
The vet returned, his report went in-and promptly vanished.
Sources inside the Bureau of Animal Health insist it went to the Minister. The Minister's office denies having seen it.
But Waterbag has confirmed that all copies were promptly rounded up and pulped, while the allegedly strong, criticial and pointed recommendations are being 'readjusted' to a more palatable form.
The issue to Waterbag, reeks of stupidity and mishandling.

Indeed, if this report has any credence at all it would be very interesting indeed, to say the least, to have an explicit ministerial response to the allegations made in the article. It would be particularly interesting to know just how much of the report form the Government vet was in fact incorporated in the body of the report on the sea transport of sheep. I notice that on page 11 and subsequent pages of the report there is a reference to a study undertaken in October 1980 by Mr Meischke of the Bureau of Animal Health who made observations and measurements on a modern sheep carrier with 40,000 sheep. It may be that this is the gentleman whose report is the subject of the newspaper reference. If that is the case it would be interesting to know what was in the report, if this description of some of its comments is accurate. This description as far as it goes makes fairly unsavoury reading. I will add just one short illustration of that by referring to the passage headed 'Waste Control' which is a description of the findings of Mr Meischke. The passage states:

Great difficulty was experienced in waste control on this ship. The impervious pressed aluminium alloy or concrete floors drained through single 10 mm holes in each corner, which were nearly always blocked, and then through grates in the alleyways, which were frequently blocked. The result was that the wool of the sheep became contaminated and this raised atmospheric ammonia levels and humidity. Waste spilled over into food and water troughs below. Water spillage, feed spillage and, in certain areas of the ship, seaspray and rain, exacerbated the problems.

The report went on in respect of a number of other matters on this voyage which resulted, it is recorded, in a final mortality rate among the sheep in question of 1.5 per cent. It must be acknowledged that that is perhaps no higher a percentage than one would expect for any kind of transportation of animals over this distance and for this period. However, that figure is qualified by a further reference in this account of the report to the effect that true mortality figures were enormously difficult to establish because of the logistics involved in obtaining an accurate on-off count uncomplicated by other factors. I simply make the point that, if this is the report which was pulped in its original form and made to be rewritten in a more palatable and less potentially explosive form, it still raises some very serious questions as to what on earth was in the original report. On page 21 of the report it is stated:
Several other veterinarians have recently travelled with sheep to the Middle East. Their findings differ in emphasis from those made by Meischke but not in the overall picture.

So it is unclear, at least to me, whether the repressed report which is the subject of the National Farmer allegations was this Meischke report or whether, in fact, there are some other government veterinarian reports, at least one of which has been made subsequently to the Meischke expedition and which has been pulped and suppressed because of the unpalatability of its findings. I think these are important matters. They are of particular interest, as I have said, to people who are concerned with the operation of the industry generally. They are also of very obvious and immediate concern to the extremely large number of people in the community who, quite properly, are concerned with issues of animal welfare. I would suggest also that they are of an obvious kind of concern to that equally large and growing number of people in the community who are concerned with honesty and openness in government. I for one would very much appreciate an indication from the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner), who is in the chamber, that he will arrange for an investigation of the matters to which I have adverted, which clearly arise out of the contents of this report, and report to the Senate accordingly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak to the motion moved by Senator Walsh. Whilst Senator Evans in his opening remarks said that he was somewhat out of his depth in speaking about livestock, I would be somewhat out of my depth if I were to speak on legal matters. However, I feel that I am not out of my depth when I speak about sheep, having earned my living as a shearer for well over 20 years. I have probably handled more live sheep than any other person in this chamber.
—Live chooks, too.

—I have handled live chooks, too, over a period of 10 years. I am concerned mainly with what the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) said in the statement he put down yesterday in the House of Representatives and which we have not yet seen. The statement did not come down with the report in this chamber and I have to refer to yesterday's House of Representatives Hansard to see what the Minister said. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commonwealth has the constitutional responsibility for animal exports. The Bureau of Animal Health co-ordinates and supervises this activity by delegating inspection and certification functions to State departments of agriculture.

Whilst this is a very comprehensive report, nothing was said yesterday in that statement by the Minister about the Department of Primary Industry overseeing the export of live horses. I have mentioned that matter at length in this chamber. Whilst the Department has carried out a study on the effects of the export of live sheep, I look forward to the day when a similar report is brought down in the Senate about what the Department has done in overviewing the export of live horses to Japan. From the Press reports and the interviews which have been conducted on This Day Tonight and other current affairs programs, there is conclusive proof that those animals have been severely mistreated. This report is entitled 'Sea Transport of Sheep'. In the section headed 'General Husbandry of Sheep During Transportation', under the sub-heading 'Purchase and Assembly in Australia' it is stated:

Although those directly engaged in the industry understand the cumulative effects of such activities, those engaged in single facets may not. For example, most stock transport in Australia is to single destinations. An owner of stock arranges for his livestock to be carried to a sale by a local carrier. The stock are sold and the new owner then becomes directly involved in their welfare.

The problem begins after the stock have been sold in the saleyards and loaded on road transports or even into railway trucks for transport either to an abattoir or to the sea-front for export. This is the area about which concern is being expressed by many people who are concerned with the welfare of animals. Those of us who use the roads in country areas know that one has only to travel behind these road transports to see the way that some sheep are crowded into transports. Before the sheep have travelled a very great distance a lot of the weaker ones are trampled by the stronger ones. Quite often, when the transport reaches its destination a lot of the sheep are dead or severely injured. I think that the Bureau of Animal Health should be supervising that sort of transport of live sheep as well as supervising the transport of live sheep by sea. That matter is of great concern to me and to many other people. Under the same heading to which I referred, the report goes on:
All those engaged in the transport of sheep within Australia must be made aware of the special needs of sheep which are to be exported.

I would add to that the special needs of sheep which are transported within Australia for any purpose, when great care ought to be taken. Another heading in the report attracted my attention. On page 6 of this report, under the heading ' ''Shandying'' of Sheep' it is stated:
It is known that 'shandying' of sheep, i.e. mixing of sheep as to age, breed and origin, takes place and is accepted in the industry.

The shandying of sheep is not accepted by many of the people who have sheep for sale. I have been told by quite a few people who have sold sheep to buyers, supposedly for live export, that those sheep are drafted on the property. A certain percentage is drafted off the mob which is to be sold; the grower is paid at one price for X number of sheep for the live sheep market and at another price for sheep supposedly for local kill. After those sheep have been segregated and the price has been arrived at-on a basis of 30:20, or whatever, until 100 per cent is reached-the sheep are again mixed up and loaded on to transports. Many of the growers are very concerned that all those sheep are exported live so that the buyer, the in-between man, is the man who is making the enormous profit out of the sale. The grower is not being paid 100 per cent export price for all the sheep because the buyer claims a certain percentage are being exported live. This is something that the Bureau of Animal Health also ought to consider. Further on in the report, under the sub-heading 'Standards for Carriage of Sheep', it is stated:
The Australian Bureau of Animal Health in consultation with the States and industry, has issued 'Standards for the Carriage of Sheep by Sea' . . .

I hope that the Bureau will also issue standards for the carriage of sheep within Australia, no matter for what purpose they are being carried-whether for transport from one farm to another, from the farm to the abattoir, from the sale yards to the abattoir, or from the sale yards to the sea front. Whichever way livestock are carried, whether they be sheep, horses, donkeys or whatever, the Bureau of Animal Health should lay down standards for their carriage and should see that those standards are policed strictly. In that way people who have no concern at all for the welfare of livestock will not be able to abuse them just for monetary purposes. Having been a shearer for over 20 years, I have witnessed sheep being treated in a very callous manner in sheds which have not been built to care properly for sheep. They are crammed into pens, in some places there is not even a grating. I have shorn in many sheds where the sheep are crowded together on dirt floors, and honourable senators can imagine the state of those sheep. If there has been a dewy night the roof is dripping with dew in the morning and if the sheep have not been drained properly prior to shedding-this occurs also in the carriage of sheep to market-they are in a terrible mess and they suffer terribly overnight. The shearers also have had to suffer greatly the next day. In many cases they take a vote on the sheep and turn them out as being wet sheep even though the sheep have not been in a shower of rain, only the dew that has come off the roof. The sheep have been shedded in conditions which are highly unsatisfactory.

I could talk at great length about much of the cruelty to live sheep which I have seen, particularly ewes which are heavy in lamb. They are jammed into very confined spaces. It is all very well for people who talk about the export of live sheep to say that only old wethers are being exported. Much evidence has been provided to show that young sheep and young female sheep are being exported live to the Kuwait market and to other Middle East markets. This is of great concern to me. Senator Walsh made mention of the fact that the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union has shown some concern that great numbers of sheep are being exported live. The unionists point out that that is to the detriment of their livelihood. On the other hand the members of the union of which I have been a member since about 1935, the Australian Workers Union, benefit because the sheep have to be shorn before they are loaded for live export. So two unions are somewhat at a difference as to the effect which the export of live sheep has on their members' livelihood.

Be that as it may, I think what we must look at when we talk in terms of exporting live sheep is educating the buyers of live sheep in the overseas market in supervising the slaughter of those sheep in Australia under the conditions in which they want them slaughtered for those markets and in setting up properly equipped abattoirs in Australia so that the sheep can be slaughtered in Australia and so that no one in the Australian work force is losing a job or an income because the sheep are being exported live.

I conclude by saying that I do hope that the Bureau of Animal Health takes the study mentioned in this report somewhat further, undertakes a study on the transport of live sheep in Australia and extends that even further to the export of live horses and cattle.
