DEBATE.TITLE: PARLIAMENTARY DELEGATION TO THE COUNCIL OF EUROPE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -I present the report of the Australian Delegation to the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development debate at the Council of Europe, held at Strasbourg, in September 1980. I was not a delegate at the meeting in Strasbourg. I was a delegate at the Inter-Parliamentary Union conference which was held in East Berlin last year. Dr Harry Edwards was the leader of that delegation, but due to the fact that there was an election forthcoming, he had to return to Australia. Australia was very ably represented by both Mr Bruce Graham and the Honourable C. K. Jones. In annex B of the report, the Honourable C. K. Jones made the following statement:

SPEECH.PARA: Before concluding, I should like to repeat my concern about an issue I mentioned when attending this Council two years ago, namely, the process of preparation of OECD economic surveys, which we all know are based on information supplied by the national governments. The problem is that, at least in Australia, this national survey is accepted as being simply a mouthpiece for the Australian Government.
I mention that because it has been mentioned in this chamber before. Indeed, the Honourable C. K. Jones quoted from the Australian Financial Review to support his argument in the following terms:

The annual survey of the Australian economy, and economic policy, by the Secretariat of the Paris-based Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development has become a regular occasion for self-congratulation by the Australian Government. For inevitably it gives a somewhat rosy picture of Australia's policy experience and prospects. This is not surprising, since the OECD has long since given up any attempt at giving an objective, independent evaluation of the Australian economy. It can be relied upon to faithfully reflect the Australian Treasury's views.
The reason I mention that is that the Secretary-General of the OECD, Mr Emile Van Lennep, in annex C, picked up that point. In defence of the OECD he said:

I regretted that Mr Jones reiterated the criticisms of the independent judgment of the Secretariat of OECD. It is difficult for me to accept such comment. It would have been more helpful to have been confronted with facts and with analysis of what the defects are. Mr Jones told us that the OECD Secretariat goes to Australia and talks only with the Government and the political party in power. Let me state the facts about the visits of the last two missions of the Secretariat to Australia.

The first of these two saw, apart from the government departments, the Australian Employers' Federation and the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The mission made appointments with the Leader of the Opposition in parliament and with the Opposition spokesman on Treasury affairs. Both gentlemen, for reasons that were never clear, cancelled those appointments, to our regret.

The second mission, a year later, again saw government departments-as OECD missions do in all countries they visit-and apart from that made a tremendous effort to obtain other views, through visits to the Melbourne Economic Institute, to the Monetary Group at Monash University, and to the Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders University.

I can assure Mr Jones and, as far as necessary, others, that the OECD Secretariat also has the ability to read and to follow very carefully the development of views expressed in individual countries, and it also reads newspapers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen The Hon R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the report of the Commonwealth of Australia's Delegation to the 26th Commonwealth Parliamentary Association Conference held at Lusaka, Zambia, 1980. I recommend the report to honourable senators and honourable members. Honourable senators may already have scanned through the report. They will notice that it contains fairly lengthy statements of the main debates on the subject matters including not only the plenary sessions but also the debates in respect of the other panels of the conference. Perhaps I should quickly mention the subject matters which engaged the attention of the speakers in the plenary sessions. There was a discussion on current threats to international peace and security, led by India. There was a discussion on the Brandt report; international collaboration in combating drugs, 'the Law of the Sea', and the subject which engaged the attention of most people 'Africa South of the Sahara: The Beginning of a New Era'.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will recall that when the delegation had reached Lusaka it had reached a peaceful country adjoining another peaceful country; and every delegate to the conference was very pleased with the result of the Rhodesian settlement, which had been supported by the Australian Government and by the Australian Parliament. As a result of that settlement a very well known and educated African, Mr Mugabe, had been installed as Prime Minister of Zimbabwe. At that time he seemed to be a successful Prime Minister and since that time has established control over his country to such an extent that our Government in particular has donated over $20m in aid to Zimbabwe and the United Kingdom Government has promised about #100m in the next three years.

At the conference discussion took place as to what should be done about South Africa and about apartheid. The general tenor of the discussion was that the Commonwealth should proceed with the sort of role which we have come to accept. I only want to say that in my opinion the procedures that have been adopted by the Commonwealth-negotiation and discussion-including the pressures which heads of government can apply in important circumstances, prove that the Commonwealth is still a useful organisation. Of course, the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association plays an important role. However, the Australian Commonwealth branch proposed in New Zealand that to some extent procedures in the plenary sessions ought to be strengthened and that the Association should consider the adoption of recommendations and resolutions. It seemed to us from Australia that that procedure would strengthen the Association. I must confess that although we put that proposition before the conference, the executive opposed it in the plenary session. Many of the speakers at the conference asserted that such a procedure would not aid the Association but might wreck it and that dividing on motions or recommendations might be worse than retaining the present procedures. The Australian delegation was not convinced of that and argued for acceptance of its proposal. It still seems to me that the Australian Commonwealth branch and other branches of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association ought to be able to take a positive stand on this matter. The report contains a reference to this matter. Honourable senators will see that although we put our proposal in the strongest way, not only did the conference reject it but also, surprisingly some of our State branches did not agree with it. The Australian Commonwealth branch also put forward suggestions on how the panels should be composed, but they too were rejected.

I ought to say on behalf of the members of the delegation that we were in a very favourable position to see the change that had taken place in Zambia and in Zimbabwe as a result of the settlement in Zimbabwe. Both countries will develop more quickly than the situation in the early part of the war would have allowed. The settlement allowed us not only to travel within Zambia but also to make short visits to Zimbabwe.

On behalf of my colleagues in the delegation I acknowledge the assistance given to the delegation in particular by the then Acting High Commissioner, Michael Potts, and by an accompanying officer from the Department of Foreign Affairs, Sue Boyd, who not only gave valuable assistance in respect of arrangements but also knew the country and was able to guide and help the delegation. I commend the Australian High Commissioner in Zimbabwe, who also assisted the delegation. On behalf of those honourable senators and members who went further afield, I also thank the Australian High Commissioner in London, who was able to assist me and others in our program in the United Kingdom.

I would like to make a point about aviation. This matter was raised by Senator Sibraa and me shortly after my return from the conference. Honourable senators might remember that in November Senator Sibraa and I asked why the Australian Government had prevented Qantas Airways Ltd from flying in and out of South Africa. The reasons have not yet been made public.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was a commercial judgment by Qantas.
—Senator Sibraa, supported by me, put on the record some comments made by the Chairman of Qantas, Mr Leslie, which were reported in the Australian in November. The report stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Leslie also said Qantas was looking for new business and trying to overturn the Government ban on flights to South Africa.
Qantas was eyeing South America and talks had been held with a number of airlines there.
He criticised the Government's uneven policy on South Africa, claiming it should outlaw all flights or give half the business to Qantas.
'I take the view if you do not like South Africa then don't let anyone fly there', Mr Leslie said.

In the week that that was reported the Government had approved three extra flights by South African Airways into Australia, which seems crazy to me in the aftermath of an important decision by Australia in respect of Zimbabwe and in view of the fact that our prestige and the interests of the Australian Parliament in that country and in surrounding countries had been recognised and reported upon by delegates to the conference of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Association. As Senator Sibraa said, if there are problems in flying into Johannesburg, there are other ways to fly into South Africa. I hope that soon the Government will consider not only what we are saying but also the request of Qantas in respect of this matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave -I wish to make a personal explanation. During Senator Bishop's speech I misrepresented my position. I was not referring to the matter to which he referred. I was referring to the original decision by Qantas Airways Ltd to withdraw from the South Africa route. It was a commercial decision made some years ago. I am sorry if I misrepresented my position.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report on Australia and ASEAN: Government Response-Ministerial Statement

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on Australia and ASEAN. I seek leave to have the statement incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

I wish to respond, on behalf of the Government, to the report on Australia and ASEAN, the Association of South East Asian Nations, by the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which was tabled in Parliament on 4 December 1980. The report was issued after a wide-ranging inquiry by the Committee during 1979 and 1980. The Committee heard evidence from many individuals and groups and the report covers the many issues involved in Australia's relations with ASEAN and the countries of ASEAN.

I commend the Committee and its members for their report and would not wish to let the opportunity pass without paying a tribute to Senator Peter Sim. I understand that this is the last of a distinguished series of reports the Committee has produced under his chairmanship. I believe all honourable senators will agree that the report owes much to his wide understanding of the relationship between Australians and the peoples of our neighbouring region.

The report on Australia's relations with ASEAN brings into focus a central concern of our foreign policy. Australia's long-standing ties with the individual countries of ASEAN have gained in significance since those five nations came together in a joint endeavour to work for the social and economic development, and the stability, of their region. Australia, as a close neighbour, is intimately affected by events there. Not only does the region include some of the world's most rapidly-growing economies, but changes occurring there have obvious political and strategic significance for us. Australia's national interest demands that we follow these changes closely, that we support ASEAN in meeting the challenges these changes pose and that we seek, consistent with our national interests, to influence the way in which these challenges are met.

The Committee's report cautions against any attempt to categorise the relationship between Australia and ASEAN as in some way special. The Government agrees with this view. In fact, neither ASEAN nor Australia has sought to create an exclusive or special relationship. Australia and the ASEAN countries have global policies and obligations and a multiplicity of links with other countries which it is not desirable or intended to set aside. To harbour the belief that the ASEAN-Australia relationship is special would be to invite a potentially damaging complacency in the relationship. At the same time, there should be no doubt that the Australian Government continues to place a high priority on its relations with the countries of ASEAN and the Association itself. Vietnam's invasion of Kampuchea, with support from the Soviet Union, and the resultant problems which have flowed from that invasion, have served to underline a number of important politico-strategic concerns shared by Australia and the ASEAN countries.

In 1974 Australia became the first country to establish a dialogue relationship with ASEAN. Regular consultations are now held on political, economic and development issues and on a range of other matters. They have included one meeting at heads of government level-in 1977 when the Prime Minister met with his ASEAN counterparts in Kuala Lumpur. Meetings between the Australian Foreign Minister and his ASEAN counterparts are now an established practice and are a welcome and most valuable feature of the dialogue. The frequency of consultations between other Ministers of the ASEAN and Australian governments has also increased since 1977.

Consultations at the ministerial level are supplemented by regular contact between Australian and ASEAN officials in Canberra, in the ASEAN countries and in other centres such as the United Nations in New York. Consultations have been given form through the annual ASEAN-Australia Forum, a meeting of senior officials, which is scheduled to meet next in Canberra in April. Between Forum meetings, the ASEAN-Australia Consultative Meeting, AACM, established in 1978, brings Australian officials from twelve departments into regular consultation with the heads of the ASEAN diplomatic missions in Canberra. Matters of detail affecting our trading relations and our development co-operation programs are dealt with by special working groups under the AACM. This consultative machinery has proved an effective and practical way of enabling a continuous process of consultations on matters of interest and concern to the six countries.

The Government agrees with the Committee's recommendation that priority be given to developing policy-making processes to co-ordinate effectively the interdependent elements of domestic and foreign policies. The Government considers that the political and economic, foreign and domestic elements of Australian policy should continue to be treated as parts of our total policy towards ASEAN and not approached as entirely separate entities. As well, in formulating policy towards ASEAN, full account needs to be taken of Australia's important bilateral relations with the ASEAN countries. It is important that the practice of adequate consultation on policy matters affecting Australia's relations with ASEAN be continued. To provide a co-ordinated approach the Government in 1977 established the interdepartmental committee on ASEAN. I believe this machinery is working well.

The Government accepts the Committee's recommendation that consultative procedures in policy co-ordination should be broadened to promote close liaison with the non-governmental sector when the issues involve them. Some advance has been made in this area since evidence was presented to the Senate Committee. In practice the Government and departments maintain close contact with the business community and with business groups, including the bilateral business co-operation committees, chambers of commerce and similar bodies which link the Australian and ASEAN private sectors. In addition, officials provide briefings and seminars for individuals and groups in the Australian business community and these have resulted in a better understanding by government and business alike of matters arising in dealing with ASEAN.

To meet the growing demands of Australia-ASEAN relations, the Committee recommended that Australia's diplomatic missions in the region be provided with adequate staff and resources to ensure that Australia's policies are effectively implemented. Our posts in the ASEAN countries are regarded as having a high priority in claims on staffing and resources. At the same time, there is need to balance the requirements of our ASEAN posts with requirements elsewhere, such as those arising from the opening of new posts. Because of this, pressure points do exist. Staffing levels, both at our posts and in Canberra, are kept under constant review.

In respect of economic relations, the Committee recommended that emphasis be given to developing economic policies as they are a key element in the relationship and serve both ASEAN and Australian long term interests. Efforts are already under way through consultations with the ASEAN countries, and through trade and investment development initiatives, to widen regional understanding of Australian economic policies. In July 1979 a joint trade commission was established with the Philippines and a joint trade committee with Thailand. These bodies, together with the AACM, provide useful and direct means for exchanges of information on matters of trade interest between Australia and the ASEAN countries.

The Committee states that the development of economic policies should include careful explanation of Australia's position on tariffs, including domestic implications, commitment to tariff reductions and responsibilities to the Australian community. The Government's approach to industries assistance, which involves a commitment to lower and more stable tariff levels, was set out in the White Paper on manufacturing industry and endorsed by the Study Group on Structural Adjustment. This approach recognises the need to take into account the ability of the community to absorb change and the need to deal with short term problems. The ASEAN countries have been advised of the Government's approach to those matters and this practice will continue.

The Government notes the Committee's recommendation, in respect of trading relations, that the general approach to preferences should continue 'where it is practical and mutually beneficial'. It further notes the Committee's recommendation, on prospects for trade development, that Australia should continue to stress its commitment to a reduction of trade barriers on a reciprocal and non-preferential basis and intensify its efforts to achieve such reductions. Tariff preferences accorded to products of developing countries have been regarded as an important concession by those countries, including ASEAN. As a member of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Australia has supported and participated in reciprocal and non-preferential reductions of trade barriers in the context of global trade negotiations such as the multilateral trade negotiations. Outside that framework, however, reductions in tariff occur in the context of reviews of industry assistance and are not dependent on reciprocity. To tie such reductions to reciprocity would in some instances involve maintaining barriers higher than economic prudence would justify. While opportunities for reciprocal reductions of trade barriers arise in the context of GATT negotiations, reciprocity is not required of developing countries in such rounds and, in the present global climate, demands for reciprocity from developing countries would not be well received.

The Government has already taken action in the direction recommended by the Committee to encourage and support links between private sector organisations in Australia and ASEAN. The ASEAN-Australia Business Council was established in June 1980 and I note that the Committee acknowledges the initiatives the Government has taken to support the development of industry links with ASEAN. Co-operation with the ASEAN-Australia Business Council and the various business co-operation committees and chambers will be continued where appropriate as part of these initiatives. In the end success or failure will depend upon the independent efforts of business people but I can assure the Senate that, as a Government, we will do all we can to create, as far as possible, the conditions for success.

In respect of data on trade flows, the Committee recommended that the Australian Government should give further consideration to providing more detailed statistics on the balance of payments with ASEAN countries, particularly to serve industry needs. Further progress has now been made on the review of regional balance of payments statistics mentioned in the letter from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) to Senator Sim and quoted on page 38 of the report. The Australian Statistician is now able to release broad statistics on the balance of payments with each ASEAN country, although he is unable at this time to release statistics at a detailed level.

The Committee expressed support for the proposal that the Australian Government should post a labour attache to ASEAN. It is the Government's view that such an appointment is not required at this stage but that the matter should be kept under review. The Committee's recommendations that the relevance and significance of development assistance in Australia's relations with ASEAN and its member countries should be kept under review are consistent with Government policy. Bilateral development assistance to the ASEAN countries is kept continually under review through project and program reviews, and through direct consultation with recipient governments, aid co-ordination officials and the various international consultative organisations, such as the Inter-Governmental Group on Indonesia-IGGI. The ASEAN-Australia Economic Co-operation Program-AAECP-which brings Australia and the ASEAN countries together in regional programs, is also continually reviewed through regular meetings of the AACM's special working groups on development co-operation and on trade and through the annual meetings of the ASEAN-Australia Forum.

In its conclusions and recommendations on immigration, the Committee stated that it is concerned that Australia is still seen as a European outpost in an Asian region. It recommended that the Government concentrate on projecting Australia's identity which is evolving through the changing structure of its society. The Committee also recommended the further development of immigration policy along the lines recently adopted, a humanitarian approach to the needs of refugees and the intensification of efforts to finalise the reunion in Australia of families from East Timor.

In general the Government accepts these recommendations. A substantial shift of opinion has taken place in ASEAN countries since Australia's restrictive immigration policies were changed. While Australia is still seen by some as excessively predisposed towards Europe, the view is less widely held than six or seven years ago. The understanding that many suitably qualified people are eligible to migrate to Australia is now more widespread as is recognition that Australia, while having close cultural and other ties with Europe, shares many of the preoccupations and interests of the ASEAN countries.

Personal contracts are indispensible as a basis of understanding between countries. The Government agrees with the Committee that student exchanges and migration from the ASEAN countries play an important role in building this understanding, and in removing any impression that Australia remains a European outpost in an Asian region. Changes to our private overseas student policy have recently led to the introduction of new arrangements whereby a greater number of such students will be able to enter Australia for long term study.

Since the report was drafted, Australia has maintained its resettlement and humanitarian support of Indo-Chinese refugees and its efforts to complete the East Timor family reunion program. The Australian Government has contributed some $30m to Indo-Chinese refugee and related programs overseas, with further substantial private contributions from Australian citizens. We have accepted some 47,000 Indo-Chinese refugees, most of them from ASEAN countries of first asylum. Upwards of one in every 310 persons in Australia is an Indo-Chinese refugee and community groups have backed and supported the Government's efforts. In addition to its vital humanitarian contribution, the Government's Indo-Chinese refugee program has been a postive factor in Australia's co-operation with ASEAN.

In line with the Committee's recommendation, the Government is engaged in a co-operative effort with the ASEAN countries to stem the flow of illegal narcotics through the region. The Government agrees strongly with the recommendation that everything possible should be done to prevent the incalculable damage which could be done to the fabric of our societies by the spread of narcotics, and has recently devoted increased resources to this area.

In respect of the news media, the Committee urged continuing efforts to ensure information flows between Australia and the ASEAN countries and recommended that the Government initiate further discussions with the Indonesian authorities to ensure that Radio Australia has a correspondent in Indonesia. The Government considers that the Committee's comments on these matters touch on significant aspects of the relationship between Australia and the ASEAN countries. We recognise the importance of encouraging informed and balanced coverage of developments in the region by the Australian Press and support the Committee's view that the ASEAN countries should be encouraged to establish media representation in Australia.

The Government believes that Radio Australia has an important place in expanding perceptions of Australia in the region and awaits with interest the report of the Committee of Review of the Australian Broadcasting Commission which has considered Radio Australia's operations. We are aware of objections within the Indonesian Government to aspects of Radio Australia's broadcasts. Contracts between the Australian Broadcasting Commission and the Indonesian authorities aimed at securing the return of an ABC correspondent to Jakarta have taken place. I hope that these will be successful.

The Government notes the Committee's support for the establishment of an Asian studies council, a proposal put forward in a report prepared by the Asian Studies Association of Australia. Government departments are already examining the report and the Government's views on it will be made known later in the year. In the meantime, my colleague, the Minister for Education (Mr Fife), has asked the Tertiary Education Commission to take account of the report in preparing volume I of its report for the 1982-84 triennium. On education and cultural relations the Government accepts the Committee's recommendation that every effort be made to meet requests from the ASEAN countries for assistance in education, particularly in the teaching of English.

Australia already supports a number of projects in the ASEAN countries related to education. These include bilateral aid projects, support for the South-East Asian Ministers for Education Organisation, SEAMEO, for the activities of the Australian Vice-Chancellors Committee under the Australian-Asian Universities Co-operation Scheme, AAUCS, and for the ASEAN Education Development Project under the ASEAN-Australia Economic Co-operation Program. In these fields, as in the particular field mentioned by the report, that is English teaching, the Government welcomes and makes every effort to meet requests from ASEAN governments according to their own priorities.

The Committee in its report, recommended that the work of non-governmental organisations continue to be supported by the Government and, in response to the needs indicated by the ASEAN countries, that that support be expanded wherever possible. Non-governmental connections between Australia and the ASEAN countries have been the subject of a recent inquiry by a working group established by my predecessor. The group has now completed its work and I plan to make a statement on this shortly.

The Government accepts, in the context of available resources, the Committee's recommendations about the importance of providing information about Australia in the ASEAN countries. An extensive information program is pursued by our diplomatic missions in the region. In addition, the Government has given support to Chulalongkorn University in Thailand in establishing a course on Australian politics, and in assisting the University of Indonesia which hopes to establish a Chair of Australian Studies.

The Government welcomes the public attention which the Committee's inquiry and report attracted to Australian relations with ASEAN. The report has served to underline the important place of ASEAN and the ASEAN countries in Australia's foreign policy. The findings of the Committee are broadly consistent with the initiatives the Government has already taken, or is taking, to strengthen our relations with ASEAN. The report has, at the same time, thrown into relief some areas in which problems exist and has made useful suggestions on what might be done to deal with them. The practice of consultation with ASEAN is firmly established, and I believe that this will assist with the resolution of any differences in a co-operative spirit. In dealing with the issues which must arise from time to time between neighbours, I am sure we will all remain aware of the fundamental interests we have in common in the preservation of a secure, strong and self-reliant region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sim Sen J.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I wish to make a very short statement. First of all, in general terms I think the Government's response to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence is very satisfactory, but I reserve the right at some later stage, when I hope the Government's response will be debated in the Senate, to make some comments upon some aspects of the response and on the Committee's recommendations. I wish to say only that I am very pleased, in view of the very justifiable complaints made from time to time from all sides of the Senate about the long delays in the Government's responding to Senate Committee reports, that the Government on this occasion has responded with some alacrity. The report was tabled only in February and the Government responded within a couple of months. I hope that that will set an example and will produce quicker responses to other reports. With those few comments, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The Government agreed with and accepted the majority of the recommendations in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on Australia and the Association of South East Asian Nations. I am very pleased about that. Like Senator Sim, I am very pleased about the quick response which we got to the report. I hope the Government did that because of the criticisms which have been made in the past by members of the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Having said that, however, I am disappointed that the Government did not agree with the Committee's recommendation concerning the appointment of a labour attache to ASEAN. Page 7 of the Government's response states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee expressed support for the proposal that the Australian Government should post a Labour Attache to ASEAN. It is the Government's view that such an appointment is not required at this stage but that the matter should be kept under review.

A recommendation which all honourable senators on the Committee strongly support was that we should have a labour attache in ASEAN. It was supported by the Australian Council of Trade Unions and also by a group of Australian trade unionists who recently attended an Asian trade union conference in Bangkok. I believe the labour attache should be stationed in Singapore where there is a strong trade union organisation. I think more importantly his job would have been to keep in touch with trade unions and trade union leaders in the ASEAN countries, especially in those countries where they face great difficulty in carrying out their trade union duties.

I think all of us should remember what happened to the democratic trade union movement in South Vietnam, and that is that the people who, early on in the conflict, were a third force in that country were one of the first groups to be crushed by the then South Vietnamese Government. I think it is important that a labour attache would have kept the governments of ASEAN up to date on the Australian industrial scene. It is a pity the Government did not support our recommendation. Japan has realised the importance of a labour attache. It has appointed one to Australia and, of course, we have now appointed one to Tokyo. I am not completely happy with the Government's answer in regard to staff. Page 4 of the report states:

To meet the growing demands of Australia-ASEAN relations, the Committee recommended that Australia's diplomatic missions in the region be provided with adequate staff and resources to ensure that Australia's policies are effectively implemented. Our posts in the ASEAN countries are regarded as having a high priority in claims on staffing and resources. At the same time, there is need to balance the requirements of our ASEAN posts with requirements elsewhere, such as those arising from the opening of new posts. Because of this, pressure points do exist. Staffing levels, both at our posts and in Canberra, are kept under constant review.

I think one of the problems we have is that of staff ceilings in the Department of Foreign Affairs. Unfortunately, in the ASEAN region, in some instances, it has been the locally employed staff-the local people-who have had to be put off, and Australia's image has suffered as a result of that. A number of other issues in this report ought to be debated, such as Radio Australia, the immigration policies and the ASEAN Studies Council. I do not think this is the time to debate them. Senator Sim has sought leave to continue his remarks later. I will conclude my remarks and hope this matter is brought on by the Government at an early date for debate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PHILIPPINES-INCIDENT ON AN AUSTRALIAN AID PROJECT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement on a recent incident on an Australian aid project in the Philippines.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

On 16 February 1981, two construction supervisors assigned to the Philippines Australia Development Assistance Project-PADAP-located in the province of Zamboanga del Sur on the island of Mindanao were robbed, abducted and subsequently shot by a group of bandits. One of the supervisors, Mr Gordon Murdoch, was killed and Mr Harold Hough, a New Zealander, was seriously wounded. Contrary to some reports there is no evidence that the attack was politically motivated or that it was directed specifically against the project or the personnel assigned to it.

The incident has been a source of great distress to all associated with the project: Australian aid personnel have never previously been victims of such a violent attack, although they have on occasions faced real threats to their personal safety. I wish to make a statement today about the incident, the outcome of the investigations so far conducted by Philippine and Australian officials and the intentions of the Minister for Foreign Affairs regarding the future of PADAP.

Before dealing with the incident, I pay tribute to the many persons and their families who, over the years, have accepted appointments to Australian aid projects and who have committed themselves to achieving the objectives of Australia's aid programs. Often they have been asked to work in extremely difficult and generally remote areas where the lack of development has given rise to security problems. Without the support of dedicated people such as the late Mr Murdoch, Mr Hough and others who have at one time or another worked on PADAP and similar projects in other countries, Australia would not have been able to earn its well deserved reputation as an aid donor.

The Philippine Government reacted quickly to assist by providing an aircraft to transfer the wounded man to Manila on the day of the shooting. Assurances of continued assistance in improving security arrangements have been received and measures have already been taken in this regard. Regret and concern about the incident have been expressed at the highest levels in the Philippine Government and by many from the province itself. The importance attached to the project and appreciation of the efforts of the Australian personnel assigned to it have been re-emphasised.

Investigations of events surrounding the incident have been given a high priority by the Australian Embassy in Manila which has maintained close consultation with the Philippine authorities and the Australian Development Assistance Bureau which sent a senior officer to the Philippines to investigate. On the basis of reports that have been submitted to me, I would like to inform the Senate of the incident and its implications for the project. The bulk of evidence points to project personnel, who regularly travelled the road on which the incident took place, inadvertently coming upon a road block and robbery. The subsequent events remain unclear. The bandits, for reasons that are unknown, apparently decided to abduct the two Australians after the robbery and were taking them away when shooting started. This was associated with the arrival of Philippine Armed Forces personnel at the site of the hold up; the two supervisors were shot by the bandits as their captors attempted to retreat from the military forces. Despite improvements that have already been made to security arrangements, the fact remains that there is no way by which either the Philippine or Australian governments can provide an absolute guarantee of the personal safety of personnel on this and indeed on several other projects in other countries short of withdrawing from these aid activities. The risks must, however, be balanced against the benefits to the people being served by the project. In this case the benefits are very substantial indeed. The project had a most significant and positive impact in its area of influence and has made a substantial contribution to improving living conditions and to providing greater economic opportunities for the mostly rural population affected by it. For example, there is evidence that the project has improved access to markets and rural credit facilities for those people and, as a result, there has been an increase in both the volume and number of agricultural crops.

Intensive project activity in the testing and dissemination of new crop varieties with co-operating farmers has made a significant impact on rural production as has the irrigation project. Small farmers have been the primary beneficiaries of the livestock and pasture development aspects of the project. Transportation costs have been reduced as a result of restoration of roads, while the population in the project area now enjoys improved access to health, education and other basic services. Many villages which previously had no clean and reliable water supplies are serviced by pumps installed by the project.

The project's achievements are clearly substantial. In particular, a great deal of progress has been made in ensuring that the bulk of the population shares equitably in the economic and social benefits generated by the project. As the project comes nearer to completion those benefits will become more evident. A number of Australian priests working in the area have noted the benefits that the project has brought to the local population. For its part, the Australian Government is fully committed to the project and is doing all that it can to see that its objectives are realised.

In the light of all these circumstances, the Minister for Foreign Affairs has decided that Australia's involvement in PADAP should continue but has directed ADAB to investigate alternative means of implementing the project whereby Australian personnel will in future be less exposed to risk. For instance, the Minister has directed that the geographical coverage of the project be reduced and that access to more distant work sites be improved. This will ensure that Australians are not required to work in either remote areas where it is difficult for local authorities to provide adequate protection. As a result, the risk faced by Australian personnel will be significantly diminished.

In conclusion, the Philippines Australia Development Assistance Project is an aid activity of which all Australians-and especially those who have worked on it since 1974-have every reason to be proud and one which I believe deserves the Government's continuing support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: -by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I think the incident referred to in the statement brings home to all of us the often hazardous and extreme conditions in which Australian aid officers work. Only recently an Australian Development Assistance Bureau officer died in an air crash in Tanzania after visiting an aid project at Singida. It is a project which I and other members of parliament visited in 1979. It is a very worthy project. But even before all the votes were counted, there were strong claims that the election had been rigged.

TALK.START.PARA: —The dirty tricks division.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek leave to have a statement relating to the southern bluefin tuna fishery incorporated in Hansard.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

Honourable senators will recall that on 30 March 1976 the then Minister for Primary Industry gazetted a notice under the Fisheries Act 1952 concerning the taking of southern bluefin tuna in certain waters off New South Wales, Victoria and South Australia by the pole and live bait method of fishing. The effect of this notice was to freeze the number which had fished there in the 1974-75 season-about 70 vessels. The freeze was intended as a temporary measure to allow an assessment of the situation in the fishery, and to stabilise investment, following two bad seasons when catches were poor and prices low. The industry felt recovery would be helped by controlling the number of vessels entering the fishery. The freeze was reviewed in 1977 and again in 1978, by which time studies had been completed and better fishing seasons experienced. In 1979 the Australian Fisheries Council recommended to me that the freeze be lifted.

I met with industry representatives in January last year. They drew my attention to the interaction which had developed between the tuna and south eastern trawl fisheries-many fishermen operating their vessels in both fisheries. Largely because of this I deferred lifting the tuna freeze, announcing that it would be lifted on 31 March 1981, and that in the meantime my Department would update the earlier economic survey to see if there was a need for any continuing management regime. The Australian Fisheries Council met again in September 1980 and reaffirmed its earlier recommendation that the freeze be lifted. The economic study has been completed and does not provide any basis for concluding that the freeze should continue, or that management of the tuna fishery per se is necessary.

Recently there have been a number of meetings within the industry, between industry representatives and State departments, my Department and the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. I have also met with the Federal President of the Australian Fishing Industry Council and had extensive discussions with him. I think it fair to say the industry is divided, both within the processing and fishing sectors, as to the need for the freeze and its effectiveness. After considering the advice of the industry, of my own Department and the CSIRO, I am satisfied that the freeze has been ineffective in achieving its objective of stabilising investment in the fishery. I therefore believe the Australian Fisheries Council recommendation to lift the freeze was well based. Furthermore, I am concerned about Australians being prevented from fishing for southern bluefin when we have an agreement enabling Japanese fishermen to do so. Another point is the need for Australians to expand their fishing activities to take other species of tuna, such as skipjack. It seems to me this will not be facilitated by retention of the freeze.

I do not expect there to be any significant increase in the number of new vessels in the fishery. New entrants, if any, will not be able to establish access rights under any future management regime on the same basis as fishermen who have operated in the fishery to date. Accordingly fishermen planning to enter the fishery should not base their expectations of profitability on taking southern bluefin tuna. I have concluded that I should endorse the Australian Fisheries Council's recommendation and lift the freeze, and the necessary fisheries notice will be gazetted forthwith. However I will require the South Eastern Fisheries Committee to immediately undertake a study of the tuna and trawl fisheries recommended in my Department's economic study and require it to report its conclusions to the Australian Fisheries Council in September. In the meantime operations in the tuna fishery will be kept under review by my Department to ensure that I am immediately informed if a situation develops which requires more urgent attention, and I have sought, and confidently expect to obtain, the immediate co-operation of my State colleagues in implementing any action necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the statement.

I find it necessary to make some comments on this paper because I have some reservations about the method by which it has been prepared and the results which are likely to be achieved. The southern bluefin tuna has been under discussion in regard to a freeze of fishing efforts since 30 March 1976. Whilst this subject has been discussed fairly regularly between then and now, there really is not a great deal of information additional to that made available at that time. This industry has involved approximately 70 vessels. It has now been decided, according to the statement, that the existing freeze shall be removed. The statement reads:
In 1979 the Australian Fisheries Council recommended to me that the freeze be lifted.
On page 2 it reads:
. . . does not provide any basis for concluding that the freeze should continue.

That is a very negative statement. I would have far preferred one which said that information was available to indicate that the freeze should not continue. To me it is not a strong enough statement to justify the action which had been taken. The next paragraph reads:
I think it is fair to say the industry is divided . . .

I do not think that is a good enough statement, either. The section of the industry which is involved with this fishery, to the best of my knowledge, does not say this. The section of the industry which is not involved may say it, but the section which is involved does not. The next paragraph reads:
I am satisfied that the freeze has been ineffective . . .

But we are given no detail as to how or why it is considered to have been ineffective. The statement does not say whether there has been any change in the maximum catch levels or the economic advantages of the fishery. I believe it is not sufficient for the Minister to say: ' . . . I am satisfied that the freeze has been ineffective'. In the last paragraph on page 2 of the statement the Minister stated:
Furthermore, I am concerned about Australians being prevented from fishing for southern bluefin when we have an agreement enabling Japanese fishermen to do so.

When there is an agreement with the Japanese fishermen and if there is any question of pressure the obvious thing to do is reduce the Japanese fleet and allow an equivalent number of Australian boats to take the place of the Japanese vessels. In my opinion that would be the prudent way to ensure that the industry develops. On the third page of the statement the Minister said:
I do not expect there to be any significant increase in the number of new vessels in the fishery.

At a meeting of the South Eastern Fisheries Committee on 25 November 1980 the industry's view was expressed by Mr Connell, the President of the Australian Fishing Industry Council. The minutes of that meeting state:

. . . Mr Connell expressed the view of industry that if there are no management measures imposed on the southern bluefin tuna fishery after 31 March 1981, there will be a dramatic increase in the number of vessels licensed for the fishery and consequent increase in effort which would in turn put pressure on other fisheries such as the south east trawl fishery. Both Dr Francois and Mr Wharton commented that they would be concerned to see any additional pressure placed on the trawl fishery.
In spite of that comment by an industry representative the Minister has stated:
I do not expect there to be any significant increase in the number of new vessels in the fishery.
The next sentence in the statement probably sums it all up. I would need some explanation from somebody to tell me what it means. It states:

New entrants, if any, will not be able to establish access rights under any future management regime on the same basis as fishermen who have operated in the fishery to date. Accordingly fishermen planning to enter the fishery should not base their expectations of profitability on taking southern bluefin tuna.

Earlier in the statement we were told the freeze had been lifted. I really do not understand how the two points of view can be expressed in the one document. In the last paragraph of the statement the Minister stated:

However I will require the South Eastern Fisheries Committee to immediately undertake a study of the tuna and trawl fisheries recommended in my Department's economic study and require it to report its conclusions to the Australian Fisheries Council in September.

I do not think it is improper for me to suggest that if it is so important that such a study should be undertaken it should have been undertaken and concluded before the freeze was lifted. I think it is quite inappropriate that this action should have been taken at this time bearing in mind the evidence that is currently available to us. I feel it is only right that I should express my concern about this matter. I am sure I speak for a considerable number of fishermen in South Australia, Victoria and New South Wales in particular who are heavily dependent on this fishery and associated fisheries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the motion moved by Senator Archer that the Senate take note of the statement I join him in expressing my concern at the contents of this statement. Senator Archer is the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce which at present has before it a reference which was referred to it by me 18 months ago in my capacity at that time as the secretary to the parliamentary Labor Party Caucus resources committee. I was the secretary to that committee for some five years. A good deal of concern had been expressed to the committee about the fishing industry as a whole in Australia. That was the reason the Opposition decided that the Senate Standing Committee should have a look at the Commonwealth's responsibility for the development of the Australian fishing industry. No doubt Senator Archer, as the Chairman of the Senate Committee, apart from his close contact with fishermen in Tasmania, is now the recipient of a good deal of correspondence by way of submissions expressing concern about this industry. I join him in expressing my concern that this freeze has been lifted before the meeting of the Australian Fisheries Council in September and also before the Senate Standing Committee on Trade and Commerce has been able to make a report on the subject to the Senate. I hope some answers, in line with Senator Archer's plea, will be forthcoming.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) agreed to:
That leave be given to introduce a Bill for an Act relating to joint sittings of the Parliament.
Bill presented, and read a first time.
Standing Orders suspended.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The purpose of this Bill is to amend three pieces of legislation to cover the Joint Sitting of the Senate and the House of Representatives which is to be held to choose a senator for the Australian Capital Territory in the place of the late Senator John Knight. The three Acts involved are the Evidence Act, the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act and the Parliamentary Papers Act. These three Acts were amended in 1974 in relation to the Joint Sitting of the Senate and the House of Representatives which was then held pursuant to section 57 of the Constitution. The amendments then made were limited to Joint Sittings pursuant to section 57 of the Constitution and do not apply in relation to the Joint Sitting to be held pursuant to the Senate (Representation of Territories) Act. That Act was amended last year to provide for the filling of a casual vacancy in respect of a senator from the Australian Capital Territory by the Senate and the House of Representatives.

The effect of the present Bill will be to extend the changes made in 1974 to cover any Joint Sitting of the Senate and the House of Representatives pursuant to an Act. The effect of the changes in relation to each of the three pieces of legislation concerned will be as follows: With regard to the Evidence Act, the effect of the amendment will be to provide for judicial notice of the signature of the officer presiding at a Joint Sitting held pursuant to an Act and to provide for copies of official records of proceedings of such a Joint Sitting to be admitted as evidence thereof. In relation to the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act, the effect of the amendment will be to provide authority for the broadcasting of a Joint Sitting held pursuant to an Act and to give protection against legal proceedings in respect of matters so broadcast. In referring to broadcasting, I intend also to cover the televising of a proceeding, since the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act was amended in 1974 to permit the televising of parliamentary proceedings. In relation to the Parliamentary Papers Act, the amendment now proposed would provide for authority for the publication of the proceedings of a Joint Sitting held pursuant to an Act and for protection against legal proceedings in respect of the publication of the proceedings of such a Joint Sitting by the Government Printer. The amendments are of a machinery nature, but it is desirable that the changes should be made before the Joint Sitting takes place next month. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gietzelt) adjourned.

Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I wish formally to protest, as we always do, at this action being taken by the Government. Once again, the Senate is being deprived of an opportunity to debate General Business effectively because of the Government's inefficiency in organising its own program. Tonight we are to deal with legislation which was introduced into the Senate only today and which in fact could have been introduced in plenty of time. In the last few weeks we have spent hours and hours waiting for Government legislation to be introduced. We have taken the opportunity to debate at length papers and reports, which we would not have done in normal circumstances. We have done so to co-operate with the Government, but here we have the Government, as it always does, bringing in controversial legislation at the last minute, demanding that that legislation be passed before a break, and depriving the Senate of the opportunity to discuss General Business. This situation is unsatisfactory. It has been so for the five or six years in which this Government has been in power. We will continue to protest on each occasion this is done. We realise that at the moment the numbers are such that we can do little about it. We realise also that, come July, we may well be able to do something about it. We intend to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I too voice my strong protest against the motion moved by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Senator Messner). If my colleague Senator Cavanagh were not at a very important meeting he too would be here to protest against the action of the Government. We now have to forgo General Business to allow the Government, led by Mr Fraser, to keep faith with Reg Ansett or Mr Murdoch, whoever is the owner of that airline. SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Grimes has said, the Government has had ample time in which to bring forward this legislation. Instead, it has brought it in at the last minute and taken away from all honourable senators-not only Opposition senators but also back-bench Government senators-an opportunity to speak on matters of General Business. I join with Senator Grimes, and I associate with this my colleague Senator Cavanagh, who unavoidably cannot be present, in placing on record our opposition to this action by the Government. No doubt it will not be the last occasion on which such action is taken.
