PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to enable the Commonwealth to provide loan guarantees for the purchase by Ansett Transport Industries Ltd of new front line Boeing aircraft to operate on the trunk network. The introduction of this Bill at this stage is required to enable Ansett to finalise the financial arrangements for the purchase of the new generation aircraft. The first aircraft is due for delivery in June 1981. The most significant initiative of this new, competitive era in domestic aviation is the decision by Ansett on the one hand and Trans-Australia Airlines on the other to acquire different front line wide-body aircraft. Trans-Australia Airlines was the first to announce its choice of a wide-bodied-type jet and orders have now been placed for five of the A300B Airbus, a proven and well accepted twin-engined aircraft which will carry approximately 270 passengers. Trans-Australia Airlines will also modify those of its DC9 aircraft which it is to retain to redesign the interiors to be compatible with its B727 aircraft.

Ansett, on the other hand, chose completely to restructure its fleet, and on 17 March last year announced its intention to acquire 21 Boeing aircraft, comprising five yet to be built B767 wide-body twin jets with a capacity of approximately 210 passengers; 12 B737-200 advanced twin jets; and four long range B727-200 tri jets. These aircraft are the subject of the Bill now before the Senate. Expenditure to acquire these aircraft and associated equipment is over $800m. Completion of delivery of the aircraft on order will not be until around 1985.

It was recently announced that the Government had taken an in-principle decision to establish TAA as a public company and had decided to establish an independent fare tribunal. The details are currently being considered. The Government proposes to bring before the Senate during this session an airlines agreement Bill which takes into account the Government's decisions on TAA and the tribunal. The Government has also decided to establish an inquiry into whether deregulation is a desirable long term objective. Having in mind that there will be new wide-bodied equipment and a new era of competition between the airlines over this period, with an inevitable impact upon the way in which our domestic airline system will operate in the 1980s, it is logical that time will be needed to make a full assessment of the impact of these changes. In any event, the last of the new aircraft will be delivered in 1984. Therefore, the inquiry will be asked to report within five years so that it can examine the question of deregulation against the experience of our two-airline system using this new equipment. I am confident that both TAA and Ansett will co-operate with the Government in these policy initiatives.

Deliveries of aircraft in respect of which loans will be guaranteed under this legislation will commence shortly, with the first of Ansett's B737s and TAA's A300 aircraft arriving in June. The second and third A300s will be introduced in mid-September and early November. At the same time, Ansett will progressively introduce the B727s between June and September, and the B737s between June 1981 and June 1982. The proposed delivery date of the first two B767 aircraft is November 1982. The Bill currently before the Senate is to introduce legislation to provide for the Treasurer, on behalf of the Commonwealth to furnish guarantees in respect of borrowings by a wholly-owned subsidiary of Ansett Transport Industries for the purchase of Ansett's 21 new Boeings and associated equipment and spares. Clause 4 empowers the Treasurer to guarantee the repayment of moneys borrowed, not exceeding $US490m, for the purchase of the aircraft and for related interest on that borrowing. Clause 5 provides that the Treasurer must be satisfied that the terms and conditions of the borrowing are reasonable, and provides that appropriate security be afforded to the Commonwealth. The Australian National Airlines Act already authorises the Treasurer to provide guarantees for TAA's borrowings. This Bill is consistent with the principle of according similar treatment in respect of guarantees to the airlines. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantees) Bill is to authorise the Treasurer, Mr Howard, to provide Commonwealth loan guarantees to Ansett Transport Industries Ltd and to an unnamed subsidiary of that company up to a limit of $490m. That is a most unusual course of action to which the Senate is being asked to give its approval and it is based upon the urgency criterion which this Government has placed upon this legislation. It is unprecedented, unnecessary, and is another indication of the will of the Executive being imposed upon the operations of the Senate. It makes a mockery of the attitude of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) during the fateful year of 1975 when he was trying to establish the principle that the Senate was a House of review, of independence and, therefore, capable of making independent judgments.

SPEECH.PARA: We are being forced to a guillotine, to a timetable in relation to this piece of legislation which is quite unsatisfactory in every shape or form from the point of view of the role of the Senate and the Australian people. The fact is that we are responding to the pressures of the Ansett organisation. It appears that we are following even more quickly in the wake of the new operators of that organisation. That is the way in which the Ansett organisation operated during the post-war years. I refer particularly to the Murdoch group which now not only wants to buy American presidents, newspapers, television stations and airlines but also obviously wants to buy governments and parliaments. Certainly it has bought the Australian Prime Minister who has given an undertaking-as was just mentioned by my colleague-that this piece of legislation would be rushed through the Parliament without any adequate explanation and without any proper consideration by the Senate operating as a House of review. It makes a mockery of the way in which the Parliament operates.

These guarantees enable Ansett Transport Industries to conclude a purchase arrangement for 21 new Boeing aircraft which will be programmed for delivery between June 1981 and late 1985. The 12 Boeing 737 series aircraft which are being purchased are old technology. They are noisy aircraft. This will exacerbate the noise and pollution problems at some of our airports and particularly at Mascot. Therefore, the Government's approval for the import of these aircraft strikes out the major recommendations of the Government's Major Airport Needs of Sydney Committee otherwise known as the MANS Committee. That Committee recommended that new technology, quiet, wide-bodied aircraft should be introduced during the 1980s to replace the smaller and noisier aircraft currently in use. Whilst the Government is critical of the New South Wales Government which does not want to extend Mascot airport and is insisting upon the construction of a second airport in Sydney, the Australian Labor Party is being criticised for the concern it has shown in that area. People living around the Sydney airport have expressed their views to the New South Wales Government. In the dying hours of this period of sitting of Parliament the Government has introduced a piece of legislation, which was incorporated and not even read and which was introduced into the House of Representatives only a few days ago. It is using its numbers to force the legislation through the Senate today. This, of course, is another example of the complete hypocrisy of the Fraser Government.

The provision of Australian Government guarantees to Ansett and Trans-Australia Airlines in respect of loans raised abroad to purchase new passenger aircraft is a basic feature of the two-airline policy. This Bill makes a mockery of the so-called rebellion that was in the Government ranks about the two-airline agreement. Similar guarantees have been provided to Ansett Transport Industries Ltd on 21 occasions since 1966-67 and to TAA on one occasion, and that was last year. As at 31 December 1980 the Commonwealth contingent liability in respect of loans raised overseas stood at $US57.2m for Ansett and at $US34m for TAA.

Traditionally airlines equipment loan guarantee Bills have not been objected to by the Opposition. In the past we have given our assent to them in accordance with the established policies of the Parliament. As the two-airline agreement had been agreed to we were prepared to put into effect the legislative factors relating to that agreement. However, in view of the grave and exceptional circumstances associated with this Bill I will move on behalf of the Opposition at a later stage that consideration of the legislation be postponed. I understand that copies of the amendment are currently being distributed to honourable senators. Before dealing with the Bill I propose to comment on some of the statements that have been made by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) in the other place. We have to rely on those statements because we have not been shown the courtesy of being provided with a copy of the second reading speech in this place.

The Minister reaffirmed that the Government had decided to transform Trans-Australia Airlines into a public company. Senator Collard, who on several occasions has taken issue with me, will now perhaps agree with the criticism of the Opposition because the proposal has been reaffirmed in the second reading speech. I can appreciate, of course, that he was not aware of that. He probably would not have been reading the speeches made in the other House. There is no doubt now that the Government intends to sell all or part of TAA to its wealthy friends and to stock exchange speculators. The Labor Party regards TAA as an innovative and successful public enterprise. It has been hobbled as a result of the pressures by the Ansett organisation over the years. We will be having a lot more to say about that in the ensuing months. The sale of TAA would rob the 90 per cent of Australians who do not hold shares in public companies of their ownership of this famous airline. This valuable national asset is a symbol of public enterprise achievement and national spirit. Its sale, therefore, to private enterprise would constitute, in our view, gross misappropriation of public property. The Australian Labor Party will resist its sale at every opportunity.

The Minister used his second reading speech as a subterfuge to announce that an inquiry would be conducted at some time between now and 1986. Heaven only knows why he selected that year because it is at least two elections away. In his speech to the House of Representatives he said that the deregulation of the airline industry was desirable in the long term. By making that announcement in the late part of the evening he hoped to prevent parliamentary response on a matter which ought properly to have been the subject of a special statement and special debate in the Parliament. It is now evident that following a threatened rebellion in the Government caucus against this Bill last Thursday-I remind honourable senators that a week later the Government is ramming this Bill through the Senate-a deal was concluded to establish an inquiry into airline deregulation if the rebels would support this measure. That is the shady, shoddy deal that has been entered into. These so-called rebels of the Government who insisted upon deregulation of the industry have been conned into believing that such an inquiry will take place some time between 1981 and 1986.

Of course, the poor, hapless, embattled and, some might even say, hopeless Minister for Transport told the Government caucus that the Bill concerned the purchase of one aircraft only. Subsequently, he had to be advised, because he did not even know, that there would be a purchase of 21 aircraft. That is what this legislation is about. The rebels in the caucus were jubilant when the Minister conceded that he would have an inquiry into deregulation. Surely it must be obvious to those members who claim to be rebels, who claim to have a different philosophical position to that of the Government, that their victory was a hollow one. They have been fooled and conned again by the Fraser Administration. The inquiry in the form outlined is a sop to those gullible back bench rebels.

The Minister, in announcing the inquiry last Thursday evening, could not even tell the House who would conduct it, when it would be conducted, where it would be held, what its terms of reference might or might not be or even when it would commence. Then he had the audacity to suggest that it would faithfully report back to the Parliament some time before that magical 1986-if by some mischance this Government were to be returned at the next election. That is something beyond the power of the Government. The servile attitude of the Government to the proprietors of Ansett has been shown so many times and has certainly been apparent in the announcement of this inquiry.

The Minister told the House that he was confident that TAA and Ansett would co-operate despite the almost unlimited legislative powers that he has to require both airlines to supply all relevant financial and operational information. Honourable senators will recall that the Minister made a similar statement when the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares was announced. The record shows that his confidence on that occasion was misplaced. Ansett did not co-operate or make a substantive submission except to advise the Government to sell TAA. How willingly has the Government taken up that piece of advice.

Let us turn to the Bill that is before us. The manner in which the legislation has been approved by the Government caucus and presented to the Parliament for urgent passage is surely a matter of grave public concern. The Bill that we are discussing comes as a result of brawling amongst government members following the complete and utter collapse of the Government's aviation policy. That surely is acknowledged even by those who will be prepared to assist the Executive, the Cabinet, in using the forms of the Senate to force this Bill through this evening. We now have a situation in which the Government's aviation policy is being determined day by day or, as a colleague said when he was debating this matter in the other place, on the hour by the hour.

This Bill is being handled by a Minister who did not know how many aircraft were involved in the purchase and who, I am satisfied, does not appreciate fully the implications of the legislation. The proposed guarantee of the $US490m borrowing for Ansett involves the largest amount ever sought by any airline in this country's history. In the circumstances Parliament should have been given full information on the loans to be guaranateed and the purchase for which they were to be applied. Unlike previous loan guarantee Bills the Ansett subsidiary concerned with these guarantees is not named. Surely the Parliament is entitled to know that.

Here we are setting aside the debate on the freedom of information legislation that was scheduled for today. In this piece of legislation we are not told what the unnamed subsidiary is. Why the secrecy? Why can we not be told? Why can it not be indicated in the legislation itself? It ought to have been specified in the provisions of the Bill. Clause 4 of the Bill stipulates that the proceeds of the loans raised by Ansett are to be used for the purchase of 21 aircraft itemised and related spare parts and equipment. However, most interestingly in the publicity associated with the provisions of the United States Export-Import Bank loans to Ansett is the reference to the provision of an amount of money totalling $US34.2m for purposes related to publicity and other matters. What does that mean? What explanation has the Government about that? Has the Caucus of the Government parties been told what that means, or are they prepared to sit idly by and cop what the Executive directs? I will come back to that subject a little later.

Clause 5 sets out the conditions of the guarantees to be provided. It gives the Minister extensive powers which the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares highlighted that the Minister had failed to exercise in the past. He failed to exercise extensive powers over the financial accounts of Ansett and its subsidiaries. Here we have another example of three reputable men who are making certain recommendations as a result of their appointment to the committee. They are giving advice to the Government and that advice is set aside. Let us get it clear and on the record that we do not like what the Government is doing and we do not like the pressure that is being exerted on the Government by the Ansett organisation. It is not right in the United States either. The Ansett loans affair has become a matter of great notoriety, great publicity and great concern even in the United States of America. There the Congress is prepared to exercise its proper powers. It is regrettable that an Australian company should be the subject of such notoriety in the United States Press, such attention, concern and activity by United States Government agencies, especially as it is a company which depends so much upon the legislative decisions and protection of the Australian Parliament for its financial success. It cannot operate without our guarantee.

A series of loans to Ansett Transport Industries from the United States Export-Import Bank-Eximbank-is involved in this legislation. Yet most of the Minister's second reading speech was devoted to matters not relevant to the Bill. He did not even bother to tell the House of Representatives what it is all about, any more than the Minister did in this place when he had the speech incorporated in Hansard. The second reading speech makes no mention of the individual loans or the series of loans involved. The Minister did not provide any advice to the Parliament of the public concern and investigations in the United States. He gave us no explanations whatsoever about the manner in which the Eximbank loans were arranged or about the proceeds of those loans. We are asked to put our signatures on a blank cheque. There is concern in the United States Congress from both sides of American politics, about these matters. There certainly would be much public concern about the way in which the Murdoch empire was able to exercise its influence in respect of the November 1980 elections for the Presidency of that country. Yet the only concern that is being expressed in this Parliament is coming from the Australian Labor Party. However, when I look at the list of speakers I gather that members of this Parliament, other than Government members, are equally concerned about this whole issue.

A patently false statement by the Prime Minister was referred to by one of my colleagues a few moments before I started to speak. Last Friday the Prime Minister proclaimed that this legislation must be passed before Easter. Why? Are Government members or the Minister going to tell us why this legislation must be passed before Easter? Is it to get the Murdoch group off the hook in the United States by having some imprimatur from this Parliament? Are we being used as a rubber stamp? Is that what is involved? One is entitled to draw that conclusion because no explanation is given to the Parliament. Yet, the Prime Minister, who claims to support the principles of parliamentery democracy, makes these statements not to the Parliament, either in the House of Representatives or through his spokesman in this place, but in fact on television. I quote from a transcript of his Press conference. In my view it does not read correctly but it is what the Prime Minister said. The transcript reads:

We have to get this legislation through before Easter, because the guarantees are needed. The Ansett group, in fulfilling that loan with the Eximbank and we are not prepared to run the risk of going over the time scales in relation to that because that would probably force Ansett into a renegotiation with Exim. That would have all sorts of complications and difficulties which nobody would want.

Certainly Mr Fraser would not want that situation to arise and certainly Mr Murdoch would not want it, but maybe the Australian people and the Australian Parliament want it. Maybe the American Government and the American people want to know a little more about the money that is so freely given outside the normal channels of international finance to an organisation which is under an investigation of some importance in the United States. The people of Australia are likely to be locked into a guarantee for almost $US500m and they will very much want to know, as we want to know, what complications and difficulties are associated with the Eximbank loan being made to Ansett Transport Industries. In those few words the Prime Minister took the course-we do not say this lightly-of concealing what is a very serious issue in the United States, an issue to which this Government does not want to address itself. In other words, it wants to protect an organisation that even within the heartland of American capitalism is in some sort of trouble and under some investigation.

I ask the Prime Minister and the Minister representing the Minister for Transport (Senator Messner) to elaborate to this Parliament and to the people of Australia on the complications and difficulties about which the Prime Minister has expressed so much concern in terms that he does not want to risk a renegotiation of the loan. Why is that? Are we not entitled to this information? Surely those members of the Government who speak so eloquently when it comes to the question of access to information would share our concern about knowing what is in the mind of the Ansett organisation and what is in the mind of the Prime Minister but is not in the knowledge of the Parliament. I remind the Minister and those honourable senators who sit opposite that they are sent here by the people of Australia exactly to exercise consideration of these matters. They are sent here to protect the interests of the Australian people, not to protect the interests of the Government's wealthy backers in private commerce.

It is interesting to note that in his second reading speech the Minister for Transport-and the Minister representing the Minister for Transport in this place, but I cannot blame him because his words are the words of the Minister he represents-very carefully refrained from mentioning the Eximbank loan. Here we have the Prime Minister talking about it outside the Parliament and the Minister in the Parliament saying not a word. In what sort of degenerative state are the parliamentary processes of this country? Thank God that, as from 1 July, that situation will stop, at least in this place. Explanations will be demanded and explanations will be given, otherwise the Government will not be able to pass its legislation. I am sure that will be the view of the majority of honourable senators.

The Minister has made no mention of any urgency or deadline for the provisions of the guarantees. No evidence has been provided to the Parliament that there is a deadline to meet, nor has there been mention of anything to support what the Prime Minister said last Friday night at his Press conference. Obviously these matters have been the subject of discussion and debate over the dinner table or over the telephone because we all know that people associated with that organisation-and with other organisations, for that matter-have been wining and dining with the Prime Minister and other Ministers in the last several weeks. There was some sort of deal arrangement worked out which, of course, is very repugnant to those people who believe in the democratic process and that the Parliament is supposed to exercise some responsibility. What do we get? We get absolutely no information because the matter has been worked out in some shady, shoddy deal over the dinner table with the Prime Minister. The evidence that is publicly available indicates the opposite of what the Prime Minister said. In fact, the Prime Minister in rushing this Bill through is seeking to protect Ansett in its difficulties in the United States of America. Can the Minister deny that? Can the Government deny that? It is a very serious allegation that we have made. Let us hear what the Government has to say about it.

Obviously the Prime Minister wants to give Ansett Transport Industries' loan application added status by providing that company with Australian Government guarantees before the current United States investigations into the whole circumstances of the Eximbank loans are completed. Obviously the Prime Minister wants to say to the Ansett leadership-the people who after all organised the stock exchange raid on the original Ansett organisation only a year or so ago when this Government refused to help Sir Reginald Ansett and allowed the coup to take place: 'What are you arguing about and questioning? These loans have already received the legislative approval of the Australian Government. There could not possibly be anything wrong, otherwise the Australian Parliament would not have given its assent to the legislation and would not have approved of the manner in which these loans were obtained.' We say that this is just not good enough.

Around this issue there is a stench arising from the manner in which the Bill has been presented to the Parliament and rushed through. There is a stench arising from the failure of the Minister for Transport to inform the Parliament as to the questionable circumstances associated with Eximbank loans to Ansett Transport Industries. There is a stench arising from the persistent preferential treatment accorded this airline by this Government and a stench which obviously is being examined by the United States Senate itself. There is a stench arising from the relationship between this Government and the proprietors of Ansett Airlines, and the Ansett Press, which is now a powerful part of the Fourth Estate.

There is a smell of corruption hanging over the whole Ansett loans affairs. That is obvious if one reads the reports available as a result of the investigations in the United States. The course that this Government is proposing to follow may even be illegal; it is certainly immoral and certainly illogical. The Australian Treasury has very strict regulations covering loans and Commonwealth guarantees for loans. Can the Minister for Transport really tell this Parliament that he is proposing to adopt a procedure to guarantee loans by the people of Australia-loans of almost $500m which are presently under active federal investigation in the country in which they have been made-without even waiting for the preliminary report of investigations in the United States? Is this a legal, responsible and proper way for the Parliament to operate? On 25 March this year Senator Proxmire of the United States Senate Banking Committee asked Eximbank to suspend the Ansett loans until the high-powered United States General Accounting Office had completed its investigation into the terms of the Boeing sale to Ansett. Senator Proxmire stated:
I believe the public interest required that upon completion of the General Accounting Office Report Exim--
That is the bank-
re-examine the loans to determine whether approval or denial is the appropriate course of action.

The remarks of Senator Heinz are most significant as he is now in the majority party in the Senate and Chairman of the Sub-committee of International Finance. He joined Senator Proxmire in calling for a review of the loan. He said that the Eximbank board would be well advised to honour Senator Proxmire's request. He added:
I think it would be a good idea for the new chairman to look at the whole Ansett financing arrangement.

This is the kind of discussion that has been taking place in the United Sates, where these loans are being raised and provided at a major cost to the United States taxpayers. In this Parliament, under this Government, this Prime Minister and this Minister for Transport, there has not been one word, whisper or even suggestion of that. There has only been an assertion by the Prime Minister outside of the parliamentary processes that some sort of phantom deadline has to apply. The Prime Minister was really saying: 'Let us get this legislation through quickly. Let us make Ansett look better in the light of these investigations. Let us not talk about any of the problems or difficulties associated with the legislation'.

On 31 March, only a week ago, the Eximbank in the United States deferred to a future date approval of the $US289m loan to Ansett. The American Government has set the matter aside. The Government with which the Australian Government claims to have a close philosophical position and alliance has taken that extraordinary step. We have heard nothing from the Government in our country. The public record shows that the Eximbank loans to Australia are currently under investigation by the United States Senate Banking Committee and the powerful General Accounting Office, to which I have already referred. That organisation is even more powerful in the American set-up than the Auditor-General in Australia or the Joint Committe of Public Accounts of this Parliament. The General Accounting Office is reportable to the United States Legislature. The loans are also under investigation by the administrative officers of Eximbank and the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

Are we not lightly passing over the seriousness of this issue? Would any Government senator come before this parliament and suggest, if we had a situation where the public accounts section of our Parliament was saying such a thing in respect of some major issue, that we should nevertheless ignore it and push the legislation through? Of course not. The Fraser Government is notorious for its behaviour in respect of matters of public morality. Let us look at what the Australian Broadcasting Commission's AM program reported on 26 March of this year. It said:

The American Justice Department has announced that the FBI is to begin investigating the circumstances surrounding the $200m loan to Ansett from America's Export Import Bank. The new complaint comes from the Public Integrity Section within the Justice Department and its spokesman, Mr John Russell, said that the FBI agents in particular would be probing whether politics had played a part in the granting of the Ansett loan.

Does that not make a mockery of what we were discussing today in relation to Senator Carrick's involvement and the Government's involvement in the Government Information Unit? Government supporters seem to have a different interpretation of politics, morality, probity and integrity. They switched one person from the staff of the Unit to somewhere else. That person is catered for in the establishment of the organisation but he is not doing the job. That is a play on semantics and an indication of the way in which this Government handles the taxpayers' money in this country. Public funds are involved in the Ansett loan in the United States. At least the American Congress, with all its weaknesses through having an extremist such as President Reagan running the affairs of the country, has set itself the objective of trying to establish some integrity and probity in its relationships when loans are granted to international commercial organisations. Again I refer to the AM report. It concluded:
Never before--
I stress this statement-
has the American Congress approved legislation or a joint resolution to try to deny one of the American bank's foreign loans.

Here we have a situation which is so serious that the American Congress, which has more conservatives than the Australian Parliament but which, nevertheless, has established some basis of integrity and morality, is prepared to do something about examining what it conceives to be a stinking mess. But nothing has happened in this country. There was paralysis because this Government, this Prime Minister and the people who sit on the other side of the Parliament know who their political masters are. They are captives of the proprietors of Ansett Airlines and the Murdoch Press. It is significant, as I have mentioned earlier, that Senator Heinz joined Senator Proxmire in expressing concern about the Ansett loan. A bipartisan decision was reached by two senators-they were from opposing sides of the political spectrum-who were members of the Committee which examined this matter.

That was a rare feat, we submit to the Senate. There are occasions on which we do reach common ground in this place. But, of course, pressure is exerted, is it not, upon those few senators on the other side who are not prepared to toe the party line, who are not prepared to be intimidated by the Executive and who have the courage from time to time to express an opinion substantially different from the majority view in the party? For that I give them great credit because I know how difficult it is in the party system to stand outside one's party position. I know how difficult it is on some issues to have a minority viewpoint, to express that viewpoint and to vote for it. I give those people top marks for doing so. All I am suggesting is that they should be consistent and do the same in respect of this piece of legislation. This is more important than establishing the co-called principles of freedom of information. This is an example of information being denied the Parliament.

If two men from different sides of the American political spectrum can come together as, indeed, people have on occasions in this place-it happens very rarely in the other place but it happens occasionally in this place-we have to look at why we are being forced to deal with this legislation. We have to look at the integrity of the men in the United States because they are men who have a great deal of support and who are recognised as being men of high integrity in the United States Senate. Their credentials cannot be challenged by anybody, least of all by the Prime Minister of this country. Their credentials are very highly regarded not only in the Senate of the United States but also by the United States people. But in Australia, in contrast-in secret, in some sort of shady deal-the Australian Prime Minister wants to force the Senate into being subservient to the whims of the Executive.

The Prime Minister has sought to gloss over the grave questions raised in the United States Senate on the Ansett loan. Of course, the poor, hapless Minister for Transport does not want to know about it. He does not even talk about it or recognise it. He hopes it will go away and he does not want to debate it. He cannot even get the number of aircraft right when he has to put the matter to those in his party room. Both the Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport have embarked on a process of guaranteeing substantial loans-the highest ever to come before the Parliament-the very probity and legality of which have been called into the most serious question by senior legislators in the United States Senate. That legislature at least has the public courage, integrity and determination to demand answers to the same questions that we are demanding the Government to answer today. I am now asking the Parliament, the Senate and honourable senators opposite to have the courage to support our proposal to defer approval of the loan until satisfactory answers are forthcoming. Very shortly I will be moving an amendment along those lines.

I ask those honourable senators opposite who have integrity-I believe a great number of them who have integrity must be concerned about this piece of legislation and must be asking why this information is not forthcoming-to support the Opposition in a reasonable proposal to defer consideration of this matter until the outcome of the United States investigations is known. Is that an unreasonable proposition? Is that a revolutionary proposition and one which is so unparliamentary that it cannot be given serious consideration? It is a matter about which another government has expressed serious concern. Can we not take some recognition of its views and say: 'Well, yes, that is a proposition of the Opposition?' Government senators could say: 'We may not agree with the Opposition but it has put forward a prima facie case'. If there were any semblance of democracy in this place or any decency in the Government ranks, the Government would seriously consider our proposal for the postponement of this legislation, not for months or years, but until the United States Senate has completed its investigations.

It is incredible that Senator Carrick should say that politics should not enter into the matter and that we, as politicians, should not want to talk about politics. Of course politics are involved in the Ansett loan. We want to know whether improper politics have been involved or whether improper influence has been brought to bear. Bribes and corruption have been synonymous with commercial enterprises in many other countries. No one has denied that Mr Tanaka in Japan resigned his position because he received bribes from an aircraft manufacturer. No one has denied that senior members of the Italian Parliament have been forced out because of their acceptance of money from unsavoury sources. Political parties, particularly those on the Right, such as the Christian Democrats have been bribed and sponsored by funds from the United States. Yet the United States thinks that this matter in its very homeland, ought to be investigated.

If Government honourable senators and honourable members do not agree with our proposal it will mean one thing, that is that they are prepared to disregard the decisions of the United States senators, the Senate committees concerned, the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the many other agencies that I have mentioned. The Prime Minister and the Minister for Transport would be prepared to risk the Government's liability. After all, that is what this debate is about. The Government is to guarantee loans to the tune of $500m in case there is some breakdown or reason for the loans not being met. We are being asked to act as guarantors to the tune of $500m. This Government claims to represent all the people. It is taking steps to cut back on a whole range of social programs. Yet in one go it is prepared to underwrite $500m for Mr Murdoch, Sir Peter Abeles and those associated with the Ansett organisation. Those people are not prepared to put up their own money. They want the guarantee of the Parliament. They want members of Parliament, elected to represent the interests of the Australian people, to give their assent blithely. Of course, Opposition senators will probably be accused by Government senators of procrastinating, not being fair dinkum or trying to make political capital because we are asking the questions which my colleague asked in the House of Representatives to which he did not get answers. I am sure that we will not get answers in this place.

Where are the men and women opposite with the integrity and stature of Senator Proxmire and Senator Heinz who are prepared to elevate public accountability above cronyism and favouritism to their wealthy friends and political masters in the Government? One of these gentlemen is a supporter of the American President-he is a member of his party. The senators are supporters of American capitalism. They are certainly not radicals or people who believe that labour should have more supremacy than the power of capital in market forces and the struggles that occur in that area. They are men of tremendous courage and integrity. Their words ought to be listened to with a great deal of interest. If any Government senators are as concerned as we are I invite them as people of integrity to join the Opposition and support my amendment.

Of course we concede that there is no certainty as to the outcome of the United States investigations. The United States Senate might well give its approval for the loan, but it might cancel it. The loan could be endorsed, or the door could be closed. It could make a number of decisions. Many options are available. But one of those options may well cause us to be financially responsible. Not only members of the Opposition but also members of the Australian Democrats, the Liberal Party and the National Country Party and the Independents all have a responsibility in this matter. We may be proven wrong; we concede that. But I think that there is sufficient doubt about this whole issue to say that the public interest has to be protected by ensuring that we do not enter into liability for an agreement that could be found subsequently to be faulty and illegal. It would be utterly irresponsible, wrong and immoral, to pass the Bill before us into law without the benefit of the result of those inquiries and decisions of the United States legislature.

I have shown that there is no deadline for the legislation. I have shown that serious matters are being questioned in the United States. I have shown that there are serious allegations as to the propriety of the loans and the manner in which they were negotiated. I have pointed out that since the elections in the United States last year the incoming majority party in the Senate has taken up the question of the propriety in these matters. In all of these circumstances, I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'Consideration of the Bill be postponed pending the outcome of inquiries being conducted in the United States of America by the Senate Banking Committee, the General Accounting Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the circumstances of the United States Export-Import Bank loans to Ansett Transport Industries Ltd and its subsidiary'.
I commend the amendment to the Senate, and I hope the Senate will give it consideration.

TALK.START.PARA: —I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -When I was a student, recalcitrant school boys, instead of reading Lorna Doone or Julius Caesar, read the works of an author by the name of Edgar Wallace. He was the great mystery writer of his day. May I suggest that we now have a great mystery writer in the Senate-Senator Gietzelt. I am quite sure that with his fertile imagination he could make twice or three times the money outside the Senate that he is getting here. He has read mysteries that I never knew existed into what is a pro forma Bill similar to those which we pass many times a year when the airlines want to buy new pieces of equipment.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator has berated the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) for a slip of the tongue. Anybody with common sense knows that the loan is a packet loan intended to buy a whole heap of aircraft. Of course, the Minister made a slip of the tongue and said one aircraft, but he corrected that slip. Who does not make a slip of the tongue? Sometimes we regret it. The plain and simple reason why this Bill has to be in place by early May is the fact that the delivery date of the first aircraft is June, or July at the latest. It is as simple as that. There is no basic mystery. We have done this time and again, and--

TALK.START.PARA: —There is an inquiry.

—Sure there is an inquiry, but it is none of our confounded business. If the United States Government wants to go on with an inquiry, so be it. It is a sovereign country. It is none of our business what it does. It is quite at liberty to do it. All we are doing is passing the same sort of legislation that we have passed on previous occasions to allow Ansett Transport Industries Ltd or Qantas Airways Ltd or Trans-Australia Airlines to buy aircraft. We guarantee the loans. It is as simple as that.
—Do you suggest that we do not therefore have some liability in respect of those? What happens if the loans fall through?

—We cross that bridge when we come to it. Obviously, if the loan falls through this legislation then becomes null and void because it refers only to that loan. It is as simple as that. I do find myself in some sort of agreement with Senator Gietzelt about the type of aircraft that Ansett wants to buy. As well as the new 767 it is buying 737 and 727 aircraft which are old generation aircraft, although the 727 is probably the most successful commercial aircraft that has been manufactured. I think that probably close to 1,700 have been manufactured and are in service now. They have old generation jets on them-Pratt and Whitney JT8D. I am not sure what arrangements Ansett has made but in my discussions with representatives from the Boeing organisation late in 1979 it was indicated that the Rolls Royce RB211-535 engine which is being manufactured for the 757 aircraft can also go under the wing of the 737 aircraft. I do not know whether Ansett has that in mind but it could certainly make the 737 a better aircraft.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as the noise around Sydney goes, I think it is quite significant that the New South Wales Government has broken off all negotiations with the Federal Government on the updating of Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport. The New South Wales Government will not even suggest to the Federal Government where a new airport should be. I do not mind because when the skies around Sydney get clogged and our new airport in Brisbane is operating we will get more international tourist traffic. The noise is quite significant. My understanding of the situation from surveys carried out is that about 80 per cent of the people living within the noise footprint of Sydney airport have moved there since the operation of jet aircraft began. Of course, the first jet aircraft were the noisiest. As we get into the new generation jets, even though they are bigger aircraft, they have far quieter engines and are far more tolerant. It is quite significant that about 80 per cent of people living in that area have moved there since jet aircraft have been introduced. I suppose it is conceivable that one of the reasons they moved there was the fact that people wanted to move out because of the noise and so houses could be bought cheaply. I suppose the old phrase caveat emptor is valid in that particular instance.

I would like to spend some time referring to the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares and to all the discussions that led up to it. As I have said on many occasions in this House, in about 1974 it was recognised that there was an inequity on the long haul routes. Since that particular time this Government has been trying to right that inequity. Indeed, it has done so by moving the flagfall up at a greater rate than the distance component. Since that has been going on we have had a fair internal airfare campaign which has taken place in Western Australia. That campaign has put tremendous pressure on our colleagues from Western Australia-pressure the likes of which some of us probably have not seen before. The fact that these colleagues of ours have realised that they had to succumb to that pressure and carry the campaign to this Parliament is now history. I hope that we do not see that sort of situation happening too often. It raises an interesting question. We have probably never seen before such a well orchestrated and well organised campaign to apply such massive pressure. One obviously questions the motives of such pressure and one wonders where the money came from for such a well orchestrated campaign. Obviously that question is going through the minds of many serious thinking people.

We have reached the situation today where the public is rightfully concerned and perhaps a little bewildered. It wonders what the heck is going on. This can be attributed to the massive Press reports, particularly those which appeared in the Western Australian Press, those which have been carried over here, those which have referred to what has occurred in this Parliament and those which have referred to what has gone on in many meetings behind locked doors. We have tried to wend our way through the ticklish situation to try to ensure that justice is done on the long haul routes and to see whether there was justice in any of the claims made. Unfortunately, as I said earlier, the public is concerned when, in reality, there is no basic need to be greatly concerned because Australia has probably the best, certainly one of the most efficient, cheapest and safest internal air transport systems in the world, particularly when we consider the conditions which exist in Australia. I have mentioned previously that Australia has a small population. Our land area is about the size of the United States but our population density is about one-fourteenth of the population of the United States. What makes it worse is that, if my memory serves me correctly, 70 per cent of our population lives within 35 kilometres of the coast. That means that we do not have the best conditions in the world in which to provide good air services to most of those people. Yet we manage to do that with one of the best airline systems in the world. Currently, because of the fracas raised by the group of people behind the internal air fare campaign, the public is concerned and bewildered about our airline system. I submit that it is unnecessarily concerned and bewildered. By what criteria do we judge our airlines? I suppose the best way is to look at some of the airlines around the world. I refer to a table of comparable Australian and United States fares, which I think has been circulated and which I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not read the whole of the preamble to the table because it is there for those who are interested to see. The source of the United States fares is the February 1981 North American edition of the official airline guide. The significant thing about the table is that, no matter which stage length one looks at, the Australian economy air fares as of last week were below the comparable United States air fares. Of course, we have to have a standard to consider. I know that there are discounts. There are discounts in the United States and there are discounts in Australia, but the economy fare is the standard that is usually considered. Honourable senators will notice from the table that, whichever stage one looks at, our previous air fares were below the current United States air fares. As a result of the last fare increase, fares for journeys of up to about 470 kilometres have been raised above the lowest United States economy fare, and for distances above that the fare is further lowered than the United States equivalent. By that criterion alone Australian airlines stand up fairly well.

SPEECH.PARA: It is significant that, when talking about the Sydney-Perth air fare, nobody as yet has cited the rail fare. The economy rail fare is currently $264. The rail fare has generally been looked upon as the benchmark by which people judge fares. The air fare is now $253.70. It was $268.10 which put it about $4.10 above the rail fare prior to the latest fare adjustment. But the economy air fare is now lower than the economy rail fare. That is another comparison to give us an idea of how long-haul passengers have been treated. I do not know why there is such a hang-up about Perth-Sydney or Perth-Melbourne fares. I do not think Sydney or Melbourne is the centre of the earth, let alone the centre of Australia, but apparently people in the West look at them in that way. I guess that isolation, in this day of quick communications and transport, can be a state of mind. It would probably take a person longer to travel from Winton to Sydney than to travel from Perth to Sydney. That person would have to change planes three times or trains three times. People in the West like to feel that they are part of Australia, but the isolation is not all that it has been painted. When people make comparisons they are always selective. They do not always compare like with like. I refer now to the second table that I have had circulated and ask that that also be incorporated. It examines holiday package deals.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. We often hear the story that it is cheaper to fly from Perth to Bali than it is to fly from Perth to Sydney. That is usually a selective quote, because one can always get a cheap holiday package from Perth to Bali, but it is normally compared with the economy fare from Perth to Sydney. Let me refer those honourable senators who are looking at that table to the details of the Perth to Bali flight. The figures given are those which would apply if one walked into the office of a travel agent and asked for the cheapest holiday package between the named centres, on the understanding that meals would not be included and that the apartment or motel room would be shared. The cost of a trip from Perth to Bali and a stay of seven nights, as offered by Garuda Aeroworld Tour Wholesalers, is $488. The distance involved is 2,579 kilometres. The cost of a flight from Perth to Coolangatta-a distance of 3,963 kilometres-and a TAA Take 7 Holiday would be $480. It is a round trip over a distance which exceeds that from Perth to Bali by 2,700 kilometres but it is $8 cheaper. The cost of the Ansett Well-Earned Holiday, also for seven nights, which involves a journey from Perth to Coolangatta, is $508, or $20 more than the cost of the Perth to Bali holiday.

SPEECH.PARA: I invite honourable senators to consider the distance involved in one or two other examples. The Melbourne-New Zealand package offered by Jetset Tours, which involves six nights and a distances of 2,632 kilometres, costs $498. The Adelaide to Whitsunday Village TAA Take 7 Wanderers' Paradise Holiday involves seven nights and a distance of 2,712 kilometres, and costs $459. Therefore, I submit that if we are to be fair in examining air fares or package deals we should compare like with like. Let us not compare a package deal with a normal air fare; let us compare package deal with package deal. Australia's airlines are not doing too bad a job when it comes to providing holiday package deals for the Australian traveller.

I turn now to the Holcroft report. Now that we have had a look at it and have seen the first implementation of its recommendations and their impact on Australian air fares, I wish to say that their effect has been rather disastrous. I say to the Government: 'Stop right here and now; let us not go any futher; let us look at what we have done already'. As far as I am concerned, we have gone too far in meeting the problems presented by the longhaul route. I and my colleagues from Queensland have been criticised because we have not supported the Holcroft findings. I have not done so for very deliberate reasons. I expressed my reservations about the report in this chamber but it was necessary to wait until one saw what the effect of the air fare formula would be before one could say anything really serious about it. We wanted to see justice done on the longhaul routes. Thus, we have said nothing until this point of time, certainly by way of supporting the proposal.

One of the reasons I have not supported it is that, even though in Queensland we have long distances, they are made up of a lot of short haul routes, which are our main tourist routes. This is happening just at a time when Qantas, in answering what for many of us has been a dream for a long time, is beginning to operate in and out of Townsville direct flights to and from Honolulu and the west coast of the United States. The routes that are most used by passengers travelling on to our tourist venues are Townsville-Cairns, Townsville-Proserpine, Townsville-Mackay or, if people come in through Brisbane, Brisbane-Rockhampton and then on to Keppel Island or Mackay. They travel the very routes that are now to be seriously affected by the interim implementation of the Holcroft report. So I say here and now: Let us stop; let us not go any further. Let us look at this thing. One of the recommendations that the Government has accepted is that an independent fares tribunal be set up. Let us look at that suggestion before we go any further. Now that we in Queensland are being disadvantaged, I raise this question: What if the Queensland members and senators rebelled and resorted to holding the Government to ransom, or to pressurising it or blackmailing it, or whatever term one might like to use? The whole situation in this Government would then become untenable. So I am saying: Just stop right here and now.

Of course, the Holcroft report made much ado about cross-subsidisation. Basically, I have no quarrel with cross-subsidisation, within limits. There is probably not a firm or a government statutory corporation that does not in one way or another cross-subsidise. We cannot iron it out completely. As I said, we did recognise that there was an inequality here and I think it is wrong that long haul passengers, because of the distance they have to travel and the certain amount of isolation involved, albeit with modern transport and communications, should be cross-subsidising those on the east coast. But there is room for cross-subsidisation.

Let us look at what has happened since the fare increase last Thursday. The third table to which I will refer-I have circulated copies of it-is a bit more complex. I checked with Hansard last night that it could be incorporated and I now seek leave to incorporate it before I speak to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The purpose of this is to establish a basis on which we can look at what the Holcroft recommendations are currently doing and what they ultimately will do to air fares in Australia. For the purpose of the experiment, this table had been drawn up. It is a notional table; I guess one cannot do it any other way. I want honourable senators to imagine that, say, Trans-Australia Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia had folded or that all of a sudden we had an increase in population and we were setting up an airline, and we wanted to look at what the fare structure would do and how it would result in cross-subsidisation. I have chosen Sydney-Canberra, Brisbane-Rockhampton, Melbourne-Sydney and Melbourne-Perth as a pretty representative group of sectors in the Australian airline network. I guess I could have picked one other than Brisbane-Rockhampton but, being a little parochial, I picked that one.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators will see from the table that there are columns headed 'Previous Fares', 'Current Fares' and 'Proposed Fares'. The flag fall and distance components are at the bottom of the table. The first column obviously relates to the fares that existed last week and the second column to the fares in existence now. The 'Proposed Fares' column is an exercise done according to the second Holcroft proposed formula, as mentioned on page 275 of the report. It is an exercise worked out on that basis, taking into consideration the fare increases since that report. We have worked on the basis of operating a Boeing 727 aircraft over this particular route for 12 months at 68 per cent load factor and with an all-economy configuration. We then follow the table down to the revenue that would be earned per flight and the number of stages that could be done in a normal airline day, that is, from 7 a.m. to 10 p.m. Of course, 12 Sydney-Canberra flights could be done as against only three Melbourne-Perth flights. We then look at the hours involved in each flight stage, the total hours flown per year less 5 per cent, loss of time for maintenance, and then the annual direct operating costs at $3,000 an hour for each aircraft, which I am assured is pretty close to the mark. Then we come to the surplus correction for overhead and profit over and above our direct operating costs. I have transposed this to the table at the bottom of the page so that we can see the results. If we look at the previous fare-that is the $21.80 flag fall with the distance component of 7.888c per kilometre-we will see what we have always suspected, that there has been a cross-subsidisation from the Melbourne-Perth route towards the other routes. It can be seen that this would amount to nowhere near as much as what is made out on page 208 of the Holcroft report. But the interesting thing is that we are supposed to have righted that situation.

If we look at the interim fare structure-that is, the current one involving a $40 flag fall-we see that the cross-subsidisation has been completely transposed. We are now getting a pretty heavy cross-subsidisation from the short haul routes to the long haul routes. If the Holcroft report were in any way accurate we should be starting to get near to an even surplus over the direct operating costs. To take that transposition further, if we go to a fare based on the Holcroft formula-in other words, the $52 flag fall-we see that the cross-subsidisation is considerably heavier. This is what I am basing our argument on. We have to stop here and now and try to get this wrong righted.

If the Holcroft formula were in any way correct, by the time we got to this third group of figures we should have reached a situation of somewhere near equal surplus. Although we do not know Holcroft's methodology, we can see from his figures how wrong this approach has been. We can say: 'If it is wrong in that case how wrong is the cross-subsidisation that we see on page 208?'. No one in his right mind would consider that the Sydney-Melbourne run has been cross-subsidised to the tune of $11m. If we were to sell a segment of the Australian airline system, do not tell me that it would not be the Sydney-Melbourne route from which the most money could be made and which would be the easiest to operate and thus be the most attractive. Yet this ridiculous statement is made on page 208.

I am submitting that it is about time we stopped and took a careful look at this matter. My submission is that somehow or other Holcroft's calculations have gone wrong. As I have said previously, we have a flag fall formula that is far in excess of what it should be. We have departed from the norm. These wrongs are now to be transposed over the whole airline system of Australia. They will have a detrimental effect. If we take these calculations to their ultimate conclusion and air fares go up further, with massive increases on the short haul runs, which is where the airlines make their money, we are going to see a massive swing away from airline travel to buses and trains. There is nothing wrong with that per se except for one thing. The minute the bottom line on the airlines' balance sheets is altered, a fairly heavy air fare increase over the whole network will be needed to bring that bottom line figure up again. So I submit to the chamber that we are in a fair bit of trouble if we go any further.

The Government should stop here and now. It should even come back to, say, a $30 or a $32 flag fall structure. But let us get our mathematics done pretty quickly. If the flag fall is not reduced, let us at least hold it when we consider air fare increases following cost increases. We should try to right these wrongs. Much has been said about the claim that Holcroft was not allowed enough time to complete his report. I will not debate that aspect of the matter. But I do say that if he has been working on wrong assumptions and wrong suppositions, all the time in the world would not have made this report any better. I ask the Government to cry halt at this stage.

I conclude my remarks by referring to one other factor which is of great concern to me as a Queenslander. We recognise that there has been cross-subsidisiation on our F27 routes and that in the near future we have to work this out and provide a service for those people. They are just as entitled to a service as is anybody else. If we have isolated problems with the Holcroft report in regard to the jet routes, obviously it is fair to concede that there is probably a similar situation in regard to the F27 routes. I accept the fact that the F27 routes would probably have to take a pretty hefty fare increase, but let us not go too much further down the track before we sort that matter out. I believe, as the domestic air transport review pointed out, the trunk operators should get out of the F27s. I propose in this chamber tonight that East-West Airlines, running the F27s and consolidating the service to northern Tasmania, could do it better than the two operators are now doing. I think Bush Pilots Airways Ltd in Queensland could do better if it consolidated with one operator and ran the Brisbane to Gladstone service. It could run an F27 route through western Queensland and could supplement that service with commuter-type services.

I have taken the opportunity to flag the problems, as I see them. The Government has to say halt, that we have more than looked after the long-haul routes. As I said at the beginning of my speech, I support the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill. For the reasons I mentioned, I reject the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Australian Democrats can see the reasons why the Australian Labor Party moved this amendment. Senator Gietzelt put them very eloquently, but we also tend to dispute their relevance. We will support the Government and will oppose the amendment in this case. The Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill, in summary, authorises the Treasurer to guarantee a loan to Ansett Airlines of Australia of $US490m which will allow Ansett to buy 21 Boeing aircraft and which, in turn, will permit Ansett to compete with the Trans-Australia Airlines Airbus which comes into operation next July.

SPEECH.PARA: The circumstances of this loan to Mr Murdoch have been criticised heavily in the United States-that is a matter of record-and the loan has been the subject of a United States Senate Banking Committee inquiry. It was granted by the United States Export-Import Bank in record time. The Bank charged only 8 per cent interest, which is well below the interest charged on other loans by the same bank for the purchase of aircraft. Much has been made of the fact that, three days after the bank had approved the loan, Mr Murdoch's New York paper, the Post, endorsed President Carter's re-election. Last week a senior member of the United States Senate Banking Committee called on the Export-Import Bank to delay payment of the loan to Ansett while it examined whether part of the loan had been used for purposes other than to finance the purchase of the Boeing aircraft.

We do not see this Bill as an attempt to pre-empt the Senate's power to block or to modify the proposed two-airline agreement, although I can see why that suggestion might well have been made. We cannot realistically see airline deregulation being introduced overnight, even if it were feasible or desirable to do so. I think very few honourable senators would think that. This being the case, we are probably stuck with the two-airline system, or something like it, for a number of years. TAA is fully geared up for the introduction of the Airbus in July and already had these guarantess in terms of the Australian National Airlines Act. Is it fair to turn around at this very late stage and say to Ansett: 'Sorry, we will not guarantee the finance which will allow you to compete with TAA by purchasing new aircraft'? What would that do to the Australian airline operation? Certainly, this Bill will serve to prop up the two airline system for a few more years, but I think we all would understand that while we have it we should allow it to function, in the interests of the Australian people. Looking at that crudely and directly, that 8 per cent ought to meant that the cost of aircraft will be lower, and this advantage ought to be passed on to all Australians in the form of lower fares. We have enough problems of our own in this courntry without taking on the internal ones of the United States as well. If we were to make it our business to intervene in the financial affairs of any Australian in regard to loans negotiated abroad, we would probably do nothing else.

Senator Gietzelt raised the matter of guarantees. They are there in the Bill. The aircraft equipment is collateral. Indeed, if there were a tremendous crash of this company I suppose we would end up, interestingly enough, with another government airline. We certainly would have a lot of aeroplanes to which we would be committee. The Australian Democrats' view is that we do not want to mess up the air transport industry any more than we have now-and that is quite considerably. Let us proceed with our approach to the deregulation issue along lines which we all know or should know will take time. I think honourable senators on both sides would see that. Meanwhile, we see no real reason to obstruct this Bill. As a result we propose to support it.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Bill the Senate is debating provides Ansett Transport Industries Ltd a Commonwealth guarantee for a loan of $US490m to purchase 21 new Boeing aircraft. Before I make my remarks on the Bill I must congratulate Senator Gietzelt, who I believe made an excellent speech and got right to the heart of the political machinations behind this Bill. Even though I do not completely agree with everything Senator Collard said in his contribution I must say that he showed an excellent knowledge of the airline industry and the tables that he had incorporated in the Hansard will, I am sure, benefit all honourable senators.

SPEECH.PARA: How can the Government expect this side of the Senate unequivocally to support this Bill which guarantees Ansett's $289m loan from the United States Export-Import Bank when the facts surrounding the nature of the loan are being questioned by the United States Senate and by the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and with very good reason? The United States Export-Import Bank agreed to grant a loan of $289m to Ansett Transport Industries to buy 5 Boeing 767s but it has now been revealed that of that loan $34m will be used as credit memos for ancillary purposes. Some of the Bank's directors apparently expressed surprise that these memos existed. I suggest that there are probably some people in Australia also who would be surprised that these memos existed.

I must remind the Senate of the most unusual circumstances surrounding this deal. The loan was approved just six days after Rupert Murdoch's New York Post endorsed President Carter in the New York presidential primary in February 1980. Furthermore, the loan application was approved in half the time that is normally taken and at terms more favourable than those applicable to any similar deal that we know about. I think one of the reasons why the deal was approved was spelt out in an article in the Australian on 24 March 1981 by Bryan Boswell of the Washington Bureau. The article states:
The loan to Ansett was made by the Ex-Im Bank during the Carter Administration, and was done to prevent the order going to the European consortium which builds the Airbus A300, ordered by TAA.

I think that is a fairly reasonable statement. There were also suggestions that there were kickbacks in the deal. The Australian Financial Review of 26 March 1981 in a report from the New York Times Service in part states:

The most recent set of allegations regarding kick-backs arose after bank officials learned that $34.2 million, or more than 17 per cent of the loan for the 767s was to go to finance pilot training, spare parts, advertising and a variety of other undefined services that would 'support' Ansett's purchase of the five wide body jets.

Bank officials say these activities, outlined in two credit memos, one to Boeing and another to General Electric Co. which makes engines for the jets, were not included in the original loan application, which said that the money would buy jets, engines and a limited number of spare parts and services.
The extra items were not detailed, either, in the loan agreement sent to Congress.

I wish to make some remarks about the Holcroft inquiry because the Labor Party and, I believe, a number of Government back benchers, whether they are prepared to say it or not, were disgusted at the shabby treatment that the three members of the Holcroft committee received from this Government. The report that they did bring forward was a very comprehensive report especially when one considers the short period that the committee had in which to complete its inquiry and bring down its findings. I think the recently announced changes in air fare charges are an insult to the members of the Holcroft committee. We can see that as a token gesture to Western Australian Government back benchers the Sydney to Perth fare of $286 has been lowered by $15. What a joke! What difference will $15 make for the fare between Sydney and Perth? Can anybody reasonably suggest that reduction will create more traffic on that route? If the Government were fair dinkum about this it would be utilising some of the 1,000 seats that Qantas Airways Ltd has available each week on planes travelling between Sydney or Melbourne and Perth. I think it is interesting to read the words of Sir Lenox Hewitt, who of course is the former chairman of Qantas and who now works for Ansett Transport Industries. According to the figures that were given in April 1980 by Sir Lenox Hewitt, passengers would have been able to travel Qantas from Melbourne to Perth for $101 compared with the cheapest domestic fare at that time of $252. They would have been able to travel from Sydney to Melbourne and return for $54, as opposed to the cheapest domestic fare then of $85. The return fare for people from Western Australia travelling to Sydney and out of Australia, going to Honolulu or the West Coast of the United States of America would have been $337, which I believe was a saving of approximately $154 on the domestic air fare applying at that time.

Compare the miserable cut of $15 with the increase in the fare between Sydney and Canberra. That fare went up approximately $16. A Canberra family that wants to spend Easter in Sydney and does not want to travel on an antiquated train system but wants to travel with either Trans-Australian Airlines or Ansett will now have to pay $128 extra. TAA officials in Canberra have informed me that a number of cancellations have been made over the Easter period for Canberra to Sydney flights. I also found by inquiries I made today of Ansett that a number of school groups that intended to travel from Sydney to Canberra have in fact cancelled and they will now come here by motor coach. We all know that a large proportion of the traffic between the two cities of Sydney and Canberra consists of public servants, Federal parliamentarians and their staff, all of whose air fares are paid by the Government. Ultimately it is the taxpayers who will pay for this massive and unnecessary increase.

I want to make some remarks about the sale of TAA. I think the first question we have to ask is: Why has this Government all of a sudden decided to sell TAA? The Minister claims that the Holcroft inquiry influenced his decision. But Mr Holcroft himself has denied that the inquiry ever suggested such a thing. An article in the Australian Financial Review of 2 April 1981 stated:
The chairman of the Holcroft inquiry, Mr Warwick Holcroft, last night said that he was positive that the report had not suggested selling TAA, or making it a public company.

I think that statement speaks for itself. It is quite plain to members on this side of the Senate that the Government had been waiting for any excuse to propose that TAA should be sold. The only people who would gain from a sale would be Ansett shareholders. The public would gain nothing except further fare increases. TAA, whatever anyone might say, is a profit-making enterprise. Its operating profit in 1973 was $6.76m; in 1974 it was $3.71m; in 1975 it was $4.51m; in 1976 it was $4.88m; in 1977 it was $9.51m and for the 1978-79 financial year it made $10m. TAA costs the Government absolutely nothing to maintain and makes a sizeable contribution to public revenue.

I suggest to honourable senators, especially those on the other side of the chamber, that they should check the profits of a number of airline companies overseas, not only international airlines, but also internal airlines, for example, in the United States. I suggest those figures I have just cited show TAA in a very good light indeed. TAA was brought into existence to compete against private interests and prevent undesirable economic and social effects which occur when any industry is controlled by a monopoly of private interests. On a number of occasions TAA has initiated fare cuts. It has been through its link with the Government that it has been able to push through these fare cuts. On occasions it has forced Ansett to follow suit. I do not believe that Australia can afford a situation where companies such as Ansett have to funnel off profits from their airways to prop up some of their other shaky enterprises. In this case I am referring to Ansett's link with Associated Securities Ltd.

It is totally unrealistic of the Minister to claim that TAA would not be run by a monopolistic group if it were sold. The sort of capital flow necessary to buy an enterprise even half the size of TAA would inevitably result in single corporation control. I believe, no matter what the Minister might say, that in the long term-certainly not in the short term-we would face the great danger of an airline such as TAA falling into foreign control even though it might appear on the surface as if the majority shareholding was still in Australia. Unfortunately, the Government has not seen fit to explain why or how it intends to sell TAA. I suspect that it has little idea but it is waiting for suggestions that might come from Ansett's owners who have been advocating the sale for many months. I do not think this Government can any longer deny that Ansett is running the Government's airline policy. What would happen if TAA became a public company? The Leader of the Opposition, Senator Button, made some remarks on this aspect yesterday. He quoted a statement by the Chairman of TAA. Unfortunately I have not been able to find the quote, but the Chairman said: 'This is marvellous. The first thing we will be able to do is get rid of all the unprofitable routes. We will be able to get rid of all those Fokker Friendship services in Queensland'. As a result of that nobody would win. The public would lose.

I have spoken here before and advocated a one-airline policy. I have suggested that in the future TAA and Qantas might be amalgamated.
