I do not believe that Australia can afford two international airlines, whatever Ansett says and whatever it might be trying to do at the moment to become an international airline. I do not believe our population could support two international airlines. We would have massive duplication. The administrative costs would be enormous. One of the big problems that is already faced by Qantas is that of administrative costs. Qantas, which serves a small population in Australia, has administrative centres in Sydney, Melbourne, Perth, Brisbane, Darwin and now Townsville. I ask honourable senators to compare that situation with airlines such as the West German airline Lufthansa or KLM Royal Dutch Airlines. Both airlines operate out of single airline countries. Lufthansa's administrative centre is Frankfurt. It has a small operation in Munich. KLM operates only out of Amsterdam. Our international airline has to operate administratively out of six centres yet we are thinking about having a second international airline. Ansett is already saying that it will operate out of Adelaide. This would lead to a massive duplication of administrative costs.

I believe that if TAA and Qantas were amalgamated large savings of equipment would be made. At present many of the aircraft of both companies are not being utilised. I know that part of the reason is curfews and the distance between the west coast and the east coast of Australia. We have idle aircraft at a time when the smaller states of the South Pacific are crying out for direct flights from Australia. A number of these countries have runways which are completely inadequate for the 747s. I give as an example Vanuatu, the newly emerged country in the South Pacific. This country depends desperately on tourism from Australia. It has entered into talks-I do not know that they could be described as negotiations-with Ansett Transport Industries which thinks it might be able to service the country with an international airline.

I am pointing out that if TAA and Qantas amalgamated, some of the equipment which at present remains idle because of curfews and other reasons-it is not idle because it cannot be fully utilised-would be able to service a number of these small countries. Destinations such as Fiji have tremendous amounts of traffic from Australia but in recent years have been overflown by the main international airlines such as Qantas and Pan Am World Airways. The Airbus equipment that has been bought by TAA is the best and most economic equipment to fly to Fiji and a number of South East Asian countries. As I have said, if Ansett is involved there will be more duplication of equipment, more idle time, and further increases in fares. Again it will be the public who will pay if Australia falls for a two international airline policy. If there were a merger between TAA and Qantas there would also be cheaper package deals for visitors to Australia. They would be able to see more at a more reasonable cost.

Last year a survey was conducted of all visitors to Australia. This survey indicated that of the people who were visiting here for the first time only 2 per cent went to Hobart and only 1.4 per cent went to Darwin. This is a tragedy, and one of the real reasons for those figures is the high internal airfares. We have a situation now where some visitors from overseas pay half of their original fare to be able to travel from the east coast to Perth. What has this Government done about it recently? It has given a magnificent decrease of $15 in the fare.

I have spoken here before about deregulation of the airline industry. I have to be fairly careful about this because a couple of years ago I put up an argument that the airlines could be deregulated on the east coast. I limited the deregulation to the east coast-Sydney, Melbourne, the Gold Coast and parts of north Queensland. I am still not sure whether that would work but more and more evidence is coming out of the United States, even though I admit there are conflicting reports that deregulation internally in the United States has not been the success that some people say it has been. We are finding that airline companies within the United States are seeking to amalgamate. Fewer and fewer airlines within the United States have been making profits. More alarmingly the latest statistics show that the safety record among the commuter airlines, which have felt the pinch the most, has been declining.

This Government has no airline policy at the moment. It is bowing to pressure on all fronts except the one that counts, and that is the paying public. Let us examine the Government decision that was recently called a victory for the back bench. The Government back benchers from Western Australia and the Northern Territory gained a very small decrease in fares between Sydney and Perth. The two-airline agreement is to be renegotiated and TAA is to be sold. It is interesting to note the powerful weapon they used to get these concessions. They threatened to oppose the legislation which is before us tonight and which provides for the Australian Government to give guarantees on highly suspect loans to Ansett from the US banks, and it was a very good tactic. They did not waste time in arguing for the public's right to cheaper air fares. They did not waste time arguing about the public's right to better services. They went for this Government's weak spot. This weak spot was complete allegiance to Ansett Transport Industries Ltd. They knew that this Government would defend Ansett's interests no matter what might happen. They achieved more concessions than they could have obtained with any other bargaining weapon.

The back benchers knew that the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) was trying to pull a quick trick on them by putting all the Ansett loans into this one Bill instead of having them come through in four or five Bills as Government back benchers and the Opposition expected. At the moment we have a Government which one minute opposes any idea of selling TAA and the next offers it for sale. We have a government which one minute is about to present its new airline agreement, and the next minute we are told is to be renegotiated. I think we on this side of the House have to ask ourselves who is running Australian civil aviation. Is it this Government or Ansett Transport Industries?

TALK.START.PARA: —Murdoch.
—Senator McLaren says it is the interests of the Murdoch group and Ansett Transport Industries. For that reason I support the amendment that has been moved by my colleague Senator Geitzelt. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after 'that', insert

'Consideration of the Bill be postponed pending the outcome of inquiries being conducted in the United States of America by the Senate Banking Committee, the General Accounting Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the circumstances of the United States Export-Import Bank loans to Ansett Transport Industries Limited and its subsidiary'.

The very reason that we are discussing this Bill after 8 o'clock when we should be discussing general business is that this Government cannot afford not to get this Bill through tonight. This Government, prompted by Ansett and Murdoch and its friends, has to get this Bill through tonight. If it lets it go for another fortnight it is quite likely that the inquiries being conducted in the United States by the Senate Banking Committee, the General Accounting Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation will find something wrong with the loans. Even though I do not expect it, I hope that some Government back benchers will see the morality of this issue and, even though they support the Bill, will make sure that it is at least delayed for a few weeks until we can find out what the real truth behind these Ansett loans is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jessop Sen D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say just a few words about the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill. I think it is quite important that we recognise the significance of the two-airline policy that has been evolved by governments over the years. This policy has its weaknesses, but I think in a country with a limited number of passengers to utilise these airlines we have to have regard to the economy of scale. I was attracted by what was said earlier this evening by Senator Collard who drew attention to the long range effects of decisions we make now. I think he said that he believed that we had gone too far with respect to air fares on long haul journeys. He referred to the matter of cross-subsidisation. I think he has drawn attention to a very important matter, one to which we ought to have great regard in the long term. I am certainly one of those who have not been satisfied that the Holcroft inquiry went far enough. It had a limited time in which to make its judgment. As a result its recommendations, in my opinion, were generalistic and simplistic in content. That suggestion was borne out by a member of the Holcroft inquiry to whom I spoke. I said: 'I think your report was generalistic'.
—Which member was that?
—I am not going to tell Senator Walsh who it was. Why should I? Why should I talk to Senator Walsh about the matter? I am just saying that I believe--
—You just made it up.

—I ask Senator Walsh to quieten down and let me have my say. I do not interject on Senator Walsh who is often provocative in this chamber. He is one of the worst offenders in interfering with the Standing Orders in this regard. He interjects persistently, which is quite out of order. I suggest that the Opposition should have regard to the Standing Orders when a member on this side of the chamber is trying to emphasise a point of view.
—You never had any regard between 1972 and 1975.
—Order, Senator McLaren! I ask Senator Jessop to address the Chair.

—Mr Deputy President, I really worry about honourable senators opposite who reflect on history. It means that they are not progressive, that they are not up with the times and that they cannot recognise the contemporary winds of change. I support what Senator Collard said earlier. I think his comments have a lot of merit. The recommendations contained in the Holcroft report which have been accepted by the Government are as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: 2. A clear policy on air fare pricing be articulated by the Government in accordance with the guidelines and recommendations in this report.
3. Air fare prices be related as closely as is practicable to the costs of providing the services.
4. Air fare pricing be applied on a consistent basis on the national network.

5. The Inquiry's recommended system for air fare determination be applied to air fare pricing on the national jet network and as far as possible its principles be applied in any regulated air fare pricing arrangement.

7. The regulatory authority examine airline costing procedures carefully and equip itself with sufficient information about the behaviour of costs and revenues to ensure that cross-subsidies are minimised.

Senator Collard drew attention to that aspect when he said that the issue of cross-subsidisation was perhaps slightly underemphasised in the decisions that have been made. I believe in Australia we have to aim towards a consistent policy which will provide the best service possible to people who live in Western Australia and have to travel to Sydney, Canberra and other parts of Australia which are remote from their home base. I think we have to examine also the implications of the more profitable routes in Australia. The Melbourne-Sydney route is the obvious one to which we should draw attention. I believe people in South Australia are concerned that in the future the Government examine very carefully the total concept of the Holcroft report and have regard to its long term implications. In its report the Holcroft inquiry went on to recommend-this recommendation has been accepted by the Government-as follows:
8. The air fare formula consists of a simple expression involving a fixed element and a single distance rate.

That recommendation also raises some problems. It seems to me to be over simplistic in its content. Nevertheless that is what has been accepted by the Government. Another recommendation that has been accepted by the Government reads:

21. Where the Government decides that a community shall be provided with an air service which requires a subsidy of its viable operation, the subsidy be explicitly provided so that its cost is borne by the community as a whole and not only by other air travellers as a cross-subsidy.
The other recommendation that was accepted reads:
23. Air fare pricing provide as wide a range of commercial discounts as is possible without imposing a burden on the full fare paying passenger.
The report also had regard to children. The Government has accepted the following recommendation:
The child's half-fare be not confined to economy class or restricted as to time of availability.
It went on to accept the proposition that:
The regulatory authority monitor the performance of the industry to ensure that passenger air services are provided as efficiently, as effectively, and at as low a cost as is possible.

A think that all these recommendations that have been accepted by the Government are very reasonable. However, I believe that the matters that were highlighted in Senator Collard's speech earlier deserve some support right across Australia. I think that in the long term the adoption of total concept of the Hocroft report would not provide the full answer to the future of Australian airlines. I suggest that the Government encourage the Holcroft committee to have another look at the problem and complete the inquiry that it was engaged upon because I do not think that it had sufficient time to take into consideration all implications of the whole question of the airlines in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: -The Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1981, which is before the Senate now, provides a reason for a more wide ranging discussion on aviation policies and, in particular, the question of aviation charges or air fares, than the strict subject matter of the Bill which, of course, provides a guarantee for borrowings of Ansett Airlines of Australia for the purchase of new aircraft. In the last couple of months there have been a number of debates in both Houses on aviation policy and air fares. I did not previously speak in those debates because the speakers lists were restricted, but as a Western Australian I believe that I ought to take this opportunity to make some pertinent observations about aviation policy in general, and in particular the effects of the present policies which are about to be continued, on people from Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In this society there are two defensible principles of price determination, the underlying forces which determine what prices will be charged for goods or services. The first is that charges should be determined by cost. The second, which is adopted in particular in those areas where there is an element of regulation in price determination, is that people who are disadvantaged, either by geographic isolation or some other factor, will pay less than the full cost of providing the service. Of course that principle is applied in the provision of telephone services and mail services. The distant and sparsely populated areas of the country receive a cross-subsidy through Telecom Australia and Australia Post from the more profitable services which those authorities provide in the capital cities and the more densely populated areas. In my view either of those principles, under certain circumstances, can be applied. Either prices should be set by competitive market forces, unimpeded by government regulation, or under some conditions there is a case for government regulation or government intervention to compensate disadvantaged people for the financial disabilities of living where they do.

The ironic thing about air fares in Australia, over several decades, is that neither of those principles has been applied. Charges for particular journeys have not been determined by cost. The Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares brought this out more forcefully probably than any previous investigation of this subject. But for a very long time it has been a matter of common knowledge to anyone who has taken a serious interest in it, that the long haul journeys are subsidising the short haul journeys.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell me, why is it that everybody wants to get on to the Melbourne-Sydney run? Every airline operator wants to get on to the Sydney-Melbourne run.

—I do not have the figures in front of me to see just what the cross-subsidy towards the Melbourne-Sydney route is. I know that it is not as great as that for the Melbourne-Sydney or Melbourne-Canberra route. There is a correlation; the shorter the distance the greater the cross-subsidy from the longer distance hauls. When the honourable senator said 'everyone' I presume that he was saying that the airline prefers to operate the Sydney-Melbourne route to any other route.
—And every would-be operator.

—If the honourable senator wants to argue that point of view he is, of course, obliged to argue that the attempts to quantify costs in the Holcroft report are based on false assumptions. If he wishes to do that I guess that he will have an opportunity afterwards. It is not only the Holcroft Committee which came to that conclusion. Indeed it has been acknowledged in previous modifications to charges which have been approved by the honourable senator's Government over the last few years according to distance relativities.
—And yours; yours started those.

—I think that is correct. Neither of those principles, either that charges will be determined by cost or that cost will be modified by some principle of disadvantage, has been applied in aviation policy and in air fares. In fact we are in a completely indefensible position. The most geographically disadvantaged travellers in Australia are, of course, those from places such as Darwin and-if we just deal with the larger cities-people who travel to or from Western Australia from the south-eastern States. For many years they have cross-subsidised short journeys. Although the modifications announced by the Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt) last week ameliorate to some extent that cross-subsidy, it is still there-although apparently Senator Rae wants to dispute the matter. If anything, given that in many other areas this society accepts the principle, where there is a degree of regulation in charges the short haul passengers ought to subsidise long haul passengers because they are disadvantaged simply because they live where they do.

SPEECH.PARA: The actual reductions in fares from Perth to Sydney and Melbourne in round figures are between $10 and $15 whereas, according to the Holcroft calculations, they should be in the vicinity of $50. The fares have been a long-running scandal which has not been corrected by the changes announced last week. A perhaps quantitatively less important, but in my view morally more important, scandal is the fact that economy class passengers have subsidised first class passengers for as long as fares have been regulated, or at least as long as Boeing aircraft have been used. Evidently Senator Rae does not take the Holcroft calculations very seriously. However he can go into that matter when he has an opportunity to speak.

Until very recently first class passengers paid a premium on economy class fares of 25 per cent. That was increased last year to 37 per cent, and under the charges announced last week by the Minister it has been further increased to 45 per cent. According to the Holcroft findings, the proper premium to charge first class passengers, if full costs are to be recovered, is a premium of 57 per cent. I would like to know on what economic logic or on what presumption of social justice a system which obliges economy class passengers to subsidise first class passengers and which obliges the geographically disadvantaged to subsidise the geographically advantaged can be justified? I add that, with respect to the cross-subsidy from economy class passengers to first class passengers, I do not believe from a reading of the report that the Holcroft committee considered items such as the provision of VIP lounges at airports. Although this is not quantitatively very important, I think it is symbolically quite important that the VIP lounges are used almost entirely by first class passengers. We have anomalies such as the fact well known by people who work around airports that such personalities as the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Sir Phillip Lynch) are notorious for walking into first class lounges and stuffing their pockets full of cigars. Ultimately, all that is paid for by the economy class passengers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I didn't quite hear what the honourable senator was accusing--
—I said that Lynch is notorious for stuffing his pockets full of cigars in VIP lounges at airports.
—I must object to that.

—Senator Walsh, I do not think that your statement is quite appropriate in the context of a sedate Senate debate. I suggest that you moderate your language. It might be in order for you to withdraw that statement you have just made.
—I am quite willing to withdraw it, but it does not alter the fact.
—Senator Walsh, I thank you for withdrawing your remark. Please continue with what, prior to your comment, was a good speech.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I am not accustomed to such praise or approval. The other matter on cross-subsidies which I want to raise, and which again has particular relevance to Western Australia, is that the major trunk operators, TAA and Ansett, do not operate intrastate services in Western Australia. The main intrastate services--
—What about MMA?

—That is a subsidiary of Ansett. If Senator Rae, either through his Committee on Finance and Government Operations or in some other way, can provide a detailed breakdown of the costs and revenue, and if he can isolate the MacRobertson Miller Airline Services subsidiary from the Ansett empire and accurately determine both revenue and costs, I would appreciate such an analysis. As far as I am aware, no one has yet been able to do that, and the Government does not insist that that subsidiary operation be isolated from its parent for accounting purposes. That is another matter which, in my view, ought to be cleaned up.
—You might like to move that the Senate refer that matter.

—I would be quite happy to do that. From the information available, and I concede to Senator Rae that the information cannot be taken as completely definitive, it would appear that MMA's intrastate operations are self-supporting. In other words, there is no cross-subsidy from the Ansett group to the MMA subsidiary. Indeed, if any cross-subsidy is involved it applies the other way. However, that situation does not apply in all States. There are limited services to Tasmania, a service from Adelaide to several points in South Australia, a service from Melbourne to Albury and, of course, numerous services in Queensland which are provided by the major trunk operators, either Ansett or TAA.
—TAA has no intrastate services in South Australia.

—Has it not? Actually, I did not say that it did. I said that the routes were operated by either Ansett or Trans-Australia Airlines in those various States. The Holcroft committee certainly did document a considerable cross-subsidy from the major trunk routes to the intrastate routes I have mentioned. In particular, of course, it is most notable in Queensland. I think from memory that the cross-subsidy or loss of $5m sustained by TAA-it is only TAA in Queensland which is operating the inland routes-is picked up entirely by TAA. That raises another interesting irony, or contradiction. The Queensland Government, of course, not only blackmailed TAA into maintaining those non-paying inland services but it also stipulated that TAA had to continue to operate those services with Fokker aircraft, when frequently they might have only half a dozen passengers on board an aircraft seating 40 passengers. The penalty for refusing to succumb to that blackmail from the Queensland Government was that that Government would cancel TAA's licences to operate the profitable intrastate coastal routes. As with so many other things that happen in Queensland, it is quite scandalous that that sort of blackmail should be allowed to succeed. It is the ultimate hypocrisy that the Government which blackmails an airline operator in that way should in different circumstances proclaim itself to be a paragon of free enterprise virtue.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have said, the statement made last week by the Minister did modify some of the injustices which have affected Western Australians in particular. If I could digress, I want to say a few more words about Queensland. I am not suggeting that Queensland's outback towns should not have an air service. Indeed, they would continue to have an air service. Bush Pilots Airways Ltd is quite happy to provide a service using very much more economical aircraft. Apart from all the hypocrisy and humbug of the Queensland Government, it is on cost grounds completely irrational that for those relatively small, sparsely populated towns an aircraft the size of the F27 should be placed on the route. Very much smaller aircraft should be used. It is not a question of having an F27 service or no service at all but a question of having an F27 service or a service that is far more appropriate to the volume of traffic.

TALK.START.PARA: —How should it be structured?
—If I heard Senator Rae correctly, he said he agreed with that.
—No. I am accepting what you have said. I am just asking: How would you structure it? Who should operate what sort of aircraft?
—There would not be F27s but Metro jets or Cessnas or whatever the volume of the traffic required.
—If there is a subsidy necessary, who should pay it?

—If a social judgment is made that a subsidy is justified then in my view, since Senator Rae presses me for an answer, it should be paid either by the Government of Queensland or by the Government of Australia. Certainly it should not be paid by other airline passengers. If a subsidy is paid, at least it is out in the open and everyone knows what has happened; whereas only a very small minority, in spite of the publication of the Holcroft report, realise the enormous per passenger subsidy enforced by coercive means, and of course, the burden is being picked up entirely by TAA. The statement last week by the Minister did ameliorate to some extent, although not entirely, the long-standing cross-subsidy from long distance passengers to short distance passengers. I understand that at a Press conference last Friday it was suggested to the Prime Minister by a journalist that the Government's airline policy was indecisive. The Prime Minister vigorously denied that. In a sense, I suppose, he is right. How could one say that a government was indecisive when it makes a decision every day about aviation policy? In fact, that is what it did last week.

SPEECH.PARA: One day the Minister for Transport issued this statement on domestic air fares. The next day it was announced by the Government, following some pressure apparently from a few people on the Liberal Party back bench and possibly even from somewhere else, that there would be an inquiry into the two-airline policy. Of course, that seemingly repudiated the unequivocal assertions which a number of senior Ministers had made over the past 12 months. When one dug a bit deeper-unfortunately this fact has not been properly reported, especially in Western Australia-it was revealed that the so-called inquiry was, in fact, a fraudulent exercise.

The Minister's statement in the House last Thursday was typically brought in at half past 10 in the evening in the full knowledge that media coverage of it would be minimal, coming in as it did at that time. It reminds me of Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle's sneaking out those Neimeyer statements at 6 p.m. once a month. Following the same principle, at half past 10 in the evening the Minister went into the House with a statement saying that the Government will establish an inquiry into the possibilities of deregulating aviation and that the inquiry will have five years in which to report. The next day, the Prime Minister, at one of his kerbside Press conferences with the electronic media only, said that it will probably take a couple of years to get the inquiry set up anyway from which, of course, it becomes obvious that some time within the next seven years this bogus inquiry into deregulation might actually come down with a report and some recommendation.

The same Government that truncated the Holcroft report at seven months has the audacity shortly afterwards to announce-and to expect to be taken seriously-that it is setting up an inquiry which will bring down some recommendation some time within the next seven years. On what basis does the Government justify a seven-month time period for one inquiry and a seven-year period for another? Presumably nobody who is aware of those facts will take this inquiry seriously. The reason that announcement was made was that there were a few mutinous rumblings and mutterings on the back bench. The Government was terrified that the Bill now before the Senate would not get through Parliament this week and Rupert Murdoch would not get his $500m guarantee. That inquiry is a bogus exercise, an attempt to deceive the people of Australia and the delivery by the Government of one of the pay-offs to Murdoch for his vigorous support during the last election campaign and in anticipation of equally vigorous support in future election campaigns.

The last point I want to make concerns the Minister, in particular, and his either abysmal ignorance or irrationality. The National Country Party-I think it calls itself that nationally these days but it calls itself something else in various States; it is the party to which Mr Hunt belongs anyway-had a conference in Canberra on 7 March. Mr Hunt was reported in the Sydney Sunday Telegraph of 8 March as saying that there will be:
. . . big reductions in air services if the two-airline agreement is dropped.
He also said:
. . . the parts of Australia that will suffer most will be Darwin and Perth.
He said that these cities:
. . . would not have access to the more sophisticated wide-body jet services that will be coming on stream in the '80s-
That is, if the two airlines policy were abolished. His rationale for making that assertion was that these aircraft would be concentrated:
. . . on the most popular routes to make the most possible money.

Apparently Senator Rae wants to challenge this and I will be very interested to hear what he has to say. Apparently he has a different view. The Holcroft inquiry and everyone else I know who has made a serious attempt to study this matter has come to the conclusion that under the pre-existing fares at the time Mr Hunt made the statement-given that the average load factors on the Perth-Sydney, Perth-Melbourne and Perth-Adelaide routes are above the national average; so the load factor makes the Perth service even more profitable-the most profitable route in Australia given the same load factor, is the route from Perth to the south-eastern States. That, of course, begs the question: Why would any sensible airline manager decline to put aircraft on the route which has the greatest profit potential? Not content with that, Mr Hunt has made another comment. I understand that these answers came out in Question Time at the conference. I have also observed that the wildest statements that Country Party Ministers make seem to be reserved for conferences of the party faithful. I suppose they reason with considerable justification that they are dealing with a more ignorant audience when they are speaking to a Country Party audience than they would be when dealing with the population in general-a conclusion with which no student of the Country Party could seriously disagree. Mr Hunt said:
. . . it was not until the two-airline system came into operation that the State--
He was talking about Western Australia-
achieved regular scheduled services to the eastern States.

That just is not true. I am not sure just when regular scheduled services to Western Australia were established. They were certainly established by 1946 and the two airlines agreement started in 1952. Some 17 days later Mr Hunt was questioned in the House by the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) about the empty Qantas Airways Ltd seats which are continually available between Perth and Sydney or Melbourne and about allowing domestic passengers to occupy those seats. Around 1,000 Qantas seats in each direction each week are available. Qantas has publicly stated its eagerness to make those seats available at very substantial discounts. Because of the bureaucratic interference of this self-proclaimed free enterprise Government, those seats cannot be filled. In response to this Mr Hunt said:

Many people do not understand that if we allow a number of 747 aircraft to fly intermittently over these routes it will ultimately affect the volume of passengers available for the scheduled domestic services

I interpolate that some of us-it may not have penetrated the consciousness of members of the Country Party-realised that allowing those seats to be filled, although not on a one to one ratio, would, of course, affect the number of passengers available for 727 interstate flights. Indeed that was one of the reasons that we explicitly stated for making the seats available. The Government claims to have a fuel conservation policy. If all those spare Qantas seats were occupied six east-west flights per week would be redundant. That would save one-quarter of a million litres of fuel a week. But the Government is not interested. Not only is it not interested in facilitating that but it also uses its bureaucratic regulatory power to forbid that happening, and obviously has every intention of continuing to forbid its happening. I return to the Minister's so-called answer. He said:
Ultimately this--
That is the cancellation of some existing 727 services-
must affect the frequency of the scheduled services to Perth, Darwin and elsewhere.

I guess that is true. It would affect the frequency. But when reading that I wondered whether this fellow had ever actually travelled to Perth or, if he had not travelled to Perth, whether he had any idea of the timetables on which interstate flights operate from Perth. If people in Western Australia want to go to the east by air, they have two basic choices. They can go at midday or they can go at midnight, give or take a few minutes. It is not that some people would not be able to leave Perth at 6 p.m. or at 7 a.m. if some services were cancelled. Moreover, almost without exception, all the services which leave at midday or midnight, give or take a few minutes, operate in tandem. We have this absurd product of the two airlines policy in the form of the TAA-Ansett race on almost every route in Australia. Almost without exception, the services operating from Perth operate in tandem. Does this fellow not know that half of the services could be cancelled from Perth to the east without affecting at all the options that are available to Western Australian passengers? There are only two possible conclusions. Either this Minister is so ignorant of vital matters affecting his own Department that he is unfit to hold office, or this Government is so beholden to the commercial interests of Rupert Murdoch that it is dictating to him that he has to continue to administer a policy the primary objective of which is to protect the Murdoch commercial empire, and to that perhaps one could add the empire-building ambitions of certain bureaucrats in the Department of Transport, or Transport Australia, as I think it calls itself these days.

With respect to filling empty Qantas seats with domestic passengers, it has been said in the past that international services are not particularly reliable in sticking to flight schedules and so on. I guess there is some truth in that. Obviously a headwind would delay the arrival of an aircraft travelling 6,000 miles more than it would delay an aircraft on a short haul, and it is true that the Qantas international flights that come into Perth probably do not maintain their advertised schedules as accurately as do the domestic operators. But what is wrong with allowing Perth people the option? I have absolutely no doubt that for a discount of 50 per cent hundreds or thousands of Perth people would be quite happy to sit around Perth Airport for a couple of hours waiting for an international flight to arrive and then transport them to the eastern States.

TALK.START.PARA: —Qantas is a good thing.
—Why?
—I support you, for the first time ever.

—If the honourable senator supports me I hope that he will be supporting our policy on this matter. I am, although surprised, grateful for Senator Teague's support on this matter. I would be interested to know on what grounds any member of the Liberal Party or the National Country Party, given especially that they profess to believing in maximising consumer choice and minimising bureaucratic regulation, can support a policy-and, Senator Teague included, they will support it here tonight when they all vote for this Bill-denying Western Australians the option of sitting around Perth Airport for a while, for a bit longer than they might have to for a domestic flight, in order to get a cut price seat on a Qantas plane to the eastern States. I would be very interested to learn how anyone at all could mount a case which justifies the denial to Western Australian people of that choice. I would be particularly interested to have it explained to me how anyone who purports to be an advocate of maximum consumer choice and minimal government regulation could justify such a policy. Yet, notwithstanding that, I predict, and I will not give an explanation, that all honourable senators opposite will vote for this Bill and for a policy which continues the present system and the present denial of choice.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomas Sen A.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak only briefly. I agree with most of the points that Senator Walsh made tonight, although not necessarily with the manner in which he presented them. We are debating the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1981. This Bill basically guarantees the amount of money that Ansett Transport Industries Ltd will need to purchase 21 Boeing aircraft. Because the debate has widened beyond the strict terms of the Bill, I shall make some points that I intended to save until the Bill dealing with the two airline policy came forward.

SPEECH.PARA: Liberal members in Western Australia have been working for well over two years to adjust what they see as the inequities in the fare setting formula for long haul passengers. The Government, to its credit, has acknowledged this problem. Over the last 12 months or so every adjustment made to the fare setting formula has acknowledged this by increasing the flagfall and decreasing the cost per kilometre. But this is happening far too slowly. We have had the active support of an organisation in Perth called the fair internal air fare group. This is certainly a very strong and powerful ginger group. It has supplied us with a tremendous amount of ammunition with which we have been able to support our case. Our group was instrumental in persuading the Government to establish the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares, and we have encouraged the Government to hold up the ratification of the two airlines agreement until it has had the opportunity of studying the results of the Holcroft inquiry. Senator Walsh and many of his colleagues have made a great deal of the so-called truncation of the Holcroft inquiry. Many very important decisions had to be made very quickly by the Government as a result of the Holcroft inquiry. It was fairly important that its report be made very quickly.

The Holcroft report identifies three major areas of deficiency in the present method of controlling the airlines. The first is the gross cross-subsidisation that occurs in Australia, the second is the deficiency in the air fare setting formula and the third is the lack of accountability of the whole industry. Already interim changes in the fares have occurred. I stress the word 'interim' because it has been recognised by the Government that the changes that have been made recently are only interim. We certainly expect, along the lines of the Holcroft report, that the next change will be much more dramatic and will give greater recognition to the continuing cross-subsidisation on long haul routes.

I look forward with a great deal of pleasure to the establishment of a lengthy inquiry into the possibility of deregulation of the airline industry in Australia. It needs to be a long term inquiry. Deregulation has been in force in America for only a short while, and I think a longer period is needed before a proper assessment of that substantial move can be made. In passing, it must be remembered that when that deregulation occurred people said that it was a Carter move. But that move was supported by both major parties in the United States Congress. It was supported also by most commentators on the issue. Although many people question the decision, many of the reports now coming out of America suggest that it was a correct decision. I strongly support deregulation and will take some convincing that that is not the right way to go.

The third achievement has been the setting up of an independent tribunal to establish the fare setting formula. The Holcroft inquiry established that the Department of Transport does not have expertise in that area, that it is quite deficient in the area, and that a tribunal quite independent of government controls is necessary. The sorts of pressures which Senator Walsh spoke about and which operate in Queensland tend to distort the fare setting formula if such a decision is made by a department of a government. But an inquiry independent of those sorts of pressures can more easily and more accurately set future fares.

The fourth area of recent achievement is the promise by the Government to commercialise Trans-Australia Airlines. This week in this chamber we had a debate on what the Australian Labor Party considers will be the disastrous consequences of that move. I suggest that if one of the three options that Senator Collard has been so widely propounding-that is, that a majority of the shares or all the shares should be retained by the Government-is taken up, then the only difference will be in the reporting methods under the Companies Act, which reporting will be much more substantial and much more exacting. This is a matter that I strongly support. But it is my personal belief that the Government would be well advised to sell more than 49 per cent of the shares to the general public. I agree that there should be limitations on the shareholding with the company, particularly by shareholders in existing airlines, and that particular care should be taken with regard to overseas involvement in the industry. If many of the things that we suggest should happen to TAA do happen, particularly in Queensland where there is an enormous amount of cross-subsidisation and unnecessary support of small centres, there is no reason at all why TAA could not become a very profitable organisation whose shares would be highly sought after.

TALK.START.PARA: —If it didn't fiddle its books it would look much better than it does.
—Senator Rae is much more expert in that area than I am.
—Set something aside for annual leave. It is one of the few companies-Qantas is another-that do so. See what that does to your accounts.

—Yes, I am aware of that point. I suggest that still more needs to be done. We need to watch very carefully that the two-airline agreement which will be renegotiated takes account of the matters that Senator Walsh raised with regard to spare seats on international aircraft flying across Australia. We should also take account of the less secure position in which the new two-airline agreement places the third level airlines. I guess that each of us would have received a letter from East-West Airlines Ltd. In that letter, or series of letters, the airline made out a very strong case regarding the disadvantage that it finds itself in compared with its situation under the old two-airline agreement. I point out that the recent changes to air fares incorporated a 9 per cent general increase in air fares. This is not widely recognised. The people who are complaining about quite substantial increases in air fares between Canberra and Sydney or between Sydney and Melbourne must remember that those increased air fares take account of that 9 per cent increase. It has partly removed the cross-subsidisation. I sincerely hope, and assume, that the independent tribunal to be established to look at the air fare formula will remove that cross-subsidisation.

SPEECH.PARA: What else has to be done? Trans-Australia Airlines must be made more business-like, as Senator Rae pointed out. Senator Rae has shown me some of the features of TAA's annual report which show that many mistakes have been made in its operation. If we can make it more business-like, I will certainly support the selling of more than 49 per cent of its shares. I certainly support the removal from TAA of the imposition of having to fly uneconomical routes. I agree that many smaller airlines can fly those routes much more economically. In Western Australia MacRobertson Miller Airlines Services used to service the two coastal towns of Esperance and Albany. It proved, after a number of years, to be totally uneconomical to fly F27s to those ports. So, despite an enormous amount of political and Press pressure, it ceased to fly those routes. In place of the F27s we have quite large and comfortable turbo-prop aircraft which seat about 20 people and which undertakes six or seven flights a week compared with MMA's two or three flights a week. If one asks the locals now, they admit that they were crazy to complain about the loss of the F27s.

Senator Walsh, in his final comments, ridiculed the present parallel scheduling. I suggest that parallel scheduling will be a thing of the past once TAA acquires its Airbus and Ansett Airlines of Australia acquires its new Boeings. When those aircraft are in Australia the problem of parallel scheduling will be a thing of the past. I suggest that Ansett may have made the best decision. It will have a more flexible range of aircraft. I doubt very much whether the Airbus will often go to Western Australia in the near future because such a large aircraft is less flexible for Perth's relatively limited demand. I support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: — The Bill which is being debated here tonight is the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1981. It is interesting to note that this Bill was introduced in the House of Representatives in the dying stages of a parliamentary week-in fact almost at 10.30 at night-so that no real comment could be made on it; although reading the House of Representatives Hansard I noticed that the shadow Minister for Transport attempted to make some comment but was not able to do so. It is even more interesting to note that the Bill went through the House of Representatives yesterday, which was a non-broadcast day for it, and came to us today, which is a non-broadcast day for us. So very little outside publicity has been able to be given to this Bill by way of broadcast. I do not know whether this is significant, but when one looks at some aspects of the Bill, I daresay it could be significant.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill does nothing for those people in Australia whose air transport services are at greatest risk. By 'those people' I mean those who live off the main trunk route. Many people are in that situation in Queensland, the State which I represent. These people have a definite need for air transport as there is no real alternative available. The Bill, as I said, is termed the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill. I should like to develop an argument which suggests that it could well be termed the rural air services discrimination Bill. The Minister for Transport (Mr Hunt), in his second reading speech, said:
Yesterday I announced that the Government has taken an in-principle decision to establish TAA as a public company . . .

This announcement was not well received in Queensland. In fact it was received with a great deal of alarm. Many rural residents immediately perceived that their air services were in jeopardy. In rural centres in Queensland Trans-Australia Airlines has a fairly extensive operation. For instance, in the south-west of Queensland TAA services the towns of Birdsville, Charleville, Mitchell, Quilpie, and Roma. In central Queensland it has extensive operations, and in north-western Queensland it has similar operations. But all of these air routes which TAA services have been at risk. It was mentioned earlier that Bush Pilots Airways Ltd has had its eye on these services for some time. My colleague, Senator Walsh, mentioned that perhaps Metroliners could be used in this area, and that BPA would like to do that. I disagree with Senator Walsh in one respect because these areas in western Queensland, south-western Queensland and north-western Queensland not only have passengers to be taken over those routes, but they also have freight to be taken over those routes. People in those areas want to make sure that they have aircraft which will carry them and freight when necessary.

Not only has BPA had its eye on these air routes. Senator Thomas mentioned another airline a few minutes ago which also was interested in operating in Queensland. So the air routes which have been serviced by TAA have been at risk for some time. Because of that, when it was announced that TAA would become a public company, many people in western Queensland, north-western Queensland and south-western Queensland looked at this matter with a great deal of alarm. They could see the possibility that TAA would soon abandon these routes. In fact, it took little time for people in TAA management to make up their minds that it would do so. After it was announced that TAA was to become a public company it was soon announced that TAA would pull out of Queensland's rural routes. The Chairman of TAA, Sir Robert Law-Smith, said that one advantage of becoming a public company was that F27 routes could be abandoned.

In Queensland a number of routes are sometimes called the milk run. They are called the milk run because the aircraft stop at different places en route between two major towns. But TAA is not really interested in having a milk run any more; it is looking for the cream routes, the routes between the capital cities, the routes where the real earnings will be. It seems to me that since TAA is to become a public company the first priority which it will have will be profits and not service to the outlying areas, especially the outlying areas of the State which I represent, Queensland. I acknowledge that some routes in Queensland are not profitable for TAA. In fact, the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares mentioned that there is an $11m loss for TAA on Fokkers throughout Australia. Not all of that loss, of course, is incurred in Queensland. That is quite a substantial loss.

As a national airline, TAA provided a service to the people of rural Queensland, and it provided that service irrespective of the loss which it incurred. If TAA's services are to be withdrawn from Queensland rural areas it is important that they be replaced by an efficient service. I mentioned earlier that we must make sure that if we have a different airline in western Queensland we have an airline that flies the type of plane that can provide not only a service to passengers but also a freight service.

The Minister for Transport must recognise that there is more to Australian aviation than the capital city routes. The residents in rural Queensland need a regular and an efficient air service, and they deserve one. Of course, Ansett Airlines of Australia also services some areas of Queensland with Fokkers, but those areas that it services are not away from the coast. The only places it goes to now with its Fokkers are Maryborough, Bundaberg, Gladstone, Rockhampton, Cairns and Weipa. But the point I make is this: This Bill will do nothing to help the people in those areas of Queensland that I mentioned-the north west, the west and the south west. For instance, the Minister, in his second reading speech, said:
. . . new front line Boeing aircraft to operate on the trunk network.

How much will that interest the people at Charleville, Blackall or Winton? They are not interested in the purchase of new Boeing aircraft to operate on the trunk network; they are interested in the service they require which is an absolute necessity in the areas in which they live. Later on the Minister, in his second reading speech, specified how many Boeing aircraft were involved. He said that there were 21 Boeing aircraft. But nothing has been done to help the people in rural areas.

This Bill, which is a loan guarantee Bill, is way out of the petty cash class. It guarantees repayments for Ansett of up to $US490m. This really is a staggering sum. If one looks at the amounts of loans which have been provided for Ansett and even for other airlines-even for TAA-one can see that this is far beyond anything which we have ever had before the Parliament. In 1972-73 a loan of $US30.608m-in round figures, $30m-was guaranteed for Ansett by the Parliament. In no other year since guarantees for Ansett commenced have we guaranteed an amount in excess of $30m. If honourable senators compared that $30m with what is involved now-$US490m-they will see that it is a staggering sum. It is more than 10 times greater than what we had previously.

I sometimes wonder, when we have a look at that $490m, what the ordinary pensioner must think when he or she is living on $64.10 a week. If he is paying rent he gets $5 a week to help him pay his rent. He looks at his total income of perhaps $69 a week and then sees that we here in the Australian Parliament are putting through a Bill which will guarantee to Ansett Airlines of Australia, a private company, $490m. I can just imagine what some pensioners think.

Why does the Government have to guarantee this Bill anyway? The second reading speech of the Minister did not even address itself to this question of why we in the Australian Parliament should have to guarantee such a Bill, a Bill to guarantee $490m to Ansett Airlines of Australia. If we look at the issue carefully and critically I suppose there is a good reason for its being done but I wonder whether that good reason will help the passengers in Australia. I received a document from the Library which did address itself to this question of why the Australian Parliament should consider guaranteeing $490m to Ansett Airlines of Australia. I shall read part of what that document said. It went into the whole affair in great detail. It stated in part:

One of the effects of giving loan guarantees is to provide an implicit interest subsidy equal to the difference between the actual rate of interest charged on the loan, and the rate that the borrower would have to pay if the loan were raised in the capital markets at commercial rates.

In other words, the Federal Government, or rather this Federal Parliament, is subsidising the interest payments of Ansett. If that keeps down Ansett's costs and thus its fares, I think that is fine. I think that is commendable. But would the savings be passed on to the passengers? I believe that this would be highly unlikely. In recent years Ansett has become a plaything of millionaires. Ansett has been bought and sold more times than King's Cross Station has been bought and sold on my son's Monopoly set.

To illustrate what I mean, let us examine the recent history of Ansett. I will start my illustration with a fairly insignificant but interesting aspect. In 1976, Ansett acquired 50 per cent of the shareholding in Biro Bic (Australia) Pty Ltd and Biro Bic (New Zealand) Ltd. But let us have a look at 1977. In 1977, Ansett acquired a 48 percent interest in Associated Securities Ltd. In 1978, Ansett acquired Avis Rent-a-Car System Pty Ltd. In 1979, ASL, which we will recall was purchased in 1977, was placed in receivership. Ansett lost $19m on the deal. Because it lost this $19m its shares slumped, something like we have seen with a couple of other companies only in the last few days. Because Ansett's shares slumped it seemed to a number of larger purchasers in the Australian market that perhaps this was a good time to get in and purchase some Ansett shares. So the Bell Group Ltd increased its holding at that time to 12.9 per cent of Ansett's issued capital. Ampol acquired a 20 per cent holding, Thomas Nationwide Transport Ltd acquired a holding in Ansett of just over 20 per cent and News Ltd acquired a 5 per cent holding. All that occurred mainly because of Ansett's acquiring an interest in Associated Securities Ltd which two years later was placed in receivership. Ansett lost $19m, its shares slumped and therefore it was ready for a raid from bigger purchasers. After Ampol, as I mentioned, obtained a 20 per cent holding in Ansett, Ansett Transport Industries Ltd itself purchased 20 per cent of Ampol's holding. This was described as a defensive measure. Because Ampol had purchased 20 per cent of Ansett, Ansett purchased 20 per cent of Ampol to defend itself. What followed was quite remarkable. There was a remarkable buying and counter-buying spree involving the Bell Group, Ampol, TNT, News Ltd, Messrs Holmes a'Court and Murdoch and two knights of the realm, Peter Abeles and Reginald Ansett. The hapless Reginald Ansett was out and Murdoch and Peter Abeles were in.

Who paid for all this trading and counter-trading? Who paid for Ansett's losses on ASL and on Avis too in recent years? I mentioned that a purchase was made of Avis. Who paid for those losses? There is no doubt at all that the travelling public paid for those losses. It would not be possible for anything else to happen. If Ansett is to hold its head above water, the travelling public has to pay for these losses.

I was referring earlier to fares. This Bill is likely to do nothing for the fare situation, to help those people in rural Queensland and other rural areas that I mentioned earlier who are being slugged anyway. I will illustrate the point by showing some comparisons between Queensland fares and fares between capital cities. I am going to look at economy fares between Brisbane and Sydney and economy fares between Brisbane and Melbourne and compare those with some of the internal Queensland fares-the Brisbane to Charleville figures, for instance. I am looking at the economy fares because I believe that one can really only equate Fokker fares with economy fares. If one travels in a Fokker one realises it is hardly first class compared with jet travel. In fact, I believe that Fokkers became known as Fokker Friendships because people had to sit so close together that if they were not friends before the flight they certainly were when they got off.

Let us look at some of these fares. From Brisbane to Sydney is 747 kilometres and the fare for that trip is $91.20. If one travels from Brisbane to Charleville, which is 687 kilometres-60 kilometres shorter-the fare is $97.90, which is $6.70 more. In other words, a person travelling within Queensland on a Fokker Friendship from Brisbane to Charleville travels 60 kilometres less and pays $6.70 more than a person on a Brisbane to Sydney trip. Let us equate that with a Brisbane to Melbourne flight. Brisbane to Melbourne is 1,376 kilometres. The economy fare for that trip is $134.20. If one travels from Brisbane to Winton, which is 1,156 kilometres, and 220 kilometres shorter than the distance from Brisbane to Melbourne, one pays $145.50 to travel on a Fokker Friendship-$10.70 more. In other words, in Queensland if one wants to travel intrastate from Brisbane to Winton one goes 220 kilometres less but one pays $10.70 more.

The situation is the same with a great number of other fares within rural Queensland. Rural Queensland, in this regard, is being greatly disadvantaged. Residents in rural Queensland do not receive a subsidy such as the $5m subsidy for Tasmania. It was mentioned earlier in the debate here that a subsidy could be paid; perhaps that is something we could look at. But it is doubtful that the people in rural Queensland who are paying these high fares anyway will benefit from any cost savings if the Federal Government goes into hock for $US490m for Ansett. I say that they probably will not because any savings will not be passed on as fare concessions. I would say that it is more likely that the funds will be squandered. They will be used to offset car rental businesses and to offset losses on exotic new services such as the service between Tasmania and Christchurch, the one that is supposed to be making such a loss at the moment. I believe that no relief at all will be given to air travellers.

Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, Senator Gietzelt said that this Bill has a stench. I was not going to say that. I was going to be a little more reserved and say that it has a nasty smell. I do think it has a nasty smell about it. We have to remember that the loans for these 21 jets are under investigation in the United States. We have to remember that the Bill was brought into the Parliament almost at the death knell on a Thursday night in the House of Representatives so that there could be no debate on it. We have to remember that it was brought into the House of Representatives yesterday, when the proceedings in that House were not being broadcast. It is incredible that the Bill was introduced into this place only this afternoon, given a first reading, and immediately proceeded to the second reading stage. If this were a real House of review we would not put up with that. We would want the Bill brought in here, given a first reading, and allowed to lie for some time so that we could look at it before going ahead with our speeches on the motion for the second reading of the Bill. But that did not happen today. The Bill was brought in today, the first reading was proceeded with, and immediately thereafter the second reading stage commenced. Of course the Bill will go through this place tonight at a time when the proceedings are not being broadcast. The people of Australia will have very little opportunity of knowing what is going on with this Bill.
My colleague Senator Gietzelt moved an amendment to this Bill, and I reiterate the words of the amendment. It states:
Leave out all words after 'that' insert

consideration of the Bill be postponed pending the outcome of inquires being conducted in the United States of America by the Senate Banking Committee, the General Accounting Office and the Federal Bureau of Investigation into the circumstances of the United States Export-Import Bank loans to Ansett Transport Industries Limited and its subsidiary.

I support that amendment. I would like to mention one other matter. When I was speaking perhaps five or 10 minutes ago, Senator Lewis was doing his best to interject with comments about the arguments I was using. I deliberately did not respond to him because I wanted to make sure that I kept on the track of what I was saying. However, I will say this to him, through you, Mr President. Senator Lewis certainly represents a State in this Senate. He represents the State of Victoria. I have got into a motor vehicle and travelled almost from one end of Victoria to the other in a few hours. One just cannot do that in a State such as Queensland. From Senator Lewis's comments this evening he obviously does not have an appreciation of the sorts of problems the people in western Queensland, south-west Queensland and north-west Queensland have to put up with in relation to travel. They cannot get into their motor vehicles and travel in a few hours from one end of the State to the other.

TALK.START.PARA: —You want to try it in Victoria.

—In fact, they could travel for a couple of days in Queensland and not be anywhere near the other end of the State. Honourable senators should listen to the comments of people from other States and not try to denigrate what they have to say. I am referring only to Senator Lewis at the moment because some of my parliamentary colleagues who are sitting on the other side of the chamber at the moment realise full well the problems we have in Queensland. It behoves people such as Senator Lewis, who comes from a smaller State, to listen to the comments of people from the larger States so that they can understand what the problems in those States really are. Senator Lewis may have suggested that some of the things I was saying were nonsense. I think that is one of the words he used. That is an indication that he just does not know what is going on. It is a pity that he does not listen. If he did listen, he might learn something about one of the other States in the Federation that we represent in this Parliament. I support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Gietzelt.

SPEECH.PARA: Debate (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle) read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 to rectify anomalies and inequities and to make certain other changes. Honourable senators will recall that the Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme was amended in June 1978, having regard to suggestions made by senators and members and to the provisions of the various State parliamentary superannuation schemes. Those amendments have been in operation for almost three years and, during that time, certain anomalies and inequities have come to notice.

The most serious anomaly concerns the formula for calculating the retiring allowance payable to Ministers and office holders. One effect of the formula is that some members' superannuation entitlements are decreasing the longer they remain in the Parliament. The Bill introduces new provisions under which contributions and benefits will be expressed as a percentage of the salary payable for each office held. This is similar in concept to the basic pension scheme and will overcome the anomalies and inequities inherent in the existing additional pension formula. Nevertheless, the entitlements of some members will be lower, at least initially, under the new provisions and special arrangements have been made in these cases. The Government decided some time ago that changes were required and the new provisions will, therefore, apply to all members retiring on or after 1 July 1980.

The Bill makes a number of changes in relation to commutation of retiring alowances. These include extending the period in which members may elect to commute their retiring allowances to a lump sum, permitting members retiring on or before the end of the present Parliament to commute without any restriction as to age and giving the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust power to defer a member's election to commute if it considers the member is likely to re-enter the Parliament within 12 months. The Northern Territory Legislative Assembly passed legislation in September 1979 to provide superannuation arrangements for its members. This Bill provides for benefit payable under the Northern Territory scheme to be treated for the purposes of the Commonwealth Parliamentary Superannuation Scheme in the same way as benefits payable under the State parliamentary superannuation schemes.

The Government's attention has been drawn to certain inequities concerning members of this Parliament who have qualified for pensions under State parliamentary superannuation schemes. The Bill does not make any immediate change in these provisions but will enable new arrangements to be introduced by regulation when the Government has had the opportunity to consider the matter fully. The Australian Government Actuary has advised that in the long term the proposed changes should not significantly increase the cost of the scheme to the Commonwealth. The Bill also includes a new delegations provision and a schedule of formal amendments to the Act. I commend the Bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland Sen The Hon D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one of the trustees of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme, elected by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, I can say that the legislation now before the Parliament is designed to overcome certain anomalies and inequities in the existing arrangements. The members of the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party yesterday heard a report on the matter, and because this Bill will overcome the anomalies and inequities the Opposition supports the provisions embodied in the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1981. I am from the State of Victoria, and the first think I would like to do is to tell Senator Colston, who is still sitting in the chamber, that on the map Victoria may appear to him to be a very small State but, believe me, if he were to drive from Mildura in the north-west to Orbost in the south-east he would be very tired at the end of a 14-hour journey of something like that. It is a long way. Let me assure him that I am well aware of the distances in Queensland. I am also well aware of the need for and the abilities of the small airline companies that provide the intrastate services upon which so many of us-whether we live in Queensland, Victoria, New South Wales, Western Australia or perhaps even in the very small State of Tasmania-rely.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall deal first of all with the amendment moved by the Opposition. I wish to point out the humour of the situation. Here we have the Opposition supporting an amendment moved by, of all people, Senator Gietzelt, whom I admire as a speaker but whose philosophy I cannot support in any way at all. Senator Gietzelt, of all people-he is perhaps one of the most trenchant critics in this chamber or in the other place of the United States of America-suggests that this Parliament ought to defer the consideration of this Bill pending inquiries which are being conducted in the United States of America. Good grief, Mr President, if this Government were to put forward that proposition members of the Opposition would rise en masse and protest at what a terrible thing it was that we were going to wait upon something happening in the United States. I intend to tuck aside that matter. One of these days we will get the opportunity again to refer to the amendment moved by Senator Gietzelt to the effect that legislation before this Parliament should await the happening of something in the United States of America. We will see where the Opposition stands on that occasion. Once again it has been proved beyond any shadow of doubt that members of the Opposition are opportunists. Opportunism is all that they are interested in.

I look further at the Opposition's amendment. Believe it or not, it wants to wait on the outcome of an inquiry by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. Senator Gietzelt, of all people, suggests that the Senate ought to defer its business until the FBI has completed some inquiry in the United States. It is utterly and completely beyond belief. It is one of the greatest jokes I have heard since I have been a member of this place. It is absolutely unbelievable.

I come back to the Bill and what it is all about. What do the people of Australia want from our airline industry? I put it to the Senate that there are three factors. It is utterly beyond question that the first and most important consideration is safety and reliability. That is what we want, first and foremost, from our airline industry. I think we need to consider two other factors-speed and convenience and the price. It seems to me that speed and convenience, which I have classified as a second factor, and price are related. The question of safety and reliability is independent and not related. It stands alone. It is the area in which there is not the slightest doubt that the Government must regulate the industry. I thoroughly support the regulating of the industry in relation to safety and reliability. That is an important concession on my part, I might say. Honourable senators will be well aware my opposition to regulations. I wish to refer to one aspect of the Holcroft report in relation to safety and reliability. On page 233, paragraph 14.45, the inquiry reported:
The Inquiry concluded that the matter of the maintenance of safety standards was not directly related to the goals of a regulated pricing policy and should be set aside.

In other words, in considering pricing policies or, indeed, anything else, we can set aside safety and reliability, not because we do not consider them important-on the contrary, we consider them to be of the utmost importance-but because they are and will be matters for strict government regulation, whatever party is in power. We can set aside our considerations of safety and reliability. As the Holcroft inquiry states, they do not come into the question of price. Let us now have a look at what we are left with.

I think that until now the two-airline policy has served Australia well. Let us look at our aircraft. The latest jet aircraft serve Australia, and serve it well. They have a tremendous air safety record. In particular, I refer to the DC9 aircraft. Let me assure people of the safety of the DC9 aircraft, as told to me by the pilots who fly them. I am speaking of the people who happen to be interested in this debate and who think about the DC9 aircraft or are concerned about flying. A now retired senior pilot of one of our two major airlines told me that for the last five years of his flying life he flew nothing but a DC9 because that is what he considered to be the safest aircraft flying in the world today. Let us look at the runways that we have in Australia. I put it most strongly to the Senate that had we had a monopoly airline 30 years ago when we established the two-airline policy propellor driven aircraft would still be flying around Australia today. Without the slightest shadow of doubt, successive governments would have said that they could not afford the cost of upgrading the runways to carry the extra weight of jet aircraft.

That is what the two-airline policy has brought us. It has brought us strong, solid runways and decent airports throughout our nation. The two airlines both wanted to advance and both insisted upon introducing jet aircraft. I guarantee that we would still be flying Fokker Friendships or their equivalent around Australia had we not had the two-airline policy. My party has been in power for many years. I can assure the Senate that I have not the slightest doubt that my party would have said repeatedly, year after year: 'We cannot afford to upgrade the runways, so we cannot afford to have jets'. The Labor Party would have been even worse when it was in office. Let there be not the slightest doubt that the two-airline policy has served us well. There has been a cost. The cost has been the protection of fares and routes to ensure that both airlines have operated under a profitable arrangement. Surely, after 30 years of subsidising our national airlines it is about time we reached a stage where there is some reduction in that protection.

Senator Collard earlier this evening I think put fairly clearly, succinctly and properly the proposition that following the recent change in airline pricing formula in accordance with the Holcroft report, passengers in the eastern States are now subsidising those in the West. In any pricing system, whatever it might be, some cross-subsidising is inevitable.

TALK.START.PARA: —Holcroft recommended it.

—As my colleague Senator Rae said, the Holcroft inquiry recommended it. In fact the people in the eastern States, travelling on these shorter routes, are subsidising in a small way the people travelling on the longer routes. I am not being critical; I am merely stating a fact. I also state as a fact that some cross-subsidising is inevitable in any pricing system. I deliberately did not say 'in any regulated pricing system', I said 'in any pricing system'. Senator Collard has said to the Government-I think it is fair enough-'Stop it. You have gone far enough. Perhaps you have gone too far. Stop now and let us have another look at it'. I support Senator Collard completely. I say to the Government: 'Stop it. Let us have another look at it'. I go further than Senator Collard and I suppose I do so because of our different philosophies. We are in different parties and we have slightly different philosophies even though we go along the road together very far. I think it is time for Australia to introduce to the airline industry some influence of free market forces to see what effect they will have on the factors of price and convenience to the service to Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: In chapter 14 of the Holcroft committee report the question of equity and cross-subsidy is discussed. It is argued that the Government should decide whether the cost of subsidising air services is outweighed by the benefits derived. It is argued that even when a subsidy is justified in such cases 'as the relief of physical isolation, the encouragement of national cohesion and the enhancement of family ties, or the operation of less efficient aircraft on some routes through airport or other limitations,' a direct subsidy will in general be cheaper than a cross-subsidy. The two major domestic airlines in their submissions to the committee warned of the dangers of discussing cross-subsidies when they involve an arbitrary allocation of costs to different activities. The inquiry could not accept this difficulty although it accepted the following proposition:
Rarely can a particular allocation of costs be shown to be correct when an organisation is producing more than one product.

This is true of any enterprise where market forces are allowed to operate. For example, retail stores frequently sell an item at cost or even below cost to attract customers into their stores and away from opposition stores. What is different about an airline?
