Regulations and, in particular, the arbitrary flagfall component of regulated fares make the new fare schedules suspect, and because of these arbitrary factors it appears that they may have overcompensated for some of the distance sectors. Unnecessary regulation always leads to the smart public devising means of circumventing it.

Of course we have our tax problems. For example, we know that nowadays many airline passengers from the west book Qantas Airways Ltd to New Zealand, get off in Melbourne or Sydney, cancel the New Zealand component of their fare and fly Qantas return to Perth. They are the smarties. They appear to prefer to travel Qantas, especially first class, as they find it a much more comfortable journey than that provided by Qantas's domestic competitors, Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines. I wonder what would be the results if we introduced some market forces into the field.

What the Holcroft committee accepted was that regulation would continue and said that some arbitrary factors were inevitable. I question the validity of that proposition. It is clear that the Australian air transport industry is marked by a substantial degree of economic inefficiency. As I have said, the two-airline policy has served us well until now but after 30 years is it not time that we started to try to get some efficiency into the industry to the benefit of the fare paying passenger? I suggest that the new fare structures are suspect and certainly inefficient. Press reports now indicate that both airlines are operating almost empty off peak on their short haul routes such as between Canberra and Sydney.

In recent years the United States domestic air system has been substantially reformed. It has adopted policies designed to place increased reliance upon competitive market forces. Many of the elements stimulating those policy changes in the United States are similar to those currently present in Australia. They include frequent air fare rises, embarrassing comparison of performance between the regulated carriers and the less regulated operators and advances in economic research in the airline industry. I put it to the Senate that it will not be until free market forces have been allowed to operate in Australia that airline prices will be properly determined. Maybe it will then be necessary for the Government to provide direct subsidies to overcome the problems of physical isolation in various remote areas of Australia; but until then let us please have a look at the operation of free market forces in Australia and see what that might do to bring down price and improve speed and convenience for the travelling public of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rae Sen P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is of some significance that we go back to considering the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill 1981 which we are debating. I think that a casual observer could be excused for wondering what is the subject matter of the debate. The debate is about Ansett Transport Industries and its operating subsidiary Ansett Airlines of Australia receiving an international loan guarantee from the Government. That is what the Bill is all about. It is not about the two-airlines system; it is not about the report of the Holcroft Independent Public Inquiry into Domestic Air Fares; it is not about whether Western Australia has suddenly been converted from getting a minor advantage to getting a major advantage. It is about whether an Australian company-one half of the protected duopoly should be given the advantage of a Government guarantee so that it can take advantage of conditions which it negotiated in the international market with the Boeing company and the American banking system on what might be regarded by many people as favourable terms. The mere fact that Ansett is taking a whole lot of old model 737s on which Boeing may have been very anxious to give favourable terms, is one of the things it will have to live with.

SPEECH.PARA: The simple question that we have before us is, as a matter of some urgency, to decide whether we should approve of legislation for an Australian company to take advantage of a publicly negotiated position of advantage to Australia. For heaven's sake, could anybody be heard to say that he does not support that position? I find it somewhat amazing that some speakers from the Opposition side of the chamber have given the impression that they want to dispute whether one side of the duopoly under our present system, which they and our side of politics have supported, should get the same advantage as the other side of the duopoly in the form of a Government guarantee for its necessary loans for the purchase of aircraft. I just make the point that that is what the Bill is about. The rest of the debate has been interesting but irrelevant to the Bill.

The second point I make is that whilst I support the Bill, it does not mean that I support some of the matters that have been raised. I feel that because others have gone off the track perhaps I should go off the track very briefly-and I propose to make it brief. In my brief excursion I wish to compliment Senator Collard from Queensland for bringing before the Senate figures which give rise to the question whether we have miscued somewhere in applying what people believe is the Holcroft formula. But I have the impression that nobody is really sure what the Holcroft formula is. What Senator Collard has done is to demonstrate that it is certainly open to question whether the Holcroft formula has not converted the situation of possible disadvantage for Western Australia into a situation of major advantage for Western Australians and people on other long distance routes as opposed to the short haul travellers of Australia which includes almost everybody except Western Australians travelling to the eastern States and Northern Territorians travelling-

TALK.START.PARA: —Anyone living in Cairns would not appreciate that.

—I hoped someone would mention that but I did not expect it to be Senator Thomas. I thank the honourable senator for his interjection. If the honourable senator does not know Queensland he would not realise that most flights there are short haul. Certainly they involve long distances but the average flight is a short haul one and the average Queenslander and the average tourist is being disadvantaged in Queensland under the new formula.
—The pricing arrangement is worked out on a start to finish basis. It is irrespective of how many landings are made.

—I thank Senator Thomas for demonstrating that we need to look at the points made by Senator Collard. I will not take the matter any further. There have been some large misunderstandings, and perhaps Senator Collard has contributed to that in a significant way by the incorporation of his table in Hansard. Let us say that it was important to do what has been done to overcome a short term problem, but let nobody think that what has been done is holy writ or that it is the final solution. Let nobody think that Western Australians, as a result of a little political exercise well funded and well publicised, are able to rip off the south eastern States of Australia which are the mainstay of the airline system of Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I am amazed to hear some of the suggestions that are made. For example, I hear people saying that Western Australia has been subsidising the other States. If any operator or would-be operator of an airline in Australia were asked which route he would most like to have I defy anybody to come up with a person who would say he would like to have the Melbourne-Perth route. I would offer a wager, except that under the Standing Orders that is not permitted, that every such person would say: 'I would like the Melbourne-Sydney route'. Yet, according to the interpretation placed on the Holcroft committee report, the Melbourne-Sydney route has been subsidised by other routes. It is extraordinary that every operator could be so wrong.

One of the other extraordinary aspects is the fact that if short haul air fares and medium haul and long haul air fares are compared with those of all comparable countries of the world it will be found that our former formula-that is, pre-last week-was comparable as to relativity with those of other countries. Short haul routes attracted a certain fare, as did medium and long haul routes, but suddenly since last week our long haul fares are totally out of proportion with the fares of comparable countries of the world. Everybody is out of step except Johnny Western Australia. That is what it boils down to. I do not want to suggest that we should immediately change the situation. I want to thank Senator Collard for introducing into the debate a degree of sanity and the suggestion that we should test the figures to see whether there has not been a rather horrible mistake which explains why Australia is now in the situation where it is out of step with every comparable country and where, if the situation is compared with the ambitions of every airline operator, all the airline operators are wrong. Everybody is wrong except the Western Australians when they say they will have cheaper air fares.

TALK.START.PARA: —But your argument completely ignores the probability of different aircraft.

—I thank the honourable senator very much for his interjection. My belief is that if the Western Australians continue with that Wizard of Oz magic case they have been putting they will wind up with an opportunity to have three trips a week on a Qantas 747 or the alternative of a once-a-day DC4 service. They will lose frequency of service and standard of service because no operator will operate to Western Australia on the current fares and make a profit.
—The Sydney to Melbourne people will be flying on turbo-props again.

—I simply project my fear that the Western Australian citizens have not been well served by what has been a slick, well publicised, well financed public relations operation which has not had regard to the realities. Unfortunately, the situation has been exacerbated by the interpretation of the truncated Holcroft committee report which did not purport to have determined conclusively what approach should be adopted in relation to the fixing of air fares in Australia. The Holcroft committee set a number of major qualifications to the way in which its report ought to be adopted. This opens the report to a number of major criticisms which may produce results such as those identified by the table which was incorporated in Hansard by Senator Collard.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to say more than this: Good luck to those who have the advantage now from those of us who in the last seven years saw a 206 per cent increase in air fares before copping the latest 10.1 per cent increase. That concerns the Melbourne-Launceston tourist route which has suffered the heaviest increase in air fares in Australia. We say good luck to the Western Australians but they should not complain about a subsidy because we still got a 10.1 per cent increase from the last rise in air fares. That increase was more than the national average. As opposed to the Western Australian fare increase of 106 per cent in the last seven years air fares on the Launceston-Melbourne route increased by 206 per cent, with another 10.1 per cent increase in fares last week.

Let not the Western Australians say that they alone are upset about what is happening. The so-called $5m subsidy for Tasmania has turned out to be a $5m subsidy for Hobart. That is good for a part of Tasmania but is not good for equity in the Tasmanian tourist industry. Domestic tourists operate through Launceston because that is the shortest air section to Tasmania. It is not good for the idea that there is equity in fares for the people of the various States of Australia. I think Senator Collard's table simply means that we have to have a short term solution to the problem; I support a short term solution. I support the short term attempt. Let nobody think that that is the long term solution. Let nobody think that this is the end of the matter. Let nobody think that the Holcroft report, as interpreted by some, is holy writ and the final answer. Let it be known that there are those who can demonstrate by figures, as Senator Collard has done, that we have increased the disparities and not decreased them. I support the Bill which, as I said earlier, has nothing to do with what I have been talking about for the past 10 minutes.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —It was very interesting to observe Senator Rae's remark at the end of his speech because that remark seems to apply to most speakers in this debate on the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill. Nevertheless, the Bill invited a wide-ranging discussion upon the whole aircraft industry, the purchase of aircraft and so on in this country at the moment. I wish to address the interest of the Senate to one or two matters that concern the Bill which were raised earlier in the discussion, in particular by Senator Gietzelt. He mentioned in particular the problems of the guarantees being applicable in certain circumstances, the number of loans which they covered and the difficulties he saw in the Government's committing itself to such a long range proposal. The agreements have been made at this time in order to facilitate the undertakings which Ansett Transport Industries Ltd is now entering into in order to borrow substantial sums of money to purchase this new generation of aircraft. I think it is the key to the whole matter of obtaining the loans that, indeed, these guarantees are agreed to by the Commonwealth Government. Although the sums of money involved are totally different from those which had been previously arranged, the principle remains substantially the same. The reasons are purely and simply that we are moving into a whole new generation of aircraft development in this country which envisages a new technology in relation to wide-bodied jets. It is one of those substantial moves which, if we are to continue a private enterprise involvement, requires government support of the order that we now are agreeing to by virtue of this legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out also that Senator Gietzelt drew attention to the fact that some of the loans which are being made available to Ansett Transport Industries through the Export-Import Bank in the United States of America at what appear to be concessional rates of interest, on reflection, may not be substantially different from those which may be obtainable from other sources. At this stage of the game it is a matter for negotiation, as I understand it. It may depend on the passage of this legislation and the degree of security which can be offered other lenders. In any case, notwithstanding that there may be only minor or even major differences between the rates of interest charged on these loans, the point is that the travelling public of Australia stands to gain substantially by virtue of the fact that this company, Ansett, is able to borrow at a substantially cheaper rate than otherwise might be obtainable on the commercial markets. Of course, that must be so if one recognises that higher interest costs will not be translated into higher fares.

As to Senator Gietzelt's further point following that line of thought, I think the feeling he was trying to express was, should the Government not guarantee these loans and should Ansett be forced on to the commercial markets and pay a more commercial rate of interest, that somehow would be beneficial to the travelling public of Australia. Quite obviously, the converse is true. The Government guarantee is a substantial factor in ensuring that fares in this country are kept to a minimum by virtue of the servicing costs on the loans for these aircraft being maintained at a minimum. So, in that very real sense, this Bill contributes in a very substantial way to the benefits of passengers that will be travelling on this new generation of aircraft in the years ahead.

A matter which I do not think has emerged clearly from the discussion tonight is that the guarantees given under this proposed new Act will be, of course, subject to final approval by the lenders being given. In fact, there are matters of negotiation leading up to the final conclusion of the arrangements with lenders. Of course, that includes the Eximbank in the United States. As to the protection of this Government's interests, clearly the arrangements will include provision for security over the loans in the event of default. That will entail mortgages over aircraft and other property, I take it. Australia's interest will be safeguarded by the arrangements.

As to the other matter Senator Gietzelt mentioned-and I think it flowed through some of the remarks of other honourable senators-concern was expressed about the length of time which will be taken by the deregulation inquiry. In fact, the terms of reference of that inquiry will require its report within five years. The fact is that the new generation of wide-bodied aircraft which this company, Ansett, will be setting in place will not be delivered until 1984. In fact, we are looking down the track quite a length of time to when new aircraft will be fully in place. Consequently, having had some experience of the operation of some part of Ansett's wide-bodied fleet-and, of course, of the Trans-Australia Airlines fleet-in the meantime, together with the operation of other aircraft, this will be of substantial benefit to those undertaking an inquiry. It will be taken into account in assessing the future regulation of the aircraft industry in this country. That appears to me to be a powerful argument in favour of giving this matter some time to settle down.

Essentially, the argument settles into a very clear debate about the stability of this industry and the need for it to have a basis from which to operate in the years ahead. In fact, the establishment of a clear policy directive from the Government, which is in part laid down by this legislation, indicates to the aircraft industry and those who are operating airlines in this country the direction in which we are headed. The inquiry on deregulation opens opportunities for the development of the kinds of policies which I think Senator Lewis mentioned. He spoke of the market forces, the need for those to be developed within the aircraft industry, the need for a freer flow in regard to fares and so on. Clearly, the inquiry on deregulation opens the opportunity for discussion in this regard. I thank honourable senators for all their comments in relation to the Bill. They are all constructive in relation to the development of the industry in this country. I wish the Bill a speedy passage.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be left out (Senator Gietzelt's amendment) be left out.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being beyond 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCOTT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Country Party in the Senate)

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: Motor Traffic Ordinance-Queensland School Terms: Secondary Allowances Scheme-Senate Divisions-Christmas Island: Abbott's Booby-Parliament House: Parking-Estimates Committees

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Messner) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in the adjournment debate tonight to ask for an end to the current situation in Canberra whereby persons booked for a variety of parking offences in the Australian Capital Territory cannot be fined.
—Shocking!

—It is rather. It is an extraordinary situation. For many months, even extending now to years, it has been common knowledge among Canberra people that although parking tickets can be issued to drivers who park illegally in areas reserved for disabled persons, doctors, diplomats, and members of parliament, they cannot be fined for it. As a result, there is no legal sanction at all on these offences. Some people offend over and over again, and the situation has become notorious. I believe that only in Canberra could there occur the degree of muddle and crass inefficiency that has led to this situation. Not only has it led to this situation, it also has resulted in its continuation. In this city which is supposed to be the central seat of law and government in Australia, it has not been possible for the administration that attempts to run it to see that efficient parking regulations are provided.

SPEECH.PARA: The problem, as I understand it, is in the contention concerning certain words in section 155 (4) of the Motor Traffic Ordinance. The courts have declined to hear cases which come forward, and there are very many such cases, due to insuperable evidenciary provisions imposed by magistrates. The Registrar of Motor Vehicles in Canberra has disagreed but, as there is no appeal available to a higher court, no other avenue except a redrafting of the Ordinance has been available.

I first became aware of this situation last year. I forget exactly when it was, but it would be at least a year ago when I became aware of the implications of this matter on the parking situation in front of this very place. The parking areas outside our place of work, the Senate and the House of Representatives, are supposed to be reserved for members and senators but are not reserved for them at all. I gather that parking tickets have been applied 40, 50, 60 or 70 times to the same car and because of the absurd bureaucratic bungle which has been going on and which nobody seems in the least inclined to fix up, the situation has continued. When I raised the matter last year-I think it was about a year ago-I said: 'Please fix it up. If you do not fix it up it will be necessary for someone eventually to raise it publicly which might induce some kind of action'.

I understand now that agreement has finally been reached. Amendments were proposed and the Attorney-General's Department, I gather, opposed them or took some issue with them for a considerable period, again extending into many months. This delayed the matter yet further. Now I am given to understand that agreement has finally been reached, draftsmen have looked at the problems surrounding authorisation and a final draft is being prepared right now. Nobody in this cloud cuckoo land seems to have any idea when the situation will be resolved because the redraft will be a complete overhaul of Part X of the Ordinance.

The Department of the Capital Territory has tried to do its best. It has had the international disabled insignia painted on the ground in each bay set aside for disabled drivers. This at least has induced some sense of responsibility in the community and there has been a drop-off in the number of people parking illegally in such places. Even so, the courts will refuse to hear any action brought forward by the Department in respect of those zones reserved for doctors, disabled persons, members of parliament or the diplomatic corps. Many thousands of people in Canberra are now perfectly well aware that they can park in those places and that no real action can be taken against them. This has created what to my mind is an absolutely Gilbertian situation. I would not really have believed the bureaucracy could have got itself into such a tangle with such a lack of concern for its proper function-its proper functioning after all is to administer this city property; that is what the bureaucracy is paid to do-that it could allow this situation to continue for so long.

We ask that the bureaucrats involved in this dismal affair now begin to stir themselves from their lethargy and do something to tidy up this mess as soon as they can. We ask that they do this because great inconvenience and indeed some dangers are involved in Canberra whereby doctors and disabled people are not able to rely on parking in areas which have been reasonably and justifiably reserved for them.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to refer to a Press release which was issued by the Acting Director of the Commonwealth Department of Education in Queensland, Mr Mackrell. The Press release was undated but it was received at my office on 6 April 1981. In the Press release Mr Mackrell said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . many needy families such as one parent or pension income families stand to miss out on a full term's entitlement of financial assistance for children in Year 11 and Year 12 under the Secondary Allowances Scheme (SAS).
The deadline for applications for full year entitlement is 16 April, the end of Term 1 . . .

The Press release goes on to point out that, because there has been a rearrangement of school terms in Queensland this year-in fact government schools have gone on to a semester basis-we now have four terms instead of three. The deadline for applications for full year entitlement at the end of term 1 is now much earlier than it was in previous years. In previous years the deadline would have been about another two weeks after 16 April. Mr Mackrell points out in his Press release that the number of applications received so far by the Department of Education in Brisbane is about 500 fewer than were received by the end of term 1 in 1980. It seems to me that because there is a new term arrangement in Queensland this year, a number of applications may not have been placed because people may have thought they still had further time to place those applications. I would not be surprised if some people thought they had until the end of the first semester because the word 'term' is used very rarely nowadays. People usually talk of semesters, and of semester 1 and semester 2.

TALK.START.PARA: —In normal events, when would the cut-off have been in previous years?

—The cut-off would have been about the first week of May. The first semester ends about the last week of June and I think many people probably thought they had until then to submit their applications. In fact it is half way through the first semester, some time in April, that the first half-semester, if I can put it that way, ends. That is apparently deemed to be a term. I would like the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) to refer this matter to the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) to see whether it is possible on this occasion to extend the period by which applications may be lodged because this is the first year in which this has arisen, even if it were only for another two weeks. It will be very difficult within the next week or so to get the information out into the country areas of Queensland so that people will be able to submit applications by 16 April.

SPEECH.PARA: I realise that there may be some statutory reason why the period cannot be extended. If that is so, it is one of those things that we will just have to accept. I ask the Minister for Education to look at this problem to see whether the period can be extended to give these people the opportunity of submitting an application and, therefore, perhaps being entitled to the $100-odd which is provided under the scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLaren Sen G.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise tonight a matter which I was forced to raise on 5 March; that is, the failure of the Government Whip to make an announcement after the first division on any day giving reasons why a member of the Opposition was not counted in a division. I think the situation is most unfair. I raised this matter on 5 March because that day was two days after the original division when two members of the Australian Labor Party remained out of the chamber and were not counted in the division. That happened because there were two vacancies in the Senate because of two resignations. The Labor Party is very strict with its members. Whenever we are in the Parliament, unless we have a pair, we attend divisions. People reading the Hansard of 3 March would wonder why two members of the Labor Party failed to attend a division in this place. They would have had to read Hansard of 5 March to find the reason.

SPEECH.PARA: I first raised this matter after the announcement was made by the Government Whip. I sought an assurance from him that it would not happen again. Today we had three divisions. I think, in all fairness to the Labor Party, the Government Whip should have made an announcement after the first division, as former Senator Poyser did when he was Government Whip. I quote from what he had to say on 12 February 1975. Under the heading 'Pairs' on page 109 of Senate Hansard for 12 February 1975 the following is reported:
Senator POYSER:I seek leave to make a brief statement in relation to the arrangements of pairs.
The PRESIDENT:Is leave granted? There being no dissent, leave is granted.
Senator POYSER:I wish to indicate that in the vote just taken and any future votes taken this evening Senator Bessell will be paired with the vacancy created by the resignation of Senator Murphy.

We now have a somewhat similar situation because of the unfortunate death of Senator Knight. There is a vacancy in the Senate. The Opposition Whip has been good enough to make the same arrangement with the Government Whip as Senator Poyser made when we were in government. I think the Government Whip failed in his duty by not raising this matter after the first division today. If that was an oversight, there have been two divisions since then when the fact that we had granted a pair and the reasons for granting it were not recorded. If I had not raised this matter tonight a fortnight would have passed without the Government Whip being reminded of his being remiss.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a lot of nonsense.

—It is not a lot of nonsense. I reminded the honourable senator of this matter on 5 March. He gave an undertaking that it would not happen again. I have waited for a statement after three divisions. I could have risen at the third reading stage of the Airlines Equipment (Loan Guarantee) Bill and reminded the honourable senator, but I did not. I now have to do so in the adjournment debate. I seek an assurance from the Government-if I cannot get it from the Government Whip I hope I can get it from the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Carrick)-that no member of the Labor Party will be put in this iniquitous position in any future division. If I do not receive an assurance I will move in the party room that pairs be not granted until the Government has the good grace to honour an undertaking that it gave.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kilgariff Sen B.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you may recall that earlier this evening before Senator McLaren spoke I indicated to you that I intended to seek the call to get leave to read a statement as I have done on other occasions. The statement reads: By arrangement between the Whips, Senator Georges did not vote in any previous division to compensate for the vacancy on the Government benches caused by the death of Senator Knight.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the situation. Much business has been conducted in the Senate today. I am making no criticism of you, Mr President. I endeavoured to get the call from another occupant of the chair but failed. The occupant of the chair did not see me stand. I intended to read the statement I have just read. I get considerable liaison from the Opposition Whip and other members of the Opposition. I thank them for the courtesies that have been experienced over the last three weeks. I think those courtesies and that liaison have made the Senate work quite well, with the result that we have got through the various debates and the occasional division. I point out to honourable senators and in particular to Senator McLaren that after a division it is not always possible in the hurly-burly of debate to be able to stand, get the call and make a statement. Whips have to check the pairs to ensure that no mistake is made. I absolutely disregard the criticism that Senator McLaren makes. I assure all honourable senators and particularly members of the Opposition that whenever they give me the courtesy of arranging pairs I will acknowledge it as soon as possible. This is what I have done tonight.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had several contributions to tonight's adjournment debate. I take first the matter raised by Senator McLaren. Everyone on this side of the chamber is grateful for the pair that is available for the vacancy created by the death of Senator Knight. It has been the practice since I have been a member of the Senate that whenever a vacancy has been created an arrangement has been made which cannot appear in the pairs list. Honourable senators will realise that this has been dealt with by the making of announcement. I point out how much I appreciate the co-operation that goes on between the Whips and the importance of this kind of arrangement to the good working of the Senate. I heard Senator Kilgariff's statement. One piece of business has been before the chair tonight. The adjournment was moved immediately that business was concluded. I ask honourable senators to accept what Senator Kilgariff said. Honourable senators want to acknowledge for the record the situation that is made possible by the arrangement that the Whips have made.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Colston raised a most interesting problem. It is one which I will refer to the Minister for Education (Mr Fife). I understand that there has been a new arrangement of the school year in Queensland in 1981 and that he is concerned that this may have inadvertently led some people into making assumptions about the closing date for applications under the secondary allowance scheme. I undertake to make sure that the Minister sees the Hansard and that Senator Colston's suggestion is made available to him at an early date. I think the problem that the honourable senator raises is interesting and unusual. I will see that we get an answer for him at an early date.

Senator Mason raised a question about the incorrect use of restricted parking areas by different groups of people and the non-enforceability of the Motor Traffic Ordinance. I think the honourable senator referred to section 155 (4) of that Ordinance, and to the fact that the courts will not enforce it. He made the point, if I understood him correctly, that the new ordinance will be ready for introduction shortly. He urged its early implementation. He described the situation as Gilbertian. The only words of William Schwenk Gilbert that come to mind are these:
But then the thought of dull MPs
All milling around in close proximity
And thinking for themselves
That no man can face with equanimity.

I undertake to convey the matter to the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman). Finally, I make an apology to Senator Mulvihill. He said during the adjournment debate last night-it is recorded at page 1267 of yesterday's Hansard-that he had made contact with my office in relation to some matters he wished to raise concerning a survey entitled 'Appraisal and implications of a survey of Abbott's Booby on Christmas Island'. He did inform my office. It was understood incorrectly at my end that Senator Mulvihill was to ask a question at Question Time today. My office had some information. I would have been present had we really understood what was required. I offer my apologies to the honourable senator. I have been advised that there has been much Press coverage of suggestions that the extension of protection of the Abbott's Booby bird will cause cessation of mining operations. This bird, which is an endangered species, is known to breed only on Christmas Island.

The Government is committed to the protection and preservation of the natural flora and fauna of Christmas Island. The Wild Animals Ordinance provides protection against the killing or taking of any wild bird. The Abbott's Booby bird, which is native to Christmas Island, is covered also by the Migratory Birds Ordinance 1980 and the Endangered Species Ordinance 1980. It appears that the Christmas Island Phosphate Commission or the British Phosphate Commission-we can call it what we like-is not under any general direction to restrict jungle clearing for Abbott's Booby conservation. With the assistance of the phosphate commissioners the Abbott's Booby has been under study since 1967 when a survey was carried out by Dr J. B. Nelson of Aberdeen University. Dr Nelson is a world authority on the bird. Because of growing concern to save Abbott's Booby, a detailed survey of its distribution and status on the island was carried out in 1979 and 1980.

Whilst the survey was under way and the results were being evaluated a moratorium on further clearing was instituted in certain central and western areas of the island known to be important breeding areas for Abbott's Booby. The moratorium expires some time around now but it can be extended if necessary. I understand that the results of the survey are being appraised at the moment by an expert panel which includes eminent Australians and, I understand, Dr Nelson, to whom I have already referred. Government decisions made will depend on the result of that assessment which, I hope, is progressing towards completion. I hope that answers the matters raised by the honourable senator.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to add to the response of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Senator Peter Baume) in respect of parking at Parliament House. The Usher of the Black Rod has been pursuing the question of the enforcement of parking restrictions on the Senate side of Parliament House since 20 August of last year. On 3 November the Registrar of Motor Vehicles replied to Black Rod indicating that the difficulties involved in drafting an enforceable ordinance appear at last to be overcome. However, it is also stated that increasing the penalties and rectifying the deficiencies which have prevented prosecution for various offences will not lead to a significant improvement in the regulation of parking. That will require a considerable increase in the number of offences which can be dealt with in the courts. Prosecution procedures at the moment are cumbersome and manpower intensive, Black Rod has been advised. It is hoped that all these improved measures will be in force by the middle of this year. It has been a problem which has been looked at over a long period. I think we all realise that. All which can be done is being done as constructively and as quickly as possible. I thank Senator Mason for raising the matter in the Senate tonight.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Grimes Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: Is the maintenance allowance paid by the Victorian Government to low income single parent families with secondary school children included in the income test for the purpose of calculating entitlements to widows and other pensions; if so, what justification is there for including such a payment in the income test when it is meant to compensate parents for the costs of education. What is the practice of other States in this matter.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: Under the provisions of the Social Services Act, payments made to a pensioner for or in respect of a child are not taken into account as the pensioner's income in assessing pension entitlement. The Act also contains another concession which, in effect, provides that the amount of income which a pensioner may have without affecting his pension entitlement is increased by $312 a year for each dependent child. However, the additional income allowed under this concession is reduced by any payment received for that child.

Thus, the payments in question made by the Victorian State Government are not considered as part of a pensioner's income. The payments do, however, reduce the extra income concession extended to the pensioner in respect of the dependent child concerned. Similar payments made by other State Governments would be treated in the same way.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 26 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Department of Social Security make any staff available to assist in flood relief in the Dalby area; if so, how many staff were allocated and what were their duties.
(2) Has any consideration been given to providing ex gratia payments to pensioners who face severe financial difficulties due to flood damage in the Dalby area.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The Department of Social Security made two social workers available to assist in flood relief in the Dalby area. Their duties included helping to devise strategies for the relief of victims, gathering necessary information and data relating to losses incurred by individuals and families, ascertaining the most pressing needs of members of the community, and providing general assistance and advice.

(2) No. Under arrangements introduced in 1978-79, the Commonwealth provides assistance on a $3 for $1 basis for expenditures by each State on agreed relief and restoration measures where such expenditures exceed annual base amounts established for the State. In addition the Commonwealth meets half the cost of assistance provided by the States for the immediate relief of personal hardship and distress. Accordingly, no special arrangements for pensioners in the Dalby area are seen to be required.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hamer Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 3 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does section 26(e) of the Income Tax Assessment Act require that the assessable income, for taxation purposes, of a taxpayer shall include the value to the taxpayer of all allowances, gratuities, compensations, benefits, bonuses and premiums allowed, given or granted in money, goods, land, meals, sustenance, the use of premises or quarters or otherwise.

(2) What are (a) the basis on which the value to the taxpayer would be determined; and (b) the consequential amount of tax payable at the 60% marginal tax rate for each of (i) the absolute use of a motor vehicle with a replacement value of $25,000 granted to an employee, including fuel and maintenance provided by the employer; (ii) the provision of a boarding 'scholarship' to a grammar school in a capital city valued at approximately $5,000 per year, per child, where the scholarship is an absolute gift to an employee and no academic competition is required for the granting of the scholarship; (iii) the free use of a house in a Melbourne suburb valued at approximately $200,000 or approximately $1,000 per month in rental with housekeeper services provided at the value of $10,000 per year and gardener at the value of $8,000 per year; (iv) an airline ticket valued at $2,000 awarded to an employee as a gift or prize in a non-existent contest by a travel agent which has formerly been given the $2,000 by an employer; and (v) the provision of an entertainment allowance of $3,600 to an employee; the allowance being provided through the use of a corporate credit card.
(3) What is the estimated total loss to government revenue from fringe benefits which are not returned by taxpayers or which are provided in ways which do not expose the benefits to section 26(e).

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable Senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for National Development and Energy, upon notice, on 26 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Which mining permits for oil exploratory purposes exist on the Great Barrier Reef.
(2) Who are the holders of these permits.
(3) When are the permits due for renewal.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Carrick Sen The Hon J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) There are five offshore petroleum exploration permits in force. Four permits, Q/4P, Q/5P, Q/6P and Q/7P, off the central coast and within the Great Barrier Reef Region as defined in the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act, are held by Australian Gulf Oil Company. Permit Q/11P, which is in Torres Strait, only partly extends into the Great Barrier Reef Region and is held by Gulf Interstate Overseas Ltd. Permit Q/10P was surrendered in October 1979.

(3) The conditions of these permits were suspended in 1971 pending the outcome of the Royal Commissions on Great Barrier Reef Petroleum Drilling. The permits were due for renewal in 1974 but decisions on the applications for renewal are still pending. This is consistent with the Government's decision announced by the Prime Minister on 4 June 1979 that there should be no renewal of petroleum exploration permits in the Great Barrier Reef Region until the results of both short and longer term research are known.
